Seventy patients with spontaneous and 21 with traumatic extracranial internal carotid artery dissections were studied clinically and angiographically with mean follow-ups of 64 (spontaneous group) and 40 months (traumatic group). Sixty percent of the patients in the spontaneous group and 71% in the traumatic group also had follow-up angiograms. In traumatic dissections aneurysms were common, significantly fewer aneurysms resolved or became smaller and fewer stenoses resolved or improved, whereas more stenoses progressed to occlusion. Traumatic dissections were more likely to leave the patients with neurological deficits. A significantly higher percentage of the patients with spontaneous dissections were asymptomatic at follow-up compared with the traumatic group. Although both spontaneous and traumatic dissections of extracranial internal carotid arteries mostly carry a good prognosis, the outcome may be somewhat less favorable for the traumatic group.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure. Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. Forty-two had failed irradiation for laryngeal carcinoma. Nine had supraglottic procedures, 3 endoscopic, and 31 vertical partial. Twelve (28%) required subsequent completion laryngectomy. Major complications included laryngeal stenosis in 1, incompetent laryngeal sphincters in 2, mucocutaneous fistulas in 3, and delayed deglutition in 3. Six patients had positive permanent section margins. In 5 of those, intraoperative frozen sections had been taken and were negative. Recurrent or persistent disease was eventually demonstrated in all patients with positive margins. The 2-year determinant disease-free survival rate for stage I and II disease was 85%. Three-year disease-free survival was 50% for stage III and IV disease. Partial laryngectomies, including supraglottic, can be done after irradiation failure with a high expectation of cure and acceptable morbidity. Immediate additional operation should be considered in patients with positive margins.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Using RG-C6 glioma-transplanted rats, we studied precontrast and postcontrast magnetic resonance imaging, extravasation of Evans blue, and histology. In all rats, tumor was enhanced with gadolinium-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (Gd-DTPA). The necrotic portion in the tumor, however, was not enhanced. Hemorrhage and hydrocephalus were clearly visualized on both the precontrast and postcontrast images. Blood-brain barrier-disrupted areas stained with Evans blue and areas enhanced with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging were nearly consistent. It is suggested that the mechanism of brain tumor enhancement with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging is simply related to the degree of alteration of the blood-brain barrier. The Gd-DTPA-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging, even with low magnetic field, is useful for the evaluation of size, shape, and location of experimental rat brain tumors.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. A clinical case series of 21 patients. New Mexico Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome Study Group. We reviewed 21 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome to describe the range of clinical findings in these patients. Most patients were women (20 [95%]) and middle-aged (mean, 46 years) and had taken the food supplement L-tryptophan (95%). All cases involved eosinophilia (eosinophil count, greater than or equal to 2.0 x 10(9)/L) and incapacitating myalgias. Fourteen (88%) of the 16 patients tested had mild liver function abnormalities. Aldolase levels were abnormal in all patients tested. Muscle biopsies were done in five patients; four showed eosinophilic perimyositis, and one had interstitial inflammation. No physical finding was pathognomonic or universal, but muscle tenderness, tachycardia, and rash were the most common signs found during physical examinations. Seven patients were treated with prednisone, and six showed improvement in muscle pain and a decrease in eosinophilia. The cause of this disorder is still unknown.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome). Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). The Shwachman syndrome comprises exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and bone marrow hypoplasia resulting in neutropenia. Clinical, morphological, and ultrastructural studies, as well as hair analysis, were performed in a patient with Shwachman's syndrome and severe ichthyosis. Clinical findings were lamellar ichthyosiform desquamation on the extremities. The hair was scanty and short on the scalp, in the eyelashes, and in the eyebrows. The nails were hyperkeratotic. Morphologic findings were slight, regular acanthosis and severe diffuse hyperkeratosis with variable parakeratosis. The granular layer was thickened. The papillary dermis showed very slight perivascular lymphocyte infiltration. The most prominent ultrastructural finding was the presence of solitary or multiple droplets of varying size in the cytoplasm of the keratinocytes. Hair analysis revealed no abnormalities; the cystine concentration in hair specimens was normal.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. We studied two related infants with a fatal mitochondrial disease, affecting muscle in one and liver in the other. Quantitative analysis revealed a severe depletion of mtDNA in affected tissues. This genetic abnormality was also observed in muscle of an unrelated infant with myopathy and in muscle and kidney of a fourth child with myopathy and nephropathy. Biochemistry, immunohistochemistry, and in situ hybridization showed that the depletion of mtDNA in muscle fibers was correlated with a respiratory chain defect and with lack of mitochondrially translated proteins. Although the differential tissue involvement in these infants suggests mtDNA heteroplasmy, sequence analysis of mtDNA replication origins did not reveal any abnormality that could account for the low copy number.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). Technetium-99m-Hexamibi [Hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (i)] was developed as a myocardial perfusion agent with biologic properties similar to those of thallium-201 (201TI). As 201TI has recently been observed to be of value for the diagnosis of brain tumors when used in conjunction with single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging technology, the possibility that the biologic similarity of the two radiopharmaceuticals extended to their affinity for tumors was tested. A 5-yr-old female patient with a brain stem astrocytoma showed marked focal uptake of 99mTc-Hexamibi at the site of tumor recurrence as defined by biopsy and prior 201TI/SPECT study. Tumor-to-normal cortex radioactivity ratios for the 99mTc-Hexamibi/SPECT study were 132:1 and the spatial resolution of the 99mTc-Hexamibi images was high. This observation suggests that 99mTc-Hexamibi merits further study as a potential agent for SPECT imaging of human brain tumors.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary acinar development was assessed in 17 autopsy cases of pulmonary hypoplasia associated with diaphragmatic hernia. Morphologic examination was conducted by light and electron microscopy, and morphometric study was achieved by radial alveolar count and biochemical quantitation of surfactant phospholipid. In most cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia, the ipsilateral lung was underdeveloped morphologically and biochemically compared with the contralateral lung. However, both ipsilateral and contralateral lungs were well developed in some cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia. Thus, acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia is varied. The influence of other conditions, such as oligohydramnios, polyhydramnios, and other anomalies that may influence retention of lung fluid or fetal respiratory movement, should be considered to assess the acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. A 22-yr-old subject with moderate developmental dyslexia experienced poor memory from an early age. In spite of normal intelligence he had great difficulty in learning historical and geographical names, mathematical formulae, poems and songs, and verbal series such as the letters of the alphabet and the months of the year. His recognition of familiar faces was also faulty at times. A battery of memory tests confirmed a moderate deficit of verbal as well as visual memory, whereas spatial memory was preserved. Other cognitive functions were intact, except for a mild reading disability. No evidence of brain pathology was provided by his history, neurological examination and CT scanning.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. A large variety of topical drugs and a selection of orally active antifungals are currently available. The choice between the use of oral drugs or intravaginal agents will depend on the therapeutic results obtained with the different agents, side effects, pregnancy status, and patient preference. The results obtained in the Maria Hospital, Tilburg, The Netherlands, and a review of foreign data suggest the following: (1) For acute infection oral and topical agents produce equivalent results. (2) For chronic infections oral medication is preferred. (3) Oral therapy should not be given to pregnant patients or to patients not using reliable contraceptive measures. (4) Half the patients prefer oral medication; only 5% prefer intravaginal therapy, and the others had no clear preference.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is an asymptomatic, noninflammatory cystic swelling that typically involves the anthelix of the ear and results from an accumulation of fluid within an unlined intracartilaginous cavity. We report a patient with a recurrent pseudocyst of the auricle and describe a new surgical technique for treating this condition by applying 50% trichloroacetic acid to the intracartilaginous cavity and utilizing external button bolsters for compressive therapy. This therapeutic approach is simple to perform in the office, results in permanent resolution of the pseudocyst, preserves the normal architecture of the external ear, and provides excellent postoperative and long-term cosmetic results.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Specimens of normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa from 52 patients were analysed by immunohistochemistry using a monospecific polyclonal antiserum against human pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI). In normal colonic mucosa PSTI was found in the goblet cells in the basal parts of the crypts. In adenomas of tubular, villous, and tubulo-villous types PSTI was also found in the upper parts of the polyps, usually occurring in the regeneration zone. There was a more intense staining reaction in polyps with increased atypia. Carcinomas of different types and of various grades of differentiation and of in situ type did not contain PSTI. These findings indicate that PSTI could be a marker for adenomatous rather than carcinomatous epithelium in the colon. Furthermore, the absence of the inhibitor in malignant cells might facilitate tissue invasion by malignant cells because of deficient protease inhibition.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is a frequent occurrence. A new surgical technique has been designed and was used successfully in 18 patients with ideal results. The key point of the operation is to turn over a flap of rectus abdominis muscle to envelop the bladder. Contraction of the muscle flap and the abdominal muscles would enhance voiding ability. In the meantime, the bladder is displaced forward and the resultant change in the bladder-posterior urethral angle also favors voiding. Since the bladder is near the anterior abdominal wall manual compression during voiding is made easier. All of these advantages greatly facilitate voiding.

Percutaneous urinary diversion in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. Percutaneous urinary diversion has been used as a palliative treatment option for patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of percutaneous urinary diversion in this patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 30 patients who underwent percutaneous urinary diversion between 2005 and 2010. The median follow-up period was 12 months. The results showed that percutaneous urinary diversion was successful in achieving adequate urinary drainage in all patients. However, complications such as infection and blockage were observed in a subset of patients. Overall, percutaneous urinary diversion was found to be a feasible option for managing urinary symptoms in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer, although careful patient selection and close monitoring for complications are necessary.

Histologic evaluation of the larynx in sudden infant death syndrome. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is responsible for a significant number of infant deaths worldwide. The etiology of SIDS is still largely unknown, and various theories have been proposed to explain its occurrence. One of these theories suggests that laryngeal abnormalities may be involved in SIDS. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the histologic findings in the larynx of infants who died from SIDS. 

Postmortem examination of the larynx was performed in a cohort of SIDS cases, and the histologic features were compared to a control group of infants who died from other causes. We found that the SIDS group had a significantly higher prevalence of laryngeal abnormalities, including edema, congestion, and inflammation, compared to the control group. These findings suggest that laryngeal abnormalities may be implicated in the pathogenesis of SIDS.

Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanism by which laryngeal abnormalities contribute to SIDS and to explore potential preventive measures targeting these abnormalities. Identification and understanding of these histologic changes may have implications for the early detection and management of infants at risk for SIDS.

Immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumor of the lacrimal gland. Mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland are rare neoplasms with both benign and malignant components. These tumors have variable clinical presentations, making accurate diagnosis challenging. This study aimed to evaluate the immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland to improve diagnostic accuracy.

A retrospective analysis was performed on archived specimens from patients diagnosed with mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland. Immunohistochemical staining was performed for various markers, including smooth muscle actin, Ki-67, and p53.

The results revealed that benign mixed tumors predominantly expressed smooth muscle actin, indicating the presence of myoepithelial cells. Malignant mixed tumors, on the other hand, showed increased expression of Ki-67 and p53, suggesting higher proliferative activity and p53 protein accumulation.

These findings suggest that immunohistochemical analysis can aid in differentiating between benign and malignant components of mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland. This information can guide clinicians in determining appropriate management strategies for these rare neoplasms, ensuring optimal patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore their potential clinical impact.

Collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients: changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen in serum. We investigated the changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) in the serum of gynecologic patients to evaluate collagen metabolism. Serum samples were collected from 120 gynecologic patients, including non-pregnant women, pregnant women, and pre- and post-menopausal women. The concentration of PIIINP was measured using a specific radioimmunoassay. We found that the PIIINP levels were significantly elevated in pregnant women compared to non-pregnant women, indicating an increased collagen turnover during pregnancy. In pre-menopausal women, the PIIINP levels were significantly higher compared to post-menopausal women, suggesting a decline in collagen synthesis with menopausal transition. Furthermore, in gynecologic patients with various pathological conditions, the PIIINP levels were significantly elevated compared to healthy controls, indicating an imbalance in collagen metabolism. These findings highlight the potential utility of PIIINP as a biomarker for evaluating collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients and may have implications for the diagnosis and treatment of gynecologic disorders.

Elevated soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels in patients with active multiple sclerosis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system characterized by demyelination and inflammation. The pathogenesis of MS involves the activation of T lymphocytes and the release of various cytokines. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a key cytokine involved in the regulation of T cell responses. In this study, we aimed to investigate the levels of soluble IL-2 receptor (sIL-2R) in patients with active MS. Blood samples were collected from 50 MS patients and 50 healthy controls. ELISA assays were performed to measure the levels of sIL-2R. Our results revealed significantly elevated levels of sIL-2R in MS patients compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, sIL-2R levels were positively correlated with disease severity, as assessed by the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS). These findings suggest that sIL-2R may serve as a potential biomarker for disease activity in MS and could potentially be targeted for therapeutic interventions. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and validate the clinical utility of sIL-2R in MS management.

Further evaluation of radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. Parotid carcinoma is a rare and aggressive malignancy of the salivary glands. Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for advanced cases, but its efficacy remains limited. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and outcomes of radical surgery following radiotherapy in advanced parotid carcinoma.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 patients who underwent radical surgery after receiving radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. Surgical complications, disease-free survival, and overall survival were assessed. 

The results showed that radical surgery after radiotherapy was feasible, with acceptable rates of surgical complications. The mean disease-free survival and overall survival were 26.4 months and 40.6 months, respectively. Moreover, patients with negative surgical margins had significantly better outcomes compared to those with positive margins.

In conclusion, radical surgery following radiotherapy is a viable option for selected patients with advanced parotid carcinoma. It offers a chance for improved disease control and survival outcomes. However, careful patient selection and surgical expertise are essential for optimal results. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize treatment strategies.

Does auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation reverse hypersplenism and portal hypertension? In this study, performed to assess the effect of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism, eight patients with chronic liver disease who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were analyzed. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on hypersplenism and portal hypertension. Eight patients with chronic liver disease who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were included. The results showed that auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation successfully reversed hypersplenism, as evidenced by increased platelet counts and decreased spleen size. However, portal hypertension remained unchanged in most patients. These findings suggest that while auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation may have beneficial effects on hypersplenism, it may not fully alleviate portal hypertension. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms underlying these observations and explore additional treatment options for portal hypertension in liver transplant patients.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This technique involves examining the chromosomes within interphase nuclei using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or other similar methods. By targeting specific chromosomal regions or genes with fluorescently labeled probes, alterations in chromosome number or structure can be detected. 

Several applications of interphase cytogenetic analysis have been identified in the field of neoplastic disorders. Firstly, it aids in detecting clonal abnormalities, such as chromosomal translocations, deletions, and amplifications, which are frequently associated with certain malignancies. Additionally, interphase cytogenetics enables the identification of minimal residual disease, allowing for monitoring of treatment response and evaluation of disease progression. Furthermore, it assists in identifying prognostic markers and classifying tumor subtypes based on genetic alterations, thereby contributing to personalized treatment strategies. 

Overall, interphase cytogenetic analysis serves as a valuable tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Advancements in this field continue to improve our understanding of the underlying genetic mechanisms of these diseases and have the potential to revolutionize diagnostic and therapeutic approaches in the future.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with a rare tumour, known as paraganglioma, located in the bladder. The patient initially presented with gross hematuria and was found to have anemia and abnormal coagulation parameters. Further investigations revealed a large intravesical mass. The patient underwent transurethral resection of the tumor and subsequent histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of paraganglioma. However, during the surgical procedure, the patient experienced persistent bleeding, which required meticulous hemostasis techniques and multiple blood transfusions. This case highlights the unique challenge of achieving adequate hemostasis in patients with paraganglioma, as these tumors are known to secrete hormones and vasoactive substances that can result in abnormal coagulation. Clinicians should be aware of this potential complication to ensure timely and effective management.

Functional heart replacement with the spindle pump: first results. This study reports the initial outcomes of functional heart replacement using the spindle pump in patients with end-stage heart failure. Three patients underwent the implantation of the spindle pump as a bridge to heart transplantation. The device demonstrated good hemodynamic performance with improved cardiac output and reduced ventricular filling pressures. All patients were successfully weaned off mechanical ventilation postoperatively. One patient developed a minor bleeding complication that was managed conservatively. No device-related infections or thromboembolic events were observed during the study period. These preliminary results suggest that the spindle pump may provide a viable option for functional heart replacement in patients with end-stage heart failure. Further studies with larger patient cohorts are needed to assess long-term outcomes and potential complications.

Memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra postulate for essential blepharospasm. Essential blepharospasm (EB) is an involuntary eyelid closure disorder characterized by repetitive spasms of the orbicularis oculi muscles. The pathophysiology of EB remains unclear, although dysfunction in the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuitry has been proposed. In this study, we investigated the role of the substantia nigra (SN) in EB using memory-contingent saccades (MCS), a task known to engage the SN for accurate eye movement control. We recruited 20 patients with EB and 20 age-matched healthy controls. Participants performed an MCS task, where they were instructed to make a saccade to a remembered target location after a brief delay. Results showed that patients with EB exhibited impaired MCS performance compared to controls, characterized by decreased accuracy and longer reaction times. Neuroimaging analyses revealed reduced activation in the SN during the delay period in patients with EB. These findings suggest that dysfunction in the SN may contribute to the pathophysiology of EB and highlight the potential role of the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuitry in this disorder.

Pressor systems in hypertension and congestive heart failure. Hypertension and congestive heart failure are two common cardiovascular disorders that share a complex underlying pathophysiology. Both conditions involve alterations in the pressor systems, which regulate blood pressure and fluid balance. This review aims to explore the role of pressor systems in the development and progression of hypertension and congestive heart failure.

The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) are two major pressor systems involved in these disorders. Activation of the RAAS leads to vasoconstriction and sodium and water retention, contributing to increased blood pressure. Similarly, enhanced SNS activity results in increased cardiac output and peripheral vasoconstriction.

Multiple factors, including genetic predisposition, endothelial dysfunction, and neurohormonal imbalances, contribute to the dysregulation of these pressor systems. Understanding the intricate interactions between the RAAS, SNS, and other contributing factors is crucial for developing effective therapeutic strategies for managing hypertension and congestive heart failure.

In conclusion, dysregulation of pressor systems plays a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of hypertension and congestive heart failure. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and explore novel therapeutic targets for these cardiovascular disorders.

A dentist's dilemma: nonsurgical endodontic therapy or periapical surgery for teeth with apparent pulpal pathosis and an associated periapical radiolucent lesion. Treating teeth with pulpal pathosis and periapical radiolucent lesions poses a common dilemma for dentists. The decision between nonsurgical endodontic therapy and periapical surgery is often challenging, as both approaches have their advantages and limitations. Nonsurgical endodontic therapy involves cleaning and shaping the root canal system to eliminate infection, followed by obturation to create a hermetic seal. This conservative approach is usually the first choice due to its high success rate and minimal invasiveness. However, in some cases, nonsurgical therapy may not effectively eliminate the infection or promote periapical healing. In such situations, periapical surgery becomes necessary to remove the infected tissue and restore periapical health. This abstract highlights the dilemma faced by dentists and emphasizes the importance of careful assessment and decision-making based on individual patient factors and clinical findings.

Inhibition of neutrophil migration by tumor necrosis factor. Neutrophil migration plays a crucial role in inflammation and is regulated by various factors, including tumor necrosis factor (TNF). This study aimed to investigate the effect of TNF on neutrophil migration. Neutrophils were isolated from healthy individuals and subjected to a chemotaxis assay in the presence or absence of TNF. Results showed that TNF significantly inhibited neutrophil migration towards the chemoattractant. Additionally, TNF treatment decreased the expression of key chemotactic receptors on neutrophils, including CXCR1 and CXCR2. Mechanistically, TNF-mediated inhibition of neutrophil migration was found to be mediated through the downregulation of RhoA/Rho-associated protein kinase (ROCK) signaling pathway. This study provides valuable insights into the regulatory mechanisms of neutrophil migration and highlights the potential therapeutic implications by targeting TNF signaling to modulate inflammation and immune responses.

Right ventricular infarction: a clinical case study.  In this article we review the specific case of Mrs. Right ventricular infarction is a rare but potentially lethal complication of acute myocardial infarction. It is often associated with a poor outcome due to delayed diagnosis and management challenges. This case study presents the clinical course of Mrs. X, a 60-year-old woman who presented with typical symptoms of myocardial infarction but was initially misdiagnosed. Subsequent electrocardiogram and echocardiogram findings confirmed the diagnosis of right ventricular infarction. Prompt initiation of thrombolytic therapy and supportive care resulted in favorable outcomes. This case underscores the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of right ventricular infarction to improve patient outcomes. Further research is needed to establish optimal treatment strategies for this challenging condition.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. We present a case of a patient with apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face along with a small retrosplenial hemorrhage. The patient, a 52-year-old male, presented with asymmetry of the face and was found to have a small hemorrhage in the retrosplenial region on neuroimaging. The patient did not have any other neurological symptoms or signs. A thorough evaluation was conducted, including a detailed medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests, to rule out other possible causes of facial asymmetry. The patient was followed up for 6 months, during which time the facial asymmetry gradually resolved. This case highlights the importance of considering intracranial pathologies, such as small hemorrhages, in the differential diagnosis of facial asymmetry. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms underlying this presentation and to guide appropriate management.

Open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses.  During a 7-year period, 11 adult members of the religious sect Jehovah's Witnesses underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses, who refuse blood transfusion due to religious beliefs. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 11 Jehovah's Witness patients who underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation over a 7-year period. The mean age of the patients was 58.5 years. Operative procedures included coronary artery bypass grafting (n=7), valve replacement (n=3), and combined procedures (n=1). Measures to minimize blood loss and conserve blood were implemented, including the use of cell salvage and meticulous surgical techniques. Despite the absence of blood transfusions, all patients survived the surgery without major complications, demonstrating that open-heart surgery can be safely performed in Jehovah's Witnesses with appropriate management strategies. Close collaboration between the surgical team, anesthesiologists, and transfusion medicine specialists is crucial in ensuring patient safety and successful outcomes.

The use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging to determine lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. Gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been widely utilized for the evaluation of various medical conditions. In this study, we aimed to investigate the usefulness of gadolinium-enhanced MRI in determining the lesion site in patients with traumatic facial paralysis. A total of 20 patients with traumatic facial paralysis underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI. The presence and extent of nerve edema and enhancement were assessed, and the lesion site was determined based on these findings. The results showed that gadolinium-enhanced MRI accurately depicted the location and extent of nerve injury in all cases. Additionally, the presence and extent of nerve enhancement correlated well with the severity of facial nerve injury. These findings suggest that gadolinium-enhanced MRI can be a valuable tool in determining the lesion site in patients with traumatic facial paralysis, aiding in the planning of appropriate treatment strategies.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation (TCP) using different treatment durations of 1.5 or 3 seconds in patients with glaucoma. A total of 40 eyes from 40 patients were included in the study. The laser therapy was performed using a noncontact Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. 

The patients were divided into two groups: Group A received TCP treatment for 1.5 seconds, while Group B received TCP treatment for 3 seconds. In both groups, intraocular pressure (IOP) was measured before and after the TCP procedure. Additionally, visual acuity, visual field, and complications were assessed during follow-up visits.

Preliminary results revealed a significant reduction in IOP in both groups compared to baseline. However, the reduction in IOP was higher in Group B (treated for 3 seconds) compared to Group A (treated for 1.5 seconds). No significant complications were observed during the follow-up period. 

In conclusion, noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation using both 1.5 and 3-second treatment durations showed efficacy in reducing IOP. However, longer treatment durations may lead to further IOP reduction. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and determine the optimal treatment duration for different glaucoma types.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a well-known risk factor for sudden death, a condition that accounts for a significant proportion of cardiovascular mortality. To investigate the relationship between IHD and sudden death, a retrospective case-control study was conducted. Medical records of individuals who suffered sudden death were reviewed and compared to controls without sudden death. The results showed a significant association between IHD and sudden death, with individuals diagnosed with IHD having a higher likelihood of experiencing sudden death compared to those without IHD. Additionally, further analysis revealed that the risk of sudden death was significantly increased in individuals with severe coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. These findings underscore the importance of early detection and management of IHD to prevent sudden death. Additionally, they highlight the need for further research into risk stratification and preventive strategies for individuals with IHD.

Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy. Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that requires prompt diagnosis and intervention. This abstract describes a case study of a pregnant woman who presented with sudden severe abdominal pain and hematuria. Upon examination, a rupture of the right kidney was detected, which was most likely caused by the increased pressure on the renal parenchyma during pregnancy. The patient immediately underwent an emergency laparotomy and a partial nephrectomy was performed to control bleeding and preserve renal function. Although the etiology of spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is not well understood, it is believed to be associated with preexisting renal abnormalities, trauma, or increased intra-abdominal pressure. This case highlights the importance of considering renal rupture in the differential diagnosis of acute abdominal pain in pregnant women and the need for timely surgical intervention to prevent life-threatening complications.

Transient cyst-like cortical defects following fractures in children. Fractures in children can be followed by transient cyst-like cortical defects, which are commonly observed on radiographs. This study aims to evaluate the clinical significance of these defects and provide a simplified diagnostic approach. A total of 65 children with fractures were included in the study and followed up for a mean period of 6 months. The presence of cyst-like defects was assessed through radiographic examination. Among the participants, 28 (43.1%) had cyst-like defects following their fractures. None of the children reported any symptoms related to these defects, and all of them showed complete resolution within 6 months without any intervention. Therefore, cyst-like cortical defects following fractures in children can be considered a benign and self-limiting phenomenon, without any need for further investigation or intervention.

Cervicography for evaluating the "atypical" Papanicolaou smear. Cervicography, a specialized technique for evaluating the cervix, has been proposed as a valuable tool in the assessment of "atypical" Papanicolaou (Pap) smears. This study aimed to determine the efficacy of cervicography in detecting abnormalities and guiding further management in women with atypical Pap smears. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 women who underwent cervicography after an atypical Pap smear result. Results revealed that cervicography identified abnormal findings in 84% of cases, including the presence of acetowhite epithelium and vascular patterns indicative of high-grade lesions. Among these patients, colposcopy confirmed the cervicography findings, and subsequent biopsies revealed high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or invasive cervical cancer. The sensitivity and specificity of cervicography for detecting high-grade lesions were found to be 92% and 86%, respectively. These findings suggest that cervicography can provide useful information in the evaluation of atypical Pap smears and assist in decision-making regarding further diagnostic procedures and treatment interventions.

Comparison of characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma associated with head and neck cancer and those with gastric cancer.  In ongoing reviews of 339 patients with surgically treated primary squamous cell carcinoma, there were 19 (5. 5%) cases associated with head and neck cancer and 12 (3.5%) cases associated with gastric cancer. The aim of this retrospective study was to compare the characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) associated with head and neck cancer and those associated with gastric cancer. Patients with ESCC and either head and neck cancer or gastric cancer were evaluated for various demographic, clinical, and pathological factors. The results showed that ESCC associated with head and neck cancer had a higher incidence of lymph node metastasis, advanced tumor stage, and poorer overall survival compared to ESCC associated with gastric cancer. Additionally, patients with ESCC associated with head and neck cancer were more likely to have a history of smoking and alcohol consumption. These findings suggest that ESCC associated with head and neck cancer may represent a distinct subtype with worse prognosis compared to ESCC associated with gastric cancer. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatment strategies for these subtypes of ESCC.

Hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children.  To study Ca metabolism in critically ill children, we measured ionized Ca (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3, and gastrin levels in critically ill children and in healthy controls. We analyzed the levels of ionized calcium (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3), and gastrin in critically ill children and compared them to healthy controls to investigate calcium metabolism in this population. Our study included 45 critically ill children and 25 healthy controls. We found that critically ill children had significantly lower levels of ionized calcium and 1-25[OH]2D3 compared to healthy controls. Additionally, they had higher levels of calcitonin and gastrin. There was no significant difference in PTH and 25[OH] D3 levels between the two groups. These findings suggest that critically ill children experience alterations in calcium metabolism, characterized by hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia, which may have implications for their clinical management. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for these disturbances.

Tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. Pressure ulcers are a common and debilitating condition, particularly in individuals with limited mobility or those with certain medical conditions. Tissue expansion has emerged as a promising treatment modality for promoting wound healing and reducing the risk of complications in pressure ulcer management. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 50 patients with pressure ulcers who underwent tissue expansion. The results showed that tissue expansion led to a significant reduction in ulcer size, with an average reduction of 60% observed over a period of 12 weeks. Furthermore, tissue expansion resulted in improved wound healing, reduction in pain, and enhanced patient satisfaction. This study highlights the potential of tissue expansion as a valuable therapeutic option in the management of pressure ulcers. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the long-term effectiveness of this treatment approach.

Ganglioglioma: a clinical study with long-term follow-up. This clinical study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics and long-term outcomes of ganglioglioma. A retrospective analysis of 60 patients with ganglioglioma was performed. The mean age at diagnosis was 27.3 years, with a slight male predominance. Seizures were the most common presenting symptom, observed in 75% of patients. Radiological examination showed that the majority of tumors were located in the temporal lobe. Gross total resection was achieved in 70% of cases. The 5-year overall survival rate was 83.3%, with no significant differences based on age, gender, tumor location, or extent of resection. However, patients with higher histological grades and presence of anaplastic features had worse survival outcomes. Long-term follow-up revealed a low incidence of tumor recurrence and progression. These findings support the importance of aggressive surgical resection and regular surveillance in the management of ganglioglioma.

Novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies. Neuroendocrine malignancies exhibit unique cell surface antigens that can serve as potential diagnostic and therapeutic targets. This abstract aims to review the latest discoveries in the field of novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies. Currently, several neuroendocrine markers, such as chromogranin A, synaptophysin, and CD56, are commonly used for diagnostic purposes. However, the identification of additional antigens specific to neuroendocrine tumors can improve their detection and provide opportunities for targeted therapies.

Recent studies have identified promising novel antigens, including neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), CD146, insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R), and somatostatin receptors (SSTRs). These antigens have shown high specificity in neuroendocrine malignancies and have the potential to enhance the accuracy of diagnosis and prognostication. Moreover, targeting these antigens with monoclonal antibodies or peptide receptor radionuclide therapy has shown promising results in preclinical and clinical studies.

In conclusion, the identification of novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies holds great promise for improving diagnosis, prognosis, and targeted therapies. Further research is needed to validate these antigens' clinical significance and to develop novel treatment strategies for patients with neuroendocrine tumors.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. Scalenus anticus syndrome (SAS) is a rare condition characterized by compression of the brachial plexus and/or subclavian artery by the scalenus anticus muscle. This case report describes a 28-year-old cellist who presented with persistent pain and coldness in her left upper extremity. Physical examination revealed muscle atrophy and weakness in the left hand and forearm, as well as thermal asymmetry with the affected side being colder than the contralateral side. Nerve conduction studies and electromyography confirmed the diagnosis of SAS. Treatment consisted of physical therapy and avoidance of activities that exacerbated symptoms. The patient experienced gradual improvement in pain and coldness, as well as improvement in muscle strength and function. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and appropriately diagnosing SAS in musicians who present with upper extremity pain and dysfunction. Early intervention can lead to favorable outcomes and prevent long-term complications.

The progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. The objective of this study was to investigate the progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. A total of 342 individuals with mild dementia, living in the community, were enrolled in the study and followed up for a period of five years. The progression of dementia was assessed using various cognitive, functional, and behavioral measures. 

The results showed that the majority of individuals with mild idiopathic dementia experienced a decline in cognitive function over the five-year period. Specifically, there was a significant decline in memory, attention, and executive function. Functional abilities, such as activities of daily living, also deteriorated over time. Moreover, there was an increase in behavioral symptoms, including agitation and apathy.

The rate of progression varied among individuals, with some showing a faster decline than others. Factors such as age, education level, and presence of comorbidities were found to be associated with faster progression of dementia.

In conclusion, this study highlights the progressive nature of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. These findings have important implications for the early identification and management of individuals with mild dementia, as well as the provision of support and care for patients and their families.

Renal disease in noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Renal disease poses a significant burden on individuals with noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). This abstract aims to explore the association between NIDDM and renal disease as well as potential preventive strategies. NIDDM patients are at an increased risk of developing renal complications, including diabetic nephropathy. These complications result from the complex interplay of genetic and environmental factors, including hyperglycemia, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and obesity. Early detection and management of these risk factors, alongside optimization of glycemic control, blood pressure, and lipid levels, can prevent or delay the progression of renal disease in NIDDM. Implementing comprehensive patient education, regular monitoring, and effective pharmacological intervention are crucial for primary prevention and reduction of the renal disease burden in NIDDM patients.

Cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 by MA-10 Leydig tumor cells.  The present studies were directed toward understanding the cellular processing of the cholesterol analogue, NP59. The cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 were investigated in MA-10 Leydig tumor cells. The results indicated that NP59 was rapidly internalized by the cells within 5 minutes of exposure. The internalized NP59 was primarily localized in the cytoplasm, with minimal presence in the nucleus. The transport of NP59 within the cell was found to be mediated by vesicular transport and not by diffusion. Furthermore, the esterification of NP59 with fatty acids was observed within the cell, suggesting its incorporation into lipid droplets. Taken together, these findings suggest that NP59 is efficiently taken up by MA-10 Leydig tumor cells and transported within the cell, where it undergoes esterification. These results provide valuable insights into the cellular processing of NP59, which may have implications for its potential use in diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

Thoracic spinal fractures and aortic rupture: a significant and fatal association.  We analyzed the frequency of occurrence of traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the frequency of traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. A total of 120 patients with TAR were included, of which 60 had associated thoracic spinal fractures and 60 did not. The mean age of the patients was 45 years, with a slight male predominance (58%). The overall mortality rate was 65%. Of the patients with thoracic spinal fractures, 90% had associated TAR, while only 10% of patients without spinal fractures had TAR. The odds ratio for TAR in patients with thoracic spinal fractures was 33.4 (95% confidence interval, 15.8-70.7), indicating a significant and fatal association. These findings highlight the importance of considering thoracic spinal fractures as a risk factor for TAR in trauma patients and emphasize the need for early recognition and prompt management to improve outcomes.

Use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. The use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas was evaluated in a retrospective study. A total of 47 patients with suspected or known posterior fossa hemangioblastomas underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI. The imaging findings were correlated with the surgical and histopathological results. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI accurately identified and localized all posterior fossa hemangioblastomas in the study population. Additionally, it provided valuable information regarding tumor size, vascularity, and involvement of surrounding structures. Furthermore, gadolinium-enhanced MRI aided in the pre-operative planning and determination of surgical candidates, as well as in the post-operative follow-up and assessment of treatment response. The results of this study demonstrate that gadolinium-enhanced MRI is a highly effective tool in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas.

Prognostic factors for survival of patients with advanced urothelial tumors treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin chemotherapy. The aim of this study was to identify prognostic factors for survival in patients with advanced urothelial tumors treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin (MVAC) chemotherapy. A retrospective analysis of 87 patients who underwent MVAC chemotherapy for advanced urothelial tumors was performed. Clinical and pathological factors were evaluated for their association with overall survival (OS). The median OS for the entire cohort was 14.2 months. Univariate analysis revealed that poor performance status, high tumor grade, advanced stage, presence of liver metastasis, and absence of complete response to MVAC were significant predictors of worse OS. Multivariate analysis confirmed that poor performance status, high tumor grade, and liver metastasis were independent prognostic factors for shorter survival. These findings suggest that performance status, tumor grade, and presence of liver metastasis are useful predictors of survival in patients receiving MVAC chemotherapy for advanced urothelial tumors. Such information can aid in the identification of high-risk patients who may benefit from alternative treatment strategies or closer follow-up.

Brain protection: physiological and pharmacological considerations. The brain is a vital organ that requires special protection due to its susceptibility to injury and limited regenerative capacity. This review focuses on the physiological and pharmacological considerations for brain protection. 

Physiological mechanisms of brain protection include the blood-brain barrier, which regulates the exchange of molecules between the blood and the brain, and cerebral blood flow autoregulation, which ensures a stable supply of oxygen and nutrients to the brain. Additionally, neuroprotective mechanisms such as antioxidant defense systems and heat shock proteins help to mitigate the effects of oxidative stress and protein misfolding.

Pharmacological interventions for brain protection include agents that target excitotoxicity, oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis. These include N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antagonists, antioxidants, anti-inflammatory drugs, and caspase inhibitors. Some promising pharmacological strategies under investigation include hypothermia, neurotrophic factors, and stem cell transplantation.

Overall, a multifaceted approach that combines physiological and pharmacological interventions may hold promise for improving brain protection and preventing neurological disorders. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms of brain protection and develop effective therapeutic strategies.

Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus: a review 1830-1989. Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus, also known as Sister Mary Joseph nodules, are rare and often associated with advanced malignancies. This retrospective review aimed to evaluate the characteristics and outcomes of patients diagnosed with umbilical metastases from 1830 to 1989. A thorough literature search identified 123 cases, with the primary tumor most commonly originating from the gastrointestinal tract, particularly the stomach. The review found that umbilical metastases were frequently a sign of advanced disease and carried a poor prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of only 7.8%. Further research is necessary to better understand the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management of metastatic tumors involving the umbilicus.

The pharmacology of aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents. Aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents are commonly used pharmacological interventions in the management of various thrombotic disorders. Aspirin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, functions as an irreversible inhibitor of platelet cyclooxygenase, thereby impeding the synthesis of thromboxane A2 and ultimately inhibiting platelet aggregation. Heparin, a glycosaminoglycan, acts as an anticoagulant by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III and inhibiting factors IIa (thrombin) and Xa. Coumarin derivatives, such as warfarin, exert their anticoagulant effects through inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase, which disrupts the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Thrombolytic agents, such as tissue plasminogen activator, streptokinase, or urokinase, work by converting plasminogen to plasmin, thereby facilitating the breakdown of fibrin clots. Understanding the mechanisms of action and appropriate utilization of these pharmacological agents is crucial in the treatment and prevention of thrombotic disorders.

Cheilitis granulomatosa: report of six cases and review of the literature. Cheilitis granulomatosa is a rare condition characterized by chronic swelling and granulomatous inflammation of the lips. In this case report, we present six cases of cheilitis granulomatosa and provide a thorough review of the existing literature. The onset of symptoms varied among the cases, with some patients experiencing intermittent episodes and others presenting with persistent swelling. Histopathological examination revealed non-caseating granulomas in all cases. Various treatment options were utilized, including systemic corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, and surgical interventions. Although the etiology of cheilitis granulomatosa remains unknown, the condition is often associated with other systemic disorders such as Crohn's disease and sarcoidosis. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management strategies for this challenging condition.

Steroids induce acetylcholine receptors on cultured human muscle: implications for myasthenia gravis. Steroids have long been used as an effective treatment option for various autoimmune diseases, including myasthenia gravis (MG). However, the exact mechanism by which steroids exert their therapeutic effects in MG remains unclear. This study aims to investigate the impact of steroids on acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) in cultured human muscle cells and its potential implications for MG.

Cultured human muscle cells were treated with different concentrations of steroids, including dexamethasone and prednisone. The expression and functionality of AChRs were assessed using immunocytochemistry and electrophysiological techniques, respectively.

The results revealed a significant increase in the number of AChRs in steroid-treated muscle cells compared to control cells. Moreover, electrophysiological measurements demonstrated improved AChR functionality following steroid treatment. These findings suggest that steroids induce the expression of AChRs on cultured human muscle cells, which may contribute to their therapeutic efficacy in MG.

Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the steroid-induced upregulation of AChRs could pave the way for targeted therapeutic interventions and improved management of MG patients.

Trapped-lung syndrome after cardiac surgery: a potentially preventable complication of pleural injury. Trapped-lung syndrome is a rare but potentially serious complication that can occur after cardiac surgery. It is characterized by the entrapment of the lung within the pleural space, leading to impaired lung function and respiratory distress. This condition is often caused by iatrogenic pleural injury during surgery, resulting in the formation of pleural adhesions that prevent lung expansion. 

In this retrospective study, we analyzed the cases of 25 patients who developed trapped-lung syndrome following cardiac surgery between January 2000 and December 2015. The main objective was to identify risk factors and potential preventive strategies for this complication. Our findings revealed that patients who underwent surgical procedures involving prolonged cardiopulmonary bypass or thoracotomy had a significantly higher risk of developing trapped-lung syndrome. 

Moreover, we observed that the implementation of preventive measures, such as meticulous surgical technique to minimize pleural injury and the use of pleural adhesion barriers, significantly reduced the incidence of trapped-lung syndrome. Overall, our study highlights the importance of recognizing and addressing iatrogenic pleural injury to prevent the occurrence of trapped-lung syndrome following cardiac surgery.

Preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension. Preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension remains a challenge due to the complexity of the disease and limited diagnostic tools. This abstract proposes the development of a novel expert system, the Preoperative Selection Expert System for Renovascular Hypertension (PSESRH), to aid in the identification of patients who would benefit from surgical intervention. The PSESRH utilizes a combination of clinical data, radiological imaging, and laboratory findings to generate a probability score for renovascular hypertension. A retrospective study of 200 patients with suspected renovascular hypertension was conducted to evaluate the performance of the PSESRH. The expert system demonstrated a high diagnostic accuracy of 92%, with a sensitivity of 88% and a specificity of 94%. The PSESRH has the potential to enhance preoperative decision-making and improve patient outcomes in the management of renovascular hypertension.

Myeloproliferative disorders. Myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) are a group of clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by excessive production of mature myeloid cells. The different entities within MPDs include polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and primary myelofibrosis. MPDs are associated with increased risk of thrombosis, hemorrhage, and progression to acute myeloid leukemia. This article reviews the current understanding of MPDs, including their pathogenesis, clinical presentation, and diagnostic criteria. The most common genetic mutations associated with MPDs, such as JAK2, CALR, and MPL, are discussed, along with their impact on disease pathogenesis and potential therapeutic targets. The management of MPDs is also briefly discussed, including the use of cytoreductive agents, antiplatelet therapy, and supportive care measures. Finally, the article mentions the emerging role of targeted therapies in the treatment of MPDs, as well as ongoing research efforts to better understand the molecular basis of these disorders and develop novel treatment strategies.

Congenital angiotropic lymphoma (intravascular lymphomatosis) of the T-cell type. Congenital angiotropic lymphoma, also known as intravascular lymphomatosis, is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of lymphoma cells within the lumina of small blood vessels. This T-cell lymphoma primarily affects the skin, but can also involve other organs such as the central nervous system, liver, lung, and bone marrow.

The clinical presentation of congenital angiotropic lymphoma can vary widely, with symptoms depending on the organs involved. Cutaneous manifestations include a broad spectrum of lesions, ranging from erythematous patches to papules or nodules. These skin lesions may exhibit a malar flush or a butterfly rash, similar to those observed in other diseases.

Diagnosis of congenital angiotropic lymphoma is challenging due to its rarity and nonspecific clinical presentation. Histopathological examination of skin biopsies, along with immunophenotyping and molecular studies, is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Prognosis of congenital angiotropic lymphoma is generally poor, with a rapidly progressive course and high mortality rate. Early recognition and prompt initiation of aggressive chemotherapy are crucial for improving patient outcomes. Thus, a high index of suspicion is necessary to include congenital angiotropic lymphoma in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with butterfly rash or malar flush.

Lack of change in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal tetanus toxin syndrome in rats. The aim of this study was to investigate the neurochemical changes during the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal tetanus toxin (TTX) syndrome in rats. Male Sprague-Dawley rats underwent intrahippocampal injection of TTX to induce epileptic seizures. The postepileptic phase was defined as the period immediately following the termination of seizures. Neurochemical markers including glutamate, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), dopamine, serotonin, and acetylcholine were measured in the hippocampus using microdialysis and high-performance liquid chromatography. Results showed that there was no significant change in the levels of any neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase compared to baseline levels. These findings suggest that the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal TTX syndrome does not lead to immediate neurochemical alterations in the hippocampus. Further studies are needed to explore the long-term effects of TTX-induced seizures on neurochemical signaling pathways in the hippocampus.

Two urogenital sinus syndromes.  Interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. Urogenital sinus syndromes encompass a range of disorders affecting the urinary and genital tracts. Two rare syndromes within this category are interstitial cystitis (IC) and focal vulvitis. Interstitial cystitis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by bladder pain, urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. It predominantly affects females and can significantly impact quality of life. Focal vulvitis is a localized inflammation of the vulva, typically involving the labia majora and minora. It presents with symptoms such as itching, burning, and pain. Diagnosis of both syndromes requires comprehensive evaluation, including clinical examination, symptom assessment, and potentially invasive procedures such as cystoscopy and biopsies. Treatment options for IC and focal vulvitis aim to alleviate symptoms and improve patient comfort. Additional research is needed to further understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for these conditions.

Complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty: relationships with patient age.  Five hundred consecutive attempted lower limb angioplasties for ischaemic disease (370 patients, mean age 65. Complications associated with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and their relationship to patient age were evaluated in a study of 370 patients undergoing 500 lower limb angioplasties for ischaemic disease. The mean age of the patients was 65 years. Overall, complications occurred in 13% of the procedures, with the most common being intraoperative arterial rupture (5.4%), distal embolization (3.8%), and arterial dissection (2%). The incidence of complications varied with patient age, with a significantly higher rate observed in patients aged 70 years or older (18.8%) compared to those younger than 70 (10.2%). Age was found to be an independent risk factor for complications, with each year increase in age associated with a 4% increase in the odds of experiencing a complication. These findings suggest that advanced age is a significant predictor of complications in PTA procedures for lower limb ischaemic disease.

Hepatic arterial embolization in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Hepatic arterial embolization is a well-established treatment option for hepatic artery stenosis and tumors. However, there is limited data on its efficacy for extensive celiac arterial stenosis. This case series presents three patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis who underwent hepatic arterial embolization as a therapeutic approach. All patients had symptoms of abdominal pain, weight loss, and elevated liver enzymes. Angiography revealed severe stenosis of the celiac artery, leading to compromised hepatic blood supply. Hepatic arterial embolization was performed successfully in all cases, resulting in symptom relief and improvement in liver function tests. This case series highlights hepatic arterial embolization as a viable treatment option for patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its long-term efficacy and safety.

Gallbladder carcinoma producing human chorionic gonadotropin. Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare and aggressive malignancy with poor prognosis. In this case study, we report a unique presentation of gallbladder carcinoma associated with elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). A 58-year-old male presented with right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Laboratory investigations revealed markedly elevated serum hCG levels. Imaging studies demonstrated a mass in the gallbladder with regional lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent surgical resection, and histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated expression of hCG in the tumor cells. The patient received adjuvant chemotherapy but unfortunately succumbed to the disease after 6 months. This case highlights the rare occurrence of gallbladder carcinoma producing hCG and suggests its potential utility as a diagnostic and prognostic marker in this aggressive malignancy. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and determine optimal management strategies for this subset of gallbladder carcinoma patients.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. Hepatic epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (HEH) is a rare vascular tumor that often presents with infiltrative growth and multifocal distribution. Due to its rarity and variable clinical behavior, optimal management strategies for HEH have not been clearly established. Here, we present a case of a patient with HEH who presented with severe hemorrhage, not commonly seen in this tumor type. Endovascular embolization was performed to control the bleeding, followed by surgical resection of the tumor. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remains disease-free at 2 years of follow-up. This case highlights the importance of individualized management approaches for HEH, as well as the potential for atypical presentations, such as severe hemorrhage, which may require intervention to achieve hemostasis.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus is a rare condition typically associated with tumors, cysts, or other space-occupying lesions. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics, etiology, and treatment outcomes of adults with unilateral hydrocephalus. A retrospective analysis was performed on 26 patients diagnosed with unilateral hydrocephalus. The results showed that the most common presenting symptom was headache (80.8%), followed by gait disturbances (53.8%). Imaging studies revealed various etiologies, including tumors (38.5%), cysts (26.9%), and aqueductal stenosis (23.1%). Surgical intervention, in the form of ventriculoperitoneal shunting or endoscopic third ventriculostomy, was performed in all patients, resulting in clinical improvement in 92.3% of cases. In conclusion, unilateral hydrocephalus in adults has diverse etiologies, but surgical intervention can effectively alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life.

Immunoscintigraphy of ovarian cancer with indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody.  The safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy with the indium-111-labeled monoclonal antibody OV-TL 3 F(ab')2(111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer was prospectively studied in 31 patients. Immunoscintigraphy using radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies has shown promise in the diagnosis and management of various cancers. In this study, we evaluated the safety and diagnostic accuracy of indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody (111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) in 31 patients with ovarian cancer. All patients underwent immunoscintigraphy with 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 for initial diagnosis and subsequent follow-up.

The results demonstrated favorable safety profiles, with no serious adverse events reported. Diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy was assessed by comparing the results with histopathological findings and conventional imaging modalities. Immunoscintigraphy revealed high sensitivity (87%), specificity (93%), positive predictive value (91%), and negative predictive value (89%) for the detection of ovarian cancer.

These findings support the use of 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 as a safe and accurate diagnostic tool in patients with ovarian cancer. Further studies are warranted to investigate its potential role in treatment response monitoring and prognosis assessment.

Hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis.  Several new concepts are reviewed concerning structural and functional changes in atherosclerotic and hypertensive blood vessels. This review discusses the hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis. Both conditions are characterized by structural and functional alterations in blood vessels. In hypertension, elevated blood pressure leads to endothelial dysfunction, vascular remodeling, and increased arterial stiffness. These changes contribute to the development of atherosclerosis, which is characterized by the accumulation of lipids and inflammatory cells in the arterial wall. The review highlights several new concepts regarding these vascular changes, including the role of oxidative stress, inflammation, and endothelial dysfunction in the pathogenesis of hypertension and atherosclerosis. Understanding the underlying mechanisms of these vascular changes is crucial for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of these cardiovascular diseases.

Absent or minimal cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities in Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae meningitis is a serious bacterial infection associated with significant morbidity and mortality, particularly in children. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is essential for the diagnosis and management of this condition. However, there have been reports of cases with absent or minimal CSF abnormalities in H. influenzae meningitis, leading to diagnostic challenges and potential delays in treatment initiation. 

In this study, we present a retrospective analysis of 35 patients diagnosed with H. influenzae meningitis, focusing on their CSF findings. Surprisingly, 9 out of the 35 patients (25.7%) exhibited either absent or minimal CSF abnormalities, including normal cell counts and protein levels. These patients presented with typical clinical manifestations of meningitis, such as fever, headache, and altered mental status, further emphasizing the importance of clinical suspicion in such cases.

We also compared the clinical characteristics and outcomes of patients with absent or minimal CSF abnormalities to those with typical CSF findings. There were no significant differences in age, gender, or underlying comorbidities between the two groups. However, patients with absent or minimal CSF abnormalities tended to have a shorter duration of hospitalization and a lower mortality rate.

In conclusion, our findings suggest that absent or minimal CSF abnormalities can occur in a subset of patients with H. influenzae meningitis. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for this diagnosis even in the absence of classic CSF findings, ensuring prompt treatment initiation and improved patient outcomes. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms responsible for these atypical presentations and to develop more sensitive diagnostic tools for H. influenzae meningitis.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ischemic heart disease is a common cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and ventricular arrhythmias are a significant complication of this condition. Ventricular arrhythmias can occur as a result of myocardial ischemia, infarction, or reperfusion injury, and can range from premature ventricular contractions to life-threatening ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

The underlying pathophysiology of ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease involves alterations in myocardial electrophysiology, including prolonged action potential duration, increased dispersion of repolarization, and impaired conduction. Ischemia-induced myocardial damage further exacerbates these electrophysiological changes and creates a substrate for the development of ventricular arrhythmias.

The management of ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease involves a multi-faceted approach, including revascularization strategies, pharmacological therapy, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement. Antiarrhythmic drugs such as beta-blockers, amiodarone, or sotalol may be used for rhythm control, while implantable cardioverter-defibrillators are essential for preventing sudden cardiac death in high-risk patients.

In conclusion, ventricular arrhythmias are a significant complication of ischemic heart disease and can lead to adverse clinical outcomes. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and implementing appropriate management strategies is crucial for improving patient outcomes in this population.

Internal fixation of femoral neck fractures.  Two methods compared. This study aims to compare the outcomes of internal fixation using two different methods for femoral neck fractures. A total of 100 patients with femoral neck fractures were included in the study, with 50 patients undergoing fixation with method A and 50 patients with method B. The patients were followed up for a period of 12 months. The primary outcome measures were union rates, time to union, and functional outcomes using the Harris Hip Score. The secondary outcome measures included complications and need for revision surgery. 

The results showed that method A had a significantly higher union rate compared to method B (92% vs. 80%, p<0.05). The time to union was also shorter in method A compared to method B (average 4.2 months vs. 5.8 months, p<0.05). However, there was no significant difference in the functional outcomes between the two methods. Complication rates were similar in both groups, but the need for revision surgery was slightly higher in method B (12% vs. 8%).

In conclusion, internal fixation using method A for femoral neck fractures resulted in higher union rates and shorter time to union compared to method B. Both methods had similar functional outcomes and complication rates, but method B had a slightly higher rate of revision surgery. These findings suggest that method A may be preferred for the treatment of femoral neck fractures. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are needed to confirm these results.

Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia.  OBJECTIVE: To determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (QRS duration less than or equal to 0. 11 seconds). Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (VT) refers to ventricular tachycardia with a QRS duration of less than or equal to 0.11 seconds.
