The objective of this study was to determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of this type of VT. A retrospective analysis was performed on patients who presented with sustained monomorphic VT at a tertiary medical center. Of the 500 patients included in the study, 40% had narrow QRS VT. The mean age of patients with narrow QRS VT was significantly younger compared to those with wide QRS VT (47 vs. 64 years, p<0.001). There was a higher prevalence of structural heart disease in the wide QRS VT group compared to the narrow QRS VT group (72% vs. 16%, p<0.001). Furthermore, patients with narrow QRS VT had a lower incidence of syncope and cardiac arrest compared to those with wide QRS VT. In conclusion, this study highlights the frequency and specific clinical characteristics associated with narrow QRS VT, suggesting important implications for its diagnosis and management.

Incidence of hairy cell leukemia, mycosis fungoides, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia in first known HTLV-II-endemic population.  Unlike human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I), HTLV-II has not been convincingly linked to a malignancy. This study investigated the incidence of hairy cell leukemia (HCL), mycosis fungoides (MF), and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) in the first known population endemic for human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type II (HTLV-II). A total of 172 individuals infected with HTLV-II were followed for a median period of 4.7 years. Among them, three cases of HCL, two cases of MF, and four cases of CLL were identified. The incidence rates per 1000 person-years were 6.4 for HCL, 4.3 for MF, and 8.6 for CLL. Compared to the general population, the incidence rate ratios were significantly elevated for all three diseases. However, when compared to HTLV-I-endemic populations, the incidence rates of HCL, MF, and CLL were lower in the HTLV-II-endemic population. These findings suggest that while HTLV-II may not be convincingly linked to a specific malignancy, it may still contribute to an increased risk of certain hematologic malignancies. Further research is warranted to explore the association between HTLV-II infection and these diseases.

Postictal psychosis after partial complex seizures: a multiple case study. Postictal psychosis (PIP) is a rare but clinically significant complication of epilepsy. This study aimed to investigate the clinical and electroencephalographic (EEG) characteristics, as well as the treatment outcomes, of patients with PIP after partial complex seizures (PCS). A multiple case study design was employed, including ten patients with PIP after PCS. Detailed clinical history, psychiatric evaluation, and neuroimaging findings were collected for each patient. EEG recordings during the ictal, postictal, and interictal periods were also analyzed. The mean age of the patients was 38.9 years, with a male predominance. The average duration of PIP was 11.5 days, with hallucinations being the most common psychotic symptom. EEG findings demonstrated focal epileptiform discharges during the postictal period in all patients. Treatment with antipsychotic medications resulted in complete remission of psychotic symptoms in nine patients, with one patient requiring additional treatment with antiepileptic drugs. This study highlights the clinical and EEG characteristics of PIP after PCS and emphasizes the importance of prompt recognition and appropriate treatment to improve patient outcomes. Future research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize therapeutic strategies for PIP.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. Expandable biliary metal stents have become an integral part of the management of malignant biliary obstruction. Endoscopic insertion of these stents is a minimally invasive procedure that has shown excellent results in terms of relief of jaundice and improvement in quality of life. However, one of the major challenges with the long-term use of these stents is tumor ingrowth, which can lead to stent occlusion and recurrent biliary obstruction. Several techniques have been proposed to address this issue, including diathermic cleaning, which involves the use of diathermy to burn off the ingrowing tumor tissue.

This abstract aims to review the current evidence regarding the use of expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies, focusing on the technique of endoscopic insertion and the management of tumor ingrowth. It will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of this approach, as well as the potential complications associated with diathermic cleaning. Additionally, it will highlight the importance of regular surveillance and follow-up to detect and manage tumor ingrowth in a timely manner. Overall, expandable biliary metal stents offer a promising option for the palliation of malignant biliary obstruction, but appropriate strategies for dealing with tumor ingrowth are crucial for long-term success.

Age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years.  European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. This study aimed to evaluate the age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years. The European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial involving a total of 500 participants. The participants were divided into two groups: one receiving placebo and the other receiving active treatment for a period of 12 weeks. Blood pressure measurements were taken at baseline and at regular intervals throughout the study period. Results showed that both placebo and active treatment led to a significant reduction in blood pressure in older patients. However, the hypotensive effect was more pronounced in the active treatment group compared to the placebo group. This study highlights the importance of considering age-related factors when treating hypertension in older individuals.

Improved silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions in paraffin wax sections using an inverted incubation technique [published erratum appears in J Clin Pathol 1991 Jun;44(6):528] A new simple modification to the silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was devised which, by performing the incubation with the slide inverted, results in minimal undesirable background staining, a persistent problem. The authors present a modification to the silver staining technique of nucleolar organizer regions (AgNORs) in paraffin wax sections. By inverting the slide during incubation, they were able to minimize unwanted background staining, a common issue with the traditional method. This modification provides a simple and effective approach to improve the visualization of AgNORs, aiding in their use as a diagnostic tool in various pathological conditions.

Endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients. Endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy are commonly performed procedures in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis. However, little is known about the outcomes and safety of these procedures in immunodeficient patients. This study evaluated the efficacy and complications of endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in a cohort of 25 immunodeficient patients with chronic rhinosinusitis. The surgical procedures were successfully performed in all patients without any intraoperative complications. Postoperative outcomes were assessed at 6 months, and significant improvements were observed in nasal symptoms and quality of life. Three patients experienced minor postoperative complications, including nasal bleeding and temporary loss of smell, which resolved with conservative management. These findings suggest that endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy can be safely performed in immunodeficient patients with chronic rhinosinusitis, with favorable postoperative outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings in larger cohorts.

Hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans. Hypertensive heart disease (HHD) is a significant health issue in African-Americans, characterized by structural and functional abnormalities of the heart due to longstanding high blood pressure. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and risk factors associated with HHD in this population. A retrospective analysis of medical records from a multiethnic urban community revealed a higher prevalence of HHD among African-Americans compared to other ethnic groups. Risk factors such as obesity, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease were found to be significantly associated with HHD in this population. Additionally, inadequate blood pressure control was a common issue among African-Americans with HHD. These findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions and culturally sensitive approaches to effectively manage HHD and improve cardiovascular outcomes in this high-risk population.

Cerebrospinal fluid endothelin-1 and endothelin-3 levels in normal and neurosurgical patients: a clinical study and literature review. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels of endothelin-1 (ET-1) and endothelin-3 (ET-3) have been suggested to play a role in various neurological conditions. However, limited data is available regarding the normal reference levels of these peptides in CSF and their potential alterations in neurosurgical patients. In this study, CSF samples were collected from 50 neurosurgical patients and 50 healthy controls. By using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, CSF levels of ET-1 and ET-3 were measured and compared between the two groups. Additionally, a literature review was conducted to summarize previous findings on CSF ET-1 and ET-3 levels in neurological disorders. The results from this study, along with the literature review, provide valuable insights into the potential diagnostic and prognostic significance of CSF ET-1 and ET-3 levels in neurosurgical patients.

Different tumor-derived p53 mutants exhibit distinct biological activities. The p53 protein is a crucial tumor suppressor that plays a pivotal role in maintaining genomic stability. However, mutations in the p53 gene are commonly observed in various cancers, resulting in the expression of mutant p53 proteins with altered functions. In this study, we assessed the biological activities of different tumor-derived p53 mutants. We found that each p53 mutant exhibited distinct activities, including differential effects on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and DNA damage response. Furthermore, we observed that certain p53 mutants conferred resistance to chemotherapeutic drugs, suggesting their potential involvement in drug resistance mechanisms. Additionally, we identified specific p53 mutants that displayed enhanced transcriptional activity, promoting the expression of oncogenic target genes. Our findings contribute to a better understanding of the functional diversity of p53 mutants in cancer progression and highlight the importance of developing personalized therapeutic strategies targeting specific p53 mutations.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. In this study, the performance of large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery was assessed. A total of 30 patients with infrarenal aortic aneurysms were included in the study and underwent replacement surgery using ePTFE grafts. Postoperatively, patients were monitored for graft patency and complications such as infection, thrombosis, and graft migration. Follow-up imaging with computed tomography angiography was performed to evaluate the long-term performance of the grafts. The results showed excellent graft patency in all patients, with no cases of graft infection or migration. However, two cases of thrombosis were observed, which were successfully managed with anticoagulation therapy. Overall, ePTFE grafts proved to be a reliable and effective option for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery, providing excellent graft patency and minimal complications.

The electrodiagnostic findings in polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. The aim of this study was to investigate the electrodiagnostic findings in polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. We conducted a retrospective analysis of individuals with IgM monoclonal gammopathy who underwent electrodiagnostic studies for evaluation of sensory or motor symptoms. A total of 36 patients were included in the study. The majority of patients (75%) presented with sensory symptoms, while 25% had motor symptoms. Electrodiagnostic studies revealed evidence of demyelination in 69% of patients, with mixed axonal and demyelinating features in 19% and isolated axonal features in 11%. The most common pattern observed was a distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy. Our findings indicate that polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies frequently exhibit demyelinating features on electrodiagnostic studies, highlighting the importance of considering this diagnosis in patients with sensory or motor symptoms and an IgM monoclonal gammopathy.

Treatment of chronic facial palsy by transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle. Chronic facial palsy can greatly affect the quality of life for patients, leading to functional and aesthetic impairments. In this study, we evaluate the efficacy of transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle as a treatment for chronic facial palsy. Fifteen patients with unilateral facial palsy underwent this surgical procedure and were assessed preoperatively and postoperatively at regular intervals for a mean follow-up period of 2.5 years. Functional outcomes were evaluated using the House-Brackmann grading system, while aesthetic outcomes were assessed using subjective patient satisfaction surveys. Our results demonstrated significant improvement in both functional and aesthetic outcomes postoperatively. The mean House-Brackmann grade improved from 3.8 preoperatively to 2.1 at the final follow-up visit. Patient satisfaction surveys showed an overall high level of satisfaction with the facial symmetry achieved. 
Overall, transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle appears to be a promising treatment option for chronic facial palsy, providing functional and aesthetic improvements for patients. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings and optimize surgical techniques.

Association of immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes with specific antinuclear antibodies and disease susceptibility among connective tissue disease patients. In this study, the association between immunoglobulin (Ig) Km and Gm allotypes and specific antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in connective tissue disease (CTD) patients was investigated. A total of 150 CTD patients were enrolled, including rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and Sjgren's syndrome. Serum samples were collected and analyzed for the presence of ANAs, including anti-SSA, anti-SSB, anti-RNP, anti-Sm, and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. The Ig Km and Gm allotypes were determined using serological techniques. Statistical analysis revealed significant associations between specific ANAs and Ig Km and Gm allotypes in CTD patients. Moreover, certain Ig Km and Gm allotypes were found to be associated with increased disease susceptibility in different CTD subtypes. These findings suggest a possible role of Ig Km and Gm allotypes in the development and pathogenesis of CTDs, highlighting their potential as biomarkers for disease susceptibility and monitoring. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore their clinical implications.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collaterals are alternative blood vessels that develop in response to obstruction or narrowing of a coronary artery. These collaterals serve as bypass routes to ensure adequate blood supply to the myocardium. Several studies in both animal models and humans have confirmed the existence and functional importance of coronary collaterals.

The functional significance of coronary collateral recruitment lies in its ability to mitigate the effects of vessel closure. When a coronary artery becomes occluded, the pre-existing collaterals can provide an alternative route for blood flow, thus preventing myocardial ischemia. The rate of vessel closure, which refers to the speed at which the artery becomes completely obstructed, has been found to influence the development and recruitment of coronary collaterals.

Understanding the factors that influence coronary collateral recruitment can have implications for the management of coronary artery disease. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms behind collateral growth and to determine strategies to enhance collateral circulation in patients with obstructive coronary artery disease.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. Emergency center ultrasonography (ECUS) was investigated for its effectiveness in detecting hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma in a prospective study. 72 patients were included in the study, and the detection of hemoperitoneum using ultrasonography was compared to findings from subsequent diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) or surgery. ECUS demonstrated a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 96% for detecting hemoperitoneum. The positive predictive value was 96% and the negative predictive value was 94%. The study concluded that ECUS is a reliable and accurate method for detecting hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma, and can therefore be a valuable tool in the initial evaluation of these patients in the emergency center.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. We report on a case of a male patient presenting with a rare genetic disorder characterized by ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. The patient presented with thick, dry, and scaly skin consistent with ichthyosis, along with global developmental delay and intellectual disability indicative of mental retardation. Additionally, the patient exhibited spasticity in the absence of any clinical symptoms, leading to a diagnosis of asymptomatic spasticity. Extensive genetic testing was performed, and a mutation in a known gene associated with this disorder was identified, confirming the diagnosis. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the clinical manifestations of this rare genetic disorder, as it aids in accurate diagnosis and subsequent management. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms of this disorder and develop targeted therapeutic interventions.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. Spontaneous pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the accumulation of air in the pleural cavity, leading to lung collapse. Traditional treatment involves thoracostomy tube insertion or thoracotomy, but these procedures are invasive and associated with postoperative pain and longer hospital stays. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of thoracoscopic treatment using a carbon dioxide laser.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 35 patients with spontaneous pneumothorax who underwent thoracoscopic treatment with a carbon dioxide laser. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery was performed using a single incision technique. The carbon dioxide laser was used to create adhesions between the parietal and visceral pleura, promoting lung re-expansion and preventing recurrent pneumothorax.

The results showed a success rate of 97.1%, with only one patient experiencing recurrence of pneumothorax. The mean operative duration was 42 minutes, and the mean postoperative hospital stay was 2.6 days. Complications were minimal, with no cases of infection or significant bleeding.

In conclusion, thoracoscopic treatment using a carbon dioxide laser is a safe and effective alternative for the management of spontaneous pneumothorax. It offers shorter hospital stays, reduced postoperative pain, and low complication rates. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up are needed to confirm these findings.

Incidence of gallstones in a Danish population.  Five-year incidence of gallstone disease was assessed by ultrasonography in an age- and sex-stratified random population of Danish origin aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years.  The response rate was 82. 8% (2987/3608). The five-year incidence of gallstone disease was evaluated in a Danish population through ultrasonography. A total of 2987 individuals from the original sample of 3608 responded, resulting in a response rate of 82.8%. The study population was age- and sex-stratified, including individuals aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years. Ultrasonography was used to identify the presence of gallstones, and the incidence rate was determined based on the number of new cases detected. The results of this study provide valuable information on the prevalence and progression of gallstone disease in the Danish population, allowing for a better understanding of the epidemiology and potential risk factors associated with this condition.

Computerized neuropsychological assessment of cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy. The present study aimed to evaluate the utility of computerized neuropsychological assessment in measuring cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy. A total of 50 children with epilepsy and 50 matched healthy controls underwent a computerized neuropsychological battery consisting of tests assessing various cognitive domains, including attention, memory, executive functioning, and processing speed. Results demonstrated that children with epilepsy exhibited significantly poorer performance across all cognitive domains compared to healthy controls. Specifically, deficits were observed in attentional processes, working memory, inhibitory control, and cognitive flexibility. Furthermore, the severity and type of epilepsy were found to be associated with the extent of cognitive impairment. The findings suggest that computerized neuropsychological assessment is a valuable tool for identifying specific cognitive deficits in children with epilepsy and may contribute to the development of targeted interventions to optimize cognitive functioning in this population.

Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus. Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus is a rare malignancy that arises from the bile ducts. It is often associated with chronic inflammation or bile duct stones. This study presents a retrospective analysis of 20 patients with carcinoma of the ductus choledochus who underwent surgical resection. The mean age of the patients was 65 years, with a male predominance. The most common presenting symptom was jaundice, followed by abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, were useful in preoperative diagnosis. Surgical resection, including radical resection or palliative bypass, was performed based on tumor stage and patient's general condition. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 40%. Adjuvant chemotherapy was administered in selected cases. In conclusion, carcinoma of the ductus choledochus poses a diagnostic challenge and requires a multimodal approach for effective management.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. Myotonic heart disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired relaxation and contraction of the cardiac muscle. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes and prognosis of patients with myotonic heart disease over a follow-up period of 5 years. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with myotonic heart disease were included in the study. Clinical data, including echocardiographic parameters, symptoms, and medication usage, were collected at baseline and during follow-up visits. The results showed that patients with myotonic heart disease had a high prevalence of atrial fibrillation (40%) and heart failure (30%). The mortality rate during the follow-up period was found to be 10%. This study highlights the need for long-term follow-up and management strategies for patients with myotonic heart disease to improve their outcomes and quality of life.

Clinical significance of white cell antibodies in febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions. Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR) are a common complication of blood transfusions. The etiology of FNHTR is not fully understood, but immune-mediated mechanisms have been proposed. This study aimed to investigate the clinical significance of white cell antibodies (WCA) in FNHTR. 

A total of 80 patients who experienced FNHTR were included in the study. WCA were detected using the indirect antiglobulin test. The presence or absence of WCA was correlated with clinical features of FNHTR, including fever duration, severity of symptoms, and need for additional treatments. 

Results showed that 45% of patients had detectable WCA. These patients had significantly longer fever duration and more severe symptoms compared to those without WCA. Additionally, patients with WCA were more likely to require additional treatments such as antipyretics and intravenous fluids. 

In conclusion, the presence of WCA is associated with more severe clinical manifestations in patients with FNHTR. Identifying WCA may help predict the severity of FNHTR and guide appropriate management strategies. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore targeted interventions for these patients.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Cystic brain tumors are among the most challenging lesions to diagnose and treat, with limited understanding of their underlying pathophysiology. This study aimed to investigate the presence and significance of local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed on 30 specimens obtained from patients with cystic brain tumors, including pilocytic astrocytoma, craniopharyngioma, and epidermoid cyst. The results revealed evidence of local immune activation, including increased expression of immune cell markers and activation markers. Furthermore, the presence of immune cells was found to be associated with certain tumor characteristics, such as cyst size and wall thickness. These findings suggest that local immune activation plays a role in the development and progression of cystic brain tumors and may have implications for the development of targeted immunotherapeutic approaches.

Vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids and the risk of cancer. This meta-analysis aimed to assess the association between vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid intake and the risk of cancer. A total of 20 cohort studies and 15 case-control studies were included in the analysis. The results showed that higher intake of vegetables was significantly associated with a reduced risk of overall cancer (Relative Risk [RR] = 0.83, 95% Confidence Interval [CI] 0.76-0.90). Similarly, higher fruit intake was also associated with a decreased risk of overall cancer (RR = 0.91, 95% CI 0.85-0.97). When stratified by cancer type, higher vegetable and fruit intake was consistently associated with a reduced risk of lung, colorectal, and stomach cancers. Subgroup analysis further revealed that higher carotenoid intake was significantly associated with a lower risk of lung, breast, and gastric cancers. These findings suggest that a higher intake of vegetables and fruits, as well as carotenoids, may play a protective role against the development of various cancers. Public health strategies should focus on promoting the consumption of a diverse range of vegetables and fruits to reduce cancer risk.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. We conducted a study to evaluate the outcomes of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation (TCP) in the treatment of glaucoma. A total of 40 eyes from 40 patients were included in the study. The aim was to compare the effectiveness of two different treatment durations, specifically 1.5 or 3 seconds, in achieving intraocular pressure (IOP) control.

The results showed that both treatment durations significantly reduced IOP, with a mean decrease of 30% at the 6-month follow-up. However, there was no significant difference in IOP reduction between the two treatment groups. Additionally, there were no major complications related to the procedure.

In conclusion, noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation is an effective and safe treatment option for glaucoma. Our study suggests that both 1.5 and 3-second treatment durations can achieve comparable IOP reduction. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings and determine the long-term efficacy of TCP in glaucoma management.

Evaluation of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe epilepsy.  The effects of the addition of Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, to the therapy of 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy is reported. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy to evaluate the efficacy of adding vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug (AED), to their treatment regimen. The patients were followed for a period of 12 months to assess the impact of vigabatrin on seizure frequency and severity. The results showed that the addition of vigabatrin resulted in a significant reduction in seizure frequency, with 72% of patients experiencing a decrease of at least 50%. Furthermore, 47% of patients achieved seizure freedom during the study period. The drug was generally well-tolerated, with only a few cases of mild adverse events reported. These findings suggest that vigabatrin may serve as an effective add-on therapy for patients with severe epilepsy who are resistant to other AEDs. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. The objective of this study was to investigate the role of environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease (PD). A total of 328 patients with PD and their 328 unaffected siblings were enrolled in this case-control study. Detailed information on environmental exposures such as pesticide use, smoking, and coffee consumption was collected through structured interviews. Logistic regression analysis was performed to assess the association between these environmental risk factors and PD in siblings. The results showed that pesticide exposure was significantly associated with PD in siblings, with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.35 (p<0.05). Smoking and coffee consumption did not show any significant association with PD in siblings. Subgroup analysis based on gender and age at onset did not yield any significant associations either. In conclusion, our findings suggest that pesticide exposure may play a role in the development of PD in siblings, highlighting the importance of avoiding such exposures in individuals with a familial risk of PD.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. We report a case of a periurethral polyp that presented as a urethral caruncle in a 38-year-old female. The patient presented with a painful mass at the urethral meatus that had been present for several months. A clinical examination revealed a fleshy, pedunculated lesion resembling a urethral caruncle. However, histopathological evaluation following surgical excision revealed a colonic-type polyp. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of such a case in the literature. This case highlights the importance of considering a wide range of differential diagnoses for periurethral lesions and underscores the need for histopathological evaluation to ensure accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

Oxidation reactions in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is characterized by the progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra region of the brain, leading to motor and non-motor symptoms. Oxidative stress has been implicated in the pathogenesis of PD, with increased levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and impaired cellular antioxidant defenses observed in affected brain regions. This review explores the role of oxidation reactions in PD, focusing on the involvement of mitochondrial dysfunction, protein misfolding and aggregation, and inflammation. Mitochondria are a major source of ROS production in cells and their dysfunction leads to increased oxidative stress and neuronal damage. Protein misfolding and aggregation, particularly of alpha-synuclein, contribute to the formation of Lewy bodies, a pathological hallmark of PD. Inflammation, characterized by the activation of microglia and release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, further exacerbates oxidative stress and neurodegeneration. Understanding the complex interplay between oxidation reactions and PD pathology may provide insights into novel therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative stress in PD.

Cosmetic, functional, independent: self-help aids. This study aimed to investigate the impact of cosmetic, functional, and independent self-help aids on the quality of life (QoL) of individuals with physical disabilities. A total of 100 participants with diverse disabilities were enrolled in a randomized controlled trial. They were grouped into three categories based on the type of self-help aids they received: cosmetic aids (such as wigs or prosthetics), functional aids (such as braces or walking aids), and independent aids (such as adaptive utensils or assistive devices). The participants' QoL was assessed using standardized questionnaires at baseline and after 12 weeks of using the self-help aids. Results showed significant improvements in QoL across all three groups, highlighting the importance of these aids in enhancing the well-being and independence of individuals with physical disabilities. The implications of these findings for healthcare professionals and policymakers are discussed.

Surgical and prosthesis-related complications using the Groningen button voice prosthesis.  Prosthesis-assisted tracheoesophageal speech has advanced speech rehabilitation appreciably. The use of the Groningen button voice prosthesis has greatly improved speech rehabilitation in patients who have undergone laryngectomy. This study aimed to assess surgical and prosthesis-related complications associated with the use of the Groningen button voice prosthesis. A total of 52 patients who underwent laryngectomy and received the Groningen button voice prosthesis were included in the study. An analysis of complications revealed a total of 17 surgical complications, including 9 granulation tissue formations and 8 peri-prosthetic infections. Prosthesis-related complications were also observed, with 6 replacements performed due to leakage or dislodgement. Despite these complications, the overall success rate of the Groningen button voice prosthesis was 75%, with 39 out of 52 patients achieving satisfactory speech. In conclusion, the Groningen button voice prosthesis is an effective method for tracheoesophageal speech rehabilitation, although it is associated with surgical and prosthesis-related complications that should be managed and monitored closely.

The osteogenetic potential of fracture haematoma. Fracture healing is a complex process involving the formation of a fracture haematoma, which provides a rich source of growth factors and cytokines. This study aimed to investigate the potential of the fracture haematoma to promote osteogenesis. A rabbit model of femoral fracture was used, and histological analysis revealed the presence of osteoblasts and osteoid matrix within the fracture haematoma at different time points post-fracture. Furthermore, immunohistochemistry demonstrated the expression of osteogenic markers such as Runx2 and osteocalcin. These findings suggest that the fracture haematoma has osteogenic potential and may contribute to the initiation of bone regeneration. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic applications.

Anisocoria in unilateral ophthalmic disease.  Pupillary diameters in the affected and unaffected eyes of 327 patients with uniocular red eye were assessed during fixation of a distant target. Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, can be a result of various underlying ophthalmic conditions. In this study, the pupillary diameters of 327 patients with uniocular red eye were examined while fixating on a distant target. The aim was to determine if anisocoria could be used as a diagnostic tool for unilateral ophthalmic disease. The results revealed a significant difference in pupil sizes between the affected and unaffected eyes in these patients. Therefore, anisocoria can be utilized to aid in the identification and diagnosis of unilateral eye diseases. Further research is needed to establish the specific conditions associated with anisocoria and its potential as a diagnostic indicator.

Outpatient management of schizophrenia. Outpatient management of schizophrenia has become an essential aspect of psychiatric care. This article provides an overview of the current best practices in the outpatient management of schizophrenia, including medication management, psychosocial interventions, and monitoring for adverse effects. The importance of a comprehensive and individualized treatment approach is emphasized, taking into account the unique needs and preferences of each patient. The role of the psychiatrist in coordinating care with other healthcare providers and involving family members and support networks is discussed. The challenges of long-term adherence to medication and strategies to promote treatment adherence are also reviewed. Overall, this article aims to enhance the understanding of outpatient management of schizophrenia and improve clinical outcomes for individuals living with this chronic mental illness.

Local failure and related complications after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. Local failure and related complications after treatment for carcinoma of the prostate remain a significant concern. This study aimed to compare rates of local failure and complications following definitive treatment with irradiation or surgery. Data from 500 patients with carcinoma of the prostate were analyzed retrospectively. Local failure rates were higher in the irradiation group (n=250) compared to the surgery group (n=250), with 25% and 12%, respectively. Complications such as urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and rectal bleeding were more prevalent in the surgery group. However, rates of rectal and bladder complications were higher in the irradiation group. These findings emphasize the importance of considering treatment options and weighing the potential benefits and risks for each patient. Further research is needed to enhance treatment techniques and minimize complications.

A comparative study of terbinafine versus griseofulvin in 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. This study aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of terbinafine and griseofulvin in treating 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. A total of 80 patients with clinically diagnosed cases of 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections were randomly assigned to receive either terbinafine (n=40) or griseofulvin (n=40). Treatment duration was four weeks for both groups. The primary outcome measure was complete cure rate at four weeks post-treatment. Secondary outcome measures included clinical improvement rate, mycological cure rate, and adverse events. At four weeks post-treatment, the complete cure rate was significantly higher in the terbinafine group (85%) compared to the griseofulvin group (62.5%; p<0.05). The terbinafine group also demonstrated higher clinical improvement rate (97.5% vs. 82.5%) and mycological cure rate (92.5% vs. 72.5%) compared to the griseofulvin group. Adverse events were minimal and comparable between the two groups. In conclusion, terbinafine was found to be more effective and safe than griseofulvin in treating 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage after meniscectomy: preliminary experimental study in dogs. This preliminary experimental study aimed to investigate the development of degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage following meniscectomy in dogs. Ten adult Labrador Retrievers were used in the study, with five dogs undergoing complete meniscectomy and the other five serving as controls. The dogs were evaluated at six, twelve, and eighteen months after surgery using histological and radiological assessments. The results showed that the dogs undergoing meniscectomy exhibited significantly higher degenerative changes in the articular cartilage compared to the control group. Moreover, the lesions progressed over time, with more severe degenerative changes observed at eighteen months post-surgery. These findings suggest that meniscectomy may lead to progressive degeneration of the articular cartilage, highlighting the importance of considering alternative treatment options to preserve joint health.

The use of bromodeoxyuridine cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator of cancer of the head and neck. This abstract explores the utility of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator for cancer of the head and neck. The authors discuss the rationale behind using BrdU studies, which involves measuring the incorporation of BrdU into cellular DNA during the S phase of the cell cycle. They also highlight the potential benefits of BrdU studies, such as its ability to provide information on tumor proliferation rate and its correlation with patient outcomes. Additionally, the abstract emphasizes the need for further research to define the optimal methodology for BrdU studies, including standardized protocols and interpretation criteria. Overall, this abstract supports the use of BrdU cytokinetic studies as a valuable tool in predicting outcomes in head and neck cancer patients.

Benign parotid tumors: a 24-year experience.  The medical records of 125 patients benign parotid neoplasms surgically treated over a 24-year period were retrospectively reviewed; 128 tumors were excised. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the medical records of 125 patients who underwent surgical treatment for benign parotid neoplasms over a span of 24 years. A total of 128 tumors were excised from these patients. We aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of these tumors. Our findings revealed that the majority of the patients were females (67.2%) with a mean age of 46.5 years. The most common histopathological diagnosis was pleomorphic adenoma (81.3%), followed by Warthin tumor (8.6%). The surgical approach involved partial parotidectomy in 85.2% of cases and total parotidectomy in 14.8% of cases. Complications occurred in only 4.7% of patients, with transient facial nerve paresis being the most common. Recurrence of the tumor was observed in 5.5% of cases. Our study provides valuable insights into the management and outcomes of benign parotid tumors over a long-term period.

Serum lipids and lipoproteins are less powerful predictors of extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis than are cigarette smoking and hypertension The effect of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) was studied in patients who underwent carotid arteriography. This study aimed to investigate the correlation between serum lipids and lipoproteins with extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) and compare the predictive power of these factors with cigarette smoking and hypertension. Serum lipid and lipoprotein levels were measured in a group of patients who underwent carotid arteriography. Atherosclerotic plaque burden in the extracranial carotid arteries was assessed using ultrasound imaging. Statistical analysis revealed that serum lipids and lipoproteins were not strong predictors of CAS. In contrast, cigarette smoking and hypertension showed a stronger association with the presence and severity of CAS. These findings suggest that the impact of serum lipids and lipoproteins on CAS may be less significant compared to modifiable risk factors such as cigarette smoking and hypertension. Further research is needed to explore other potential contributors to CAS development.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Cystic brain tumors are known to exhibit immune responses, but the specific mechanisms are not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed on tissue samples from 20 patients with cystic brain tumors. The results showed increased infiltration of immune cells, including T cells, B cells, and macrophages, in the cystic areas of the tumors compared to the solid areas. Additionally, the expression of immune cell activation markers, such as CD69 and HLA-DR, was found to be upregulated in the cystic areas. These findings suggest that cystic brain tumors exhibit local immune activation, which may play a role in tumor development and progression. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of this immune response in cystic brain tumors.

Selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy.  There are several areas of concern in dealing with clinical stage B disease. The selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy is a critical decision that requires careful consideration. Clinical stage B disease presents several challenges, including the potential for extracapsular extension and lymph node involvement. This study aimed to identify key factors that help in the accurate selection of patients who would benefit from radical prostatectomy.

A retrospective analysis of 150 patients with clinical stage B prostate cancer was performed. Preoperative assessments, including digital rectal examination, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, and transrectal ultrasound, were used to determine the likelihood of extracapsular extension and lymph node involvement. Additionally, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to assess tumor volume and identification of high-risk features.

The results revealed that patients with PSA levels greater than 10 ng/mL, biopsy Gleason score of 7 or higher, and MRI evidence of extracapsular extension were at a higher risk for extraprostatic disease. Furthermore, patients with detectable lymphadenopathy on MRI were more likely to have lymph node involvement. These factors were incorporated into a predictive model that showed good accuracy in identifying patients who would benefit from radical prostatectomy.

In conclusion, the careful selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy is essential. PSA levels, biopsy Gleason score, MRI findings of extracapsular extension, and lymphadenopathy are valuable predictors of extraprostatic disease. The use of a predictive model incorporating these factors can aid in the accurate selection of patients who would most benefit from surgical intervention. Further prospective studies are necessary to validate these findings and improve patient outcomes.

A new syndrome: hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone in two brothers.  Two male siblings presented in infancy with hyponatremia. We present a case report of two male siblings who presented in infancy with hyponatremia and were subsequently diagnosed with a unique syndrome characterized by hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone. Both patients exhibited delayed language development, persistent hyponatremia, and normal serum aldosterone levels. Audiological evaluation revealed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss in both siblings. Whole-exome sequencing identified a novel missense variant in the aldosterone receptor gene that was found to be inherited from their parents. This variant was predicted to result in altered receptor function, leading to aldosterone insensitivity in the salivary glands. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of this syndrome, suggesting a potential role for aldosterone in the regulation of hearing and salivary gland function. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for this rare syndrome.

Biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without biliary obstruction. Biliary pain is a common complication following cholecystectomy, and its etiology remains unclear in some cases. This study aims to explore the causes of biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without identifiable biliary obstruction. A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted for patients who underwent cholecystectomy at a tertiary care hospital. Among the included patients, 15% reported recurrent biliary pain despite the absence of biliary obstruction on imaging studies. Possible causes of biliary pain were further investigated, including sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, residual or recurrent stones, and functional gastrointestinal disorders. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and manometry were performed in a subset of patients, revealing sphincter of Oddi dysfunction as the most common cause of biliary pain (60%). Other potential causes included functional gastrointestinal disorders (20%) and recurrent stones (10%). These findings highlight the importance of considering sphincter of Oddi dysfunction in the differential diagnosis of biliary pain after cholecystectomy, even in the absence of biliary obstruction.

Neonatal diarrhea at a maternity hospital in Rangoon Between 1981 and 1986, 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit because of diarrhea (15. During the 6-year period from 1981 to 1986, a total of 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were admitted to the Sick Baby Unit due to diarrhea. The most common age of onset was within the first week of life, with a peak occurrence at 2-3 days. The majority of cases were classified as acute watery diarrhea, with a smaller proportion being bloody diarrhea. The mortality rate among these infants was 8.1%. Improving neonatal diarrhea management strategies is crucial to reducing morbidity and mortality in these infants.

Heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia.  Neurologic and voice findings.  Spasmodic dysphonia is a disturbance of phonation with laryngeal spasms. Spasmodic dysphonia is a rare neurological disorder characterized by involuntary spasms of the laryngeal muscles during speech, resulting in a strained or strangled voice quality. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity of spasmodic dysphonia by analyzing the neurologic and voice findings in a cohort of patients. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with spasmodic dysphonia were included in the study. Detailed clinical and neurologic examinations were performed, and voice recordings were analyzed for acoustic parameters. The results revealed variability in the clinical presentation and neurologic findings among the patients, with some exhibiting additional neurologic symptoms beyond laryngeal spasms. Voice analysis demonstrated changes in fundamental frequency, intensity, and phonatory breaks, further highlighting the complexity of the disorder. The findings of this study emphasize the need for a comprehensive evaluation of patients with spasmodic dysphonia to better understand the underlying etiology and inform personalized treatment approaches.

Drug response of head and neck tumors in native-state histoculture.  We describe a chemosensitivity testing of head and neck tumors, in which a native-state histoculture, ie, a three-dimensional culture system that maintains important in vivo properties, including tissue architecture, was used. The aim of this study was to evaluate the drug response of head and neck tumors using a native-state histoculture system. Tumor tissue samples were obtained from 25 patients with head and neck tumors, and were immediately placed in the histoculture system. Various anticancer drugs were then added to the culture and the viability of tumor cells was assessed using MTT assay. The results showed significant variation in drug response among the different tumor samples. Some tumors exhibited high sensitivity to certain drugs, while others showed resistance. This native-state histoculture system provides a valuable tool for predicting drug response and selecting appropriate chemotherapy regimens for individual patients with head and neck tumors, leading to more personalized treatment strategies.

Blood pressure measurements during dental checkups representative of 26-hour registration.  The effect of dental checkups on blood pressure was investigated. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of dental checkups on blood pressure measurements over a 26-hour period. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, all of whom underwent routine dental checkups. Blood pressure measurements were taken at various intervals, including before the dental checkup, immediately after, and at regular intervals over a 26-hour period. The results demonstrated a significant increase in blood pressure immediately after the dental checkup compared to the baseline measurements. However, this increase was temporary and returned to baseline levels within 4 hours. There were no significant differences in blood pressure measurements between the pre-dental checkup, immediate post-checkup, and the 26-hour period. These findings suggest that dental checkups may transiently increase blood pressure, but this effect is not sustained over a longer period of time. Further studies are warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of this phenomenon.

Central airway obstruction due to cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis in a patient with AIDS. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and can often lead to a wide range of complications. We present a case of a 42-year-old male with AIDS who developed central airway obstruction due to cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis. The patient presented with a progressive cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest revealed severe narrowing of the tracheal lumen. Bronchoscopic examination showed extensive necrotic tissue with ulcerations in the trachea. CMV infection was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction analysis of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. The patient was initiated on antiretroviral therapy along with ganciclovir, and bronchoscopic debridement was performed to alleviate the airway obstruction. He showed significant improvement in symptoms and resolution of tracheal necrosis on follow-up bronchoscopy. This case highlights the importance of considering CMV infection in the differential diagnosis of airway obstruction in patients with HIV/AIDS and the potential benefit of antiviral therapy and bronchoscopic intervention in managing this condition.

Cerebrospinal fluid fistula and endoscopic sinus surgery.  Seven cases of cerebrospinal fluid fistulae occurring as a result of endoscopic sinus surgery in a total of 800 ethmoidectomies are discussed, along with 1 case referred for consultation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) fistulae are rare complications of endoscopic sinus surgery. This study presents seven cases of CSF fistulae that occurred in 800 patients who underwent ethmoidectomy. Additionally, one case referred for consultation is discussed. The patients' clinical presentations varied, with symptoms such as postoperative rhinorrhea, recurrent meningitis, and pneumocephalus. All cases were confirmed through imaging studies, including CT scans and intraoperative findings. The fistulae were successfully repaired in all patients using endoscopic techniques, along with various materials for grafting. Postoperative follow-up showed resolution of symptoms and no further evidence of CSF leakage. This study highlights the importance of considering CSF fistula as a potential complication in patients undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery. Prompt recognition and appropriate management techniques can lead to successful outcomes.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease from allogeneic dura: a review of risks and safety. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare and fatal neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of abnormal prion proteins in the brain. Transmission of CJD through contaminated surgical instruments or transplantation of infected tissues has been well-documented. Allogeneic dura mater transplantation, commonly used in neurosurgical procedures, has been identified as a potential route of transmission for CJD. In this review, we summarize the reported cases of CJD transmission through allogeneic dura transplantation and discuss the associated risks and safety measures. A total of 77 cases of dura-associated CJD have been reported worldwide, with an estimated transmission risk of 1 in 6869 grafts. We also highlight the challenges in preventing CJD transmission, including the limited availability of validated diagnostic tests for pre-transplant screening. Strategies to mitigate the risk of dural graft-associated CJD transmission, such as improved donor selection and screening protocols, are crucial for enhancing patient safety in neurosurgical procedures.

Nitrite from inflammatory cells--a cancer risk factor in ulcerative colitis? Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were found in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the colon that increases the risk of developing colorectal cancer. This study investigated whether nitrite, a byproduct of inflammation, is a potential risk factor for cancer development in UC patients. The study included 100 patients with acute UC, and 77 percent of them exhibited elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a decreased luminal pH. These findings suggest that the presence of elevated nitrite levels in UC patients could contribute to the development of colorectal cancer. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this association and develop preventive strategies targeting nitrite-related carcinogenesis in UC patients to reduce their cancer risk.

Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis: surgical results in 32 ears and a review of the literature.  Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis is described in 32 operated ears from 28 patients. The majority of patients presented with conductive hearing loss in childhood, with an average age at diagnosis of 8.5 years. Pure-tone audiometry revealed a mean air-bone gap of 33 dB. Preoperative imaging revealed fixation of the stapes in all cases. Surgical intervention involved stapedotomy in 28 ears and stapedectomy in 4 ears. Postoperatively, there was a significant improvement in hearing, with a mean air-bone gap of 14 dB. Complications were generally minor, with three cases of temporary dizziness and one case of sensorineural hearing loss. A literature review revealed a total of 206 cases of isolated congenital stapes ankylosis reported in the literature. The etiology of this condition remains unclear, and it is often associated with other congenital anomalies. Surgical intervention is a safe and effective treatment option for isolated congenital stapes ankylosis, resulting in significant improvement in hearing function.

Protective and curative effects of rifampicin in Acanthamoeba meningitis of the mouse. Acanthamoeba meningitis is a rare but devastating infection, often leading to death despite aggressive treatment. The aim of this study was to investigate the potential protective and curative effects of rifampicin, a broad-spectrum antibiotic, in Acanthamoeba meningitis in a mouse model. Mice were infected with Acanthamoeba and then treated with rifampicin either prophylactically or after the development of symptoms. Results showed that prophylactic treatment with rifampicin significantly prolonged the survival of infected mice compared to the control group. Moreover, curative treatment with rifampicin also improved survival rates and reduced the severity of neurological symptoms. These findings suggest that rifampicin may have both protective and curative effects against Acanthamoeba meningitis and could be a potential treatment option for this life-threatening infection.

US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of gallbladder masses.  Ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was performed in 88 patients who had gallbladder masses. The aim of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic utility of ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy in patients with gallbladder masses. A total of 88 patients with gallbladder masses underwent US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Adequate cytological samples were obtained in 82 out of 88 cases (93.2%). The most common diagnoses were adenocarcinoma (n=43), followed by metastatic carcinoma (n=23), and benign lesions (n=16). The overall diagnostic accuracy of US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was 92%, with a sensitivity of 91.6% and specificity of 100%. There were no major complications associated with the procedure. Our findings demonstrate that US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy is a safe and accurate modality for the diagnosis of gallbladder masses. This technique can provide valuable information for guiding treatment decisions and improving patient outcomes.

Differences in the membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins in normal and scrapie- or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease-infected brains. Prion diseases such as scrapie and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) are characterized by the accumulation of abnormal prion proteins in the brain. The interaction of prion proteins with the cellular membrane is thought to play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of these diseases. In this study, we investigated the differences in membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins (APPs) in normal and scrapie- or CJD-infected brains. Using various biochemical and biophysical techniques, we demonstrated that the membrane association of scrapie APPs was significantly altered in infected brains compared to normal brains. We observed an increased membrane binding affinity and altered lipid composition of the associated membrane fractions in infected brains. Furthermore, we found that the scrapie APPs exhibited enhanced aggregation propensity and decreased proteolytic processing in infected brains. Our findings suggest that the abnormal membrane interaction of scrapie APPs in infected brains may contribute to the pathogenesis of prion diseases by facilitating the accumulation and propagation of abnormal prion proteins.

Role of cell-mediated immunity to staphylococci in blepharitis. Blepharitis, a common inflammatory condition of the eyelid margins, has been associated with infection by Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis. However, the role of cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in the pathogenesis of blepharitis remains poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the contribution of CMI to staphylococcal blepharitis. Thirty-five patients with chronic blepharitis were enrolled, and their immune responses to staphylococcal antigens were assessed. Results showed that patients with active blepharitis had significantly lower levels of CMI compared to healthy controls. Moreover, there was a positive correlation between the severity of blepharitis symptoms and the magnitude of the CMI response. These findings suggest that CMI plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of staphylococcal blepharitis and highlight the potential of immune-modulating therapies targeting CMI for the management of this condition. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop effective interventions.

Effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin.  Previous studies have found that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury caused further impairment of mitogenic response of B lymphocytes compared with burn injury alone. The effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin were investigated in this study. Previous research has shown that acute ethanol ingestion prior to burn injury exacerbates the impairment of B lymphocyte mitogenic response compared to burn injury alone. A total of 30 Sprague-Dawley rats were divided into four groups: control, ethanol, burn, and ethanol + burn. The rats in the ethanol groups received a single dose of ethanol via gavage, while the burn groups received a standardized third-degree burn injury. Blood samples were collected at different time points, and serum immunoglobulin levels were analyzed. The results showed that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury significantly decreased serum immunoglobulin levels compared to burn injury alone. These findings suggest that acute ethanol ingestion may have an additive effect on the suppression of the immune response following burn injury. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Closure of leaking filtering blebs with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. Filtering blebs are commonly used in glaucoma surgery to reduce intraocular pressure. However, complications such as leaks can occur, leading to hypotony and increased risk of infection. This study explored the efficacy of cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive in the closure of leaking filtering blebs. Ten patients with symptomatic leaking blebs were included in the study. The blebs were exposed and thoroughly dried before applying the tissue adhesive. Postoperatively, all patients demonstrated complete closure of the leaking blebs and resolution of symptoms. No adverse events or complications were reported during the follow-up period. Cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive appears to be a safe and effective method for closing leaking filtering blebs, providing a potential alternative to traditional surgical techniques.

Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion simulating middle cerebral artery occlusion. Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion is a rare condition that can present with similar clinical features to middle cerebral artery occlusion, leading to diagnostic challenges. This case report describes a patient who presented with symptoms suggestive of middle cerebral artery occlusion, including contralateral hemiparesis and aphasia, but imaging studies revealed a proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion instead. The patient was initially treated with intravenous thrombolysis but showed minimal improvement. Emergent endovascular thrombectomy was then performed, resulting in significant neurological improvement. This case highlights the importance of considering proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion as a differential diagnosis in cases presenting with clinical features of middle cerebral artery occlusion.

Spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While the primary pathology of PD is the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, emerging evidence suggests that spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms may also play a role in the motor dysfunction observed in PD. In this review, we discuss the potential involvement of spinal cord inhibitory pathways, specifically gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABAergic) and glycinergic systems, in the pathophysiology of PD. We highlight studies that have investigated alterations in GABAergic and glycinergic transmission in animal models of PD and in post-mortem human spinal cord tissue. Furthermore, we examine the modulation of spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms as a therapeutic target for the management of motor symptoms in PD. Understanding the contribution of spinal cord inhibitory pathways in the context of PD may provide novel insights into the pathogenesis of the disease and open new avenues for therapeutic interventions.

Effects of pill-giving on maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression Fifty outpatients with mild, chronic, mood-reactive depression whose mood improved markedly after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were randomly assigned in a double-blind design either to have their placebo medication discontinued or to have it maintained for an additional 6 weeks. This study aimed to investigate the effects of pill-giving on the maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression. Fifty outpatients who experienced significant improvement in mood after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were included in the study. These patients were randomly assigned in a double-blind design to either discontinue the placebo medication or maintain it for an additional 6 weeks. The findings demonstrated that patients who continued taking the placebo medication maintained their initial improvement in mood, suggesting that pill-giving can contribute to the maintenance of the placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms of this effect.

Cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the patient with cancer.  The records of 114 cancer patients suffering cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA) during a 3-year period at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) were retrospectively reviewed to identify variables predicting final outcome in these patients. This study aimed to identify variables predicting the final outcome in cancer patients who experienced cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA). A retrospective review of the records of 114 patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center over a 3-year period was conducted. Patient demographic information, cancer type, treatment history, comorbidities, and resuscitation outcomes were analyzed. 

The results showed that the overall survival rate after CPA in cancer patients was low, with only 17% of patients surviving to hospital discharge. Factors associated with a worse prognosis included advanced stage cancer, presence of metastasis, previous chemotherapy or radiation therapy, and the presence of comorbidities. Additionally, patients with hematologic malignancies had a significantly poorer outcome compared to those with solid tumors. 

These findings emphasize the poor prognosis for cancer patients who experience CPA and highlight the importance of considering individual patient characteristics and cancer subtype when making resuscitation decisions in this population.

Ultrasonography in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.  Differentiation of uncomplicated pyelonephritis versus complicated pyelonephritis has always been problematic. Acute pyelonephritis is a common inflammatory condition of the kidneys, and its correct classification as either uncomplicated or complicated can impact treatment strategies and patient outcomes. This study aimed to investigate the role of ultrasonography in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis. 

A total of 98 patients with suspected acute pyelonephritis were included in the study. Each patient underwent ultrasonography and their medical records were reviewed for clinical and laboratory findings. The ultrasonographic findings were classified as either complicated or uncomplicated based on the presence or absence of renal abscesses, perinephric fluid collections, or renal papillary necrosis. 

The results showed that ultrasonography had a sensitivity of 88% and a specificity of 92% in differentiating between uncomplicated and complicated acute pyelonephritis. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 82% and 94%, respectively. The presence of renal abscesses on ultrasonography was the most accurate predictor of complicated acute pyelonephritis. 

In conclusion, ultrasonography is a valuable tool in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis. Its high sensitivity and specificity make it a reliable non-invasive imaging modality for guiding treatment decisions and improving patient outcomes.

Nondiagnosed left main ostial stenosis partly due to the use of 5 French coronary angiographic catheters. This case report highlights an unusual and potentially dangerous complication of using 5 French coronary angiographic catheters during coronary angiography. A 65-year-old male patient with a history of stable angina underwent coronary angiography for evaluation of his symptoms. Initial angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease, but subsequent assessment using a 5 French catheter demonstrated a severe stenosis at the ostium of the left main coronary artery. Further investigation revealed that the ostial stenosis was most likely a result of the smaller diameter of the 5 French catheter, which caused trauma and subsequent intimal hyperplasia. This report emphasizes the need for caution when using smaller diameter catheters, particularly in patients with suspected left main coronary artery disease. Awareness of this potential complication can help prevent delayed diagnosis and management in similar cases.

Moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas: unique magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomographic findings of perifocal edema. Craniopharyngiomas are rare, benign tumors that arise from remnants of the embryonic Rathke's pouch. They commonly present with a variety of clinical symptoms, including hormonal disturbances and visual deficits. However, the presence of perifocal edema in craniopharyngiomas leading to a distinct moustache appearance on imaging has not been widely reported. In this study, we present unique magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomographic (CT) findings of perifocal edema in patients with craniopharyngiomas, resulting in a moustache-like pattern surrounding the tumor. This finding was observed in all cases included in the study and appears to be a characteristic feature of craniopharyngiomas. The exact mechanism underlying the development of perifocal edema in these tumors is unclear, but it is hypothesized to be related to the tumor's proximity to the hypothalamus and its effect on local fluid dynamics. Recognition of this imaging pattern can aid in the diagnosis and management of craniopharyngiomas, potentially leading to improved patient outcomes.

Germfree animals and technics in surgical research. The use of germfree animals in surgical research has been instrumental in advancing our understanding of various surgical procedures and techniques. Germfree animals, which are free from any known pathogenic microorganisms, provide a unique environment for studying the effects of surgical interventions. This has allowed researchers to investigate the impact of surgical procedures on wound healing, infection rates, and overall outcomes without the confounding influence of microbial interactions. Moreover, the availability of specific pathogen-free animals has enabled the study of the role of specific microorganisms in surgical outcomes. Techniques such as germfree surgery and gnotobiotic animal models have been developed to maintain the sterile environment during surgical procedures and to study the effects of reintroducing specific microbes. Overall, the use of germfree animals and associated techniques in surgical research has significantly contributed to the development of safer and more effective surgical interventions.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. This study evaluates the outcomes of treating displaced patellar fractures using partial patellectomy. A total of 78 patients with displaced patellar fractures were included in the study. All patients underwent surgery with partial patellectomy as the treatment approach. The mean age of the patients was 42 years. The mean follow-up period was 2 years.

The results revealed satisfactory outcomes in the majority of cases, with 69 patients (88.5%) reporting excellent or good results. Complications were observed in 9 patients (11.5%), including infection, patellar tendon rupture, and knee stiffness. 

Radiographic analysis showed union of the fracture in 73 patients (93.6%) at an average of 12 weeks. Functional assessment using the modified HSS score indicated an average score of 81.4 out of 100. The range of motion and muscle strength showed significant improvement post-surgery.

In conclusion, partial patellectomy is a viable treatment option for displaced patellar fractures, providing satisfactory outcomes and good functional results in the majority of cases. However, careful patient selection and post-operative monitoring are essential for minimizing complications and ensuring optimal outcomes.

Overnight admission of outpatient strabismus patients.  The trend to outpatient strabismus surgery prompted us to determine the frequency of, and the reasons for, postoperative overnight hospital admission following such surgery. We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 256 patients who underwent outpatient strabismus surgery over a 2-year period. Of these patients, 16 (6.3%) required overnight admission to the hospital following surgery. The most common reason for overnight admission was persistent nausea and vomiting (n=8), followed by uncontrolled pain requiring intravenous analgesics (n=4), and delayed recovery from anesthesia (n=2). None of the admitted patients experienced any major complications requiring surgical intervention. Patients who underwent bilateral surgery were more likely to be admitted overnight compared to those who underwent unilateral surgery (p=0.042). Our findings suggest that although the majority of patients can be safely managed as outpatients following strabismus surgery, a small proportion may require overnight admission due to postoperative complications. Preoperative counseling should include a discussion of these potential risks to ensure appropriate patient expectations and postoperative management.

Therapy of persistent human papillomavirus disease with two different interferon species.
