Postoperative respiratory insufficiency occurred in 13% of patients, characterized by decreased arterial oxygen saturation and increased partial pressure of carbon dioxide. The potential mechanisms contributing to these complications included airway obstruction due to laser-induced tissue swelling, pneumothorax secondary to laser-induced lung injury, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome. Patients with pre-existing cardiovascular and respiratory comorbidities were at an increased risk for complications. Measures such as careful preoperative evaluation, hemodynamic monitoring, and adequate postoperative respiratory support may help mitigate these complications and improve patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to develop strategies for optimizing anesthesia management during Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.

Demonstration of the genuine iso-12p character of the standard marker chromosome of testicular germ cell tumors and identification of further chromosome 12 aberrations by competitive in situ hybridization. Testicular germ cell tumors (TGCTs) are characterized by a marker chromosome, iso-12p, which is believed to play a crucial role in tumor development. In this study, we aimed to demonstrate the genuineness of iso-12p and identify other chromosome 12 aberrations in TGCTs. Competitive in situ hybridization was performed, revealing the presence of iso-12p in all tumor samples examined. Furthermore, several additional chromosome 12 aberrations, such as deletions and duplications, were identified. These findings provide further insight into the complex genetic alterations associated with TGCTs and may contribute to the development of targeted therapies for this malignancy.

The failure of serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography to predict patients at risk for pulmonary emboli after trauma. Venous thromboembolism (VTE), including pulmonary emboli (PE), is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in trauma patients. Serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography (PCVOP) has been used as a noninvasive screening tool to identify patients at high risk for developing VTE after trauma. However, its predictive value in identifying patients at risk for developing PE remains unclear. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the utility of PCVOP in predicting PE in trauma patients. Our findings showed a lack of correlation between PCVOP results and the occurrence of PE. These results suggest that PCVOP may not be an effective screening tool for identifying trauma patients at risk for developing PE, and other diagnostic modalities should be considered.

Pathological changes in levator palpebrae superioris muscle treated with botulinum toxin in a case of carotico-cavernous fistula. Carotico-cavernous fistula (CCF) is a rare vascular disorder that can lead to various ophthalmic manifestations. Botulinum toxin (BTX) has been used as a therapeutic option to manage these symptoms by inducing paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. However, the histopathological changes induced by BTX treatment in the LPS muscle of CCF patients have not been extensively studied. In this case report, we present a patient with CCF who underwent BTX treatment and subsequently underwent levator aponeurosis resection. Histopathological examination revealed significant changes in the LPS muscle, including muscle fiber atrophy, fatty infiltration, and fibrosis. These findings provide valuable insights into the potential effects of BTX on the LPS muscle and highlight the need for further research in this area.

Surgical complications of continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis.  Surgical experience with 260 consecutive patients with chronic renal failure receiving continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) at one medical center from 1980 to 1989 is reviewed. This study reviews the surgical complications experienced by 260 consecutive patients receiving continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) for chronic renal failure at a single medical center from 1980 to 1989. The overall incidence of surgical complications was found to be 27%, with the most common being exit site infections (15%) and catheter-related problems (10%). Other complications included hernias (5%), peritonitis (4%), and bowel perforation (2%). Surgical intervention was required in 12% of cases, most commonly for catheter revision or removal. The incidence of complications decreased over the study period, reflecting improvements in surgical techniques and patient management. In conclusion, while CAPD is an effective and convenient method of renal replacement therapy, it is important for healthcare providers to be aware of the potential surgical complications that may arise and to promptly address them to optimize patient outcomes.

Botulinum A toxin for the treatment of adult-onset spasmodic torticollis. Botulinum A toxin has been effectively used in the treatment of adult-onset spasmodic torticollis (ST). This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of botulinum A toxin injections in patients with ST. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with ST were included in the study. All patients received botulinum A toxin injections in the affected muscles. The severity of ST symptoms was assessed before and after the injections using the Toronto Western Spasmodic Torticollis Rating Scale (TWSTRS). The results showed a significant improvement in TWSTRS scores after botulinum A toxin injections, indicating the efficacy of the treatment. Furthermore, no major adverse events associated with the treatment were reported. These findings support the use of botulinum A toxin injections as a safe and effective therapeutic option for adult-onset ST.

Carcinoma of the cervix: value of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement.  In patients with cervical carcinoma, precise knowledge of parametrial tumor extension affects the therapeutic decision between surgery and radiation therapy. This study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging in detecting parametrial involvement in patients with cervical carcinoma. A total of 76 patients with histologically confirmed cervical carcinoma underwent MR imaging prior to treatment. Two experienced radiologists independently reviewed the MR images and assessed the presence of parametrial involvement. The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement were calculated. The results showed that MR imaging had a sensitivity of 83.3%, specificity of 92.8%, and accuracy of 89.4% in detecting parametrial involvement. These findings suggest that MR imaging is a valuable tool for assessing parametrial tumor extension in cervical carcinoma patients, aiding in the treatment decision-making process between surgery and radiation therapy.

Noninvasive assessment of cardiac output in children using impedance cardiography.  This study evaluated the effect of intracardiac shunting on the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output determinations. Impedance cardiography is a noninvasive method for assessing cardiac output in children. However, the accuracy of this technique may be affected by the presence of intracardiac shunting. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of intracardiac shunting on the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output determinations in children. 

A total of 50 children with intracardiac shunts were included in the study. Cardiac output measurements were obtained using both impedance cardiography and a reference method. The results revealed that the presence of intracardiac shunting significantly affected the accuracy of cardiac output determinations obtained through impedance cardiography. Specifically, the measurements tended to underestimate cardiac output in patients with left-to-right shunts and overestimate it in patients with right-to-left shunts. 

In conclusion, the accuracy of cardiac output determinations obtained through impedance cardiography is influenced by the presence of intracardiac shunting. Clinicians should be cautious when interpreting and utilizing these measurements in children with shunts, as they may not accurately reflect true cardiac output values. Further studies are warranted to explore potential strategies for improving the accuracy of impedance cardiography in this specific patient population.

Spinal cord compression from a thoracic paraganglioma: case report. Spinal cord compression is a rare manifestation of paragangliomas. We present the case of a 45-year-old female who presented with progressive weakness, numbness, and difficulty walking. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed an intradural mass in the thoracic region causing spinal cord compression. The patient underwent surgical excision of the tumor, which was histologically confirmed as a paraganglioma. Postoperatively, there was a significant improvement in the patient's neurological symptoms. Paragangliomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia tissue located along the sympathetic and parasympathetic chains. Intradural paragangliomas are even rarer, with only a few reported cases in the literature. Due to their potential to cause spinal cord compression, prompt diagnosis and early surgical intervention are crucial for optimal patient outcomes. This case emphasizes the importance of considering spinal cord compression as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with neurological deficits, particularly in the presence of an intradural mass.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. This study aimed to investigate the association between psychological factors and chronic pain, with a focus on determining if emotional disturbance acts as a precipitator or consequence of the pain. A sample of individuals suffering from chronic pain (N = 150) completed questionnaires assessing pain intensity, emotional distress, and pain-related disability. The results revealed a significant positive correlation between pain intensity and emotional distress (r = 0.62, p < 0.001), indicating that individuals experiencing higher pain levels also reported greater emotional disturbance. Furthermore, pain-related disability was found to mediate the relationship between pain intensity and emotional distress ( = 0.42, p < 0.001). These findings suggest that emotional disturbance may serve as both a precipitator and a consequence of chronic pain, with pain-related disability playing a significant role in this relationship. The implications of these findings for the management and treatment of chronic pain are discussed.

Use of the Collings knife electrode for percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases. The Collings knife electrode has emerged as a potential solution for difficult endourology cases requiring percutaneous access. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the Collings knife electrode in such cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent endourological procedures with percutaneous access using the Collings knife electrode between 2016 and 2020. A total of 56 patients were included in the study. The success rate of percutaneous access using the Collings knife electrode was 87.5%. The most common indication for its use was a complex renal stone burden (46.4%). Complications related to the procedure were rare, with only two cases of minor bleeding reported. No major complications or adverse events were observed. These findings suggest that the Collings knife electrode is a safe and effective tool for achieving percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these results and explore its potential applications in different endourologic procedures.

Optimum results of the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia. Carotid territory ischemia is a common condition that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The current standard of care for this condition involves surgical interventions such as carotid endarterectomy or carotid artery stenting. However, the optimal approach to surgical treatment is still a matter of debate.

Several factors need to be considered when striving for optimum results in the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia. These include patient selection, preoperative evaluation, surgical technique, and postoperative management. Additionally, the role of medical therapy and the use of adjunctive procedures such as shunting or embolic protection devices should also be taken into account.

The goal of surgical treatment is to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke and improve overall outcomes for patients. Therefore, further investigation and research are necessary to determine the most effective and safe approach for surgical intervention in carotid territory ischemia. Only through a comprehensive understanding of these factors will we be able to achieve optimum results and provide the best possible care for patients with this condition.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of crural arteries.  The authors dilated 103 stenosed crural arteries in 71 patients. The authors present their experience with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in the treatment of stenosed crural arteries. A total of 103 arteries in 71 patients were dilated using PTA. The majority of patients presented with symptoms such as claudication and rest pain. The procedure was performed under local anesthesia and fluoroscopic guidance. Balloon dilation was achieved with different sizes ranging from 2 to 6 mm, depending on the degree of stenosis. The technical success rate was 95%, with only a few cases requiring additional interventions such as stenting. Follow-up evaluations showed significant improvement in limb perfusion and symptom relief in the majority of patients. Complications were rare and included minor dissections and transient ischemic attacks. Based on their findings, the authors conclude that PTA is a safe and effective treatment option for stenotic crural arteries, providing satisfactory outcomes in terms of limb revascularization and symptom relief. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts. Saphenous vein bypass grafts are a common surgical intervention for coronary artery disease. However, aneurysmal dilatation, although rare, can occur in these grafts and present various clinical challenges. We report a case of a 62-year-old male who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting with a saphenous vein graft and subsequently developed aneurysmal dilatation at the site of the graft. The patient presented with chest pain and imaging studies revealed a saccular aneurysm measuring 3 cm in diameter. Surgical intervention was deemed necessary to prevent rupture and other complications. The aneurysm was successfully excised, and the graft was replaced with a new segment of saphenous vein. This case highlights the importance of surveillance and early detection of aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts, as prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent potentially life-threatening complications. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and optimal management strategies for this condition.

Calcium and calcium binding in human gallstone disease. The purpose of this study was to investigate the association between calcium and calcium binding proteins in human gallstone disease. Gallstone disease is a common disorder that affects millions of people worldwide, and its pathogenesis is not completely understood. It has been suggested that calcium plays a role in gallstone formation, but the mechanisms involved are not well elucidated. 

We collected gallstone samples from 60 patients undergoing cholecystectomy and analyzed them for calcium content using atomic absorption spectrometry. Additionally, we measured the expression levels of calcium-binding proteins, such as calbindin-D28k and S100A9, in gallstone samples using immunohistochemical staining. 

Our results showed a significant increase in calcium content in gallstones compared to control tissue samples. Furthermore, we found that the expression of calbindin-D28k was significantly increased in gallstones compared to control tissues, while S100A9 expression showed no significant difference. 

These findings suggest that calcium may play a role in gallstone formation, possibly through its interaction with calcium-binding proteins like calbindin-D28k. Further studies are needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms involved and to explore potential therapeutic targets for gallstone disease. This knowledge may ultimately lead to the development of novel treatment strategies for this common and burdensome condition.

Porokeratoses: immunohistochemical, light and electron microscopic evaluation. Porokeratoses are a group of rare keratinization disorders characterized by the presence of cornoid lamellae. Despite their distinctive histopathological features, the etiology and pathogenesis of porokeratoses remain poorly understood. This study aims to investigate the immunohistochemical, light, and electron microscopic characteristics of porokeratosis lesions. 

Skin biopsy specimens from 20 patients diagnosed with different types of porokeratosis were collected and subjected to immunohistochemical staining for various markers including cytokeratins, Ki-67, and p53. Light microscopy and electron microscopy were performed to evaluate the ultrastructural features of the lesions. 

Immunohistochemical analysis revealed aberrant expression of cytokeratins in the cornoid lamellae, indicating abnormal keratinocyte proliferation. The Ki-67 and p53 staining patterns suggested increased cell proliferation and uncontrolled cell growth in the lesional areas. Light microscopy demonstrated the presence of typical cornoid lamellae with parakeratosis and dyskeratosis. Electron microscopy revealed disorganized keratin filaments and abnormal keratohyalin granules. 

These findings shed light on the pathogenesis of porokeratoses, suggesting a dysregulation in keratinocyte proliferation and differentiation. The combination of immunohistochemical, light, and electron microscopy techniques provides valuable insights into the structural and molecular alterations associated with porokeratosis. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic strategies for this challenging group of disorders.

Effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions. The effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions was investigated in a randomized controlled trial. Forty patients undergoing laparotomy were randomly assigned to either an electrocautery group or a control group. Wound healing was assessed using a standardized wound assessment scale at postoperative day 7 and week 4. The electrocautery group showed significantly delayed wound healing compared to the control group at both time points, with a higher incidence of wound infections and dehiscence. Histological analysis revealed increased inflammation and impaired collagen synthesis in the electrocautery group. These findings suggest that electrocautery negatively affects wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions. Surgeons should consider alternative techniques to minimize the use of electrocautery in order to promote optimal wound healing in this setting.

Percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance: animal model. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance in an animal model. Twelve male pigs underwent the procedure under general anesthesia. The prostate gland was cooled using a cryoprobe inserted into the perineum under transrectal ultrasound guidance. The procedure was successfully completed in all animals without any major complications. After cryosurgery, the animals were euthanized, and the prostates were examined. Histological evaluation showed well-demarcated and complete freezing of the targeted prostatic tissue. This study demonstrates that percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance is a feasible and effective technique for prostate ablation. Further studies are needed to validate these findings in a clinical setting.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Distinguishing between primary and metastatic small cell tumors of bone can pose a diagnostic challenge. This case report describes a rare case of metastatic small cell tumor of bone displaying 'true' rosettes and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), traditionally associated with nervous system tumors. A 62-year-old male presented with multiple bone lesions and a previous history of lung cancer. Histological examination of a bone biopsy revealed a small cell tumor with characteristic rosettes formed by tumor cells arranged around a central luminal space. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed GFAP positivity in the tumor cells, indicating a possible neural origin. This case highlights the importance of considering metastatic small cell tumor of bone in the differential diagnosis of bone lesions, especially in patients with known primary malignancies. Immunohistochemical evaluation including GFAP staining can aid in the distinction between primary and metastatic tumors, guiding appropriate treatment decisions and prognosis.

The butterfly rash and the malar flush. The butterfly rash and malar flush are dermatological manifestations commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical significance of these cutaneous findings in a cohort of SLE patients. Medical records of 214 SLE patients were retrospectively reviewed, and the presence of butterfly rash and malar flush was documented. The overall prevalence of butterfly rash was found to be 45.3%, while malar flush was observed in 39.7% of patients. Furthermore, the presence of butterfly rash was significantly associated with increased disease activity, as measured by Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Disease Activity Index (SLEDAI) scores (p < 0.001). On the other hand, malar flush was not found to correlate with disease activity (p = 0.124). Interestingly, the presence of butterfly rash was also associated with higher cumulative organ damage, as assessed by Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics/American College of Rheumatology Damage Index (p = 0.041). Our findings highlight the clinical relevance of butterfly rash as a marker of disease activity and organ damage in SLE patients. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying pathogenic mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these dermatological manifestations in SLE.

Toxic epidermal necrolysis after bone marrow transplantation: study of nine cases. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a rare and life-threatening immune-mediated disorder characterized by widespread skin detachment and mucous membrane involvement. The condition is often triggered by medications, including antibiotics and anti-epileptic drugs. This retrospective study aims to investigate the occurrence and prognosis of TEN in patients who have undergone bone marrow transplantation (BMT). Nine cases of TEN following BMT were identified and their clinical features, outcomes, and risk factors were analyzed. The median time from BMT to the onset of TEN was 14 days. All patients presented with severe skin and mucosal involvement, and required intensive care unit admission. Seven patients received immunosuppressive therapy, while two patients had supportive treatment alone. The overall mortality rate was 55.6%, with infection being the most common cause of death. Older age, delayed engraftment, and graft-versus-host disease were identified as potential risk factors for the development of TEN after BMT. This study highlights the need for close monitoring and timely intervention in patients undergoing BMT who are at increased risk of developing TEN.

Radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma: long-term results. Radical prostatectomy is a commonly performed surgical procedure for treating localized prostate cancer. This study aims to evaluate the long-term outcomes of radical prostatectomy in patients with clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent radical prostatectomy between 1995 and 2005. The primary outcome measures were overall survival, cancer-specific survival, and biochemical recurrence-free survival. Secondary outcome measures included postoperative complications and functional outcomes. The study included 500 patients with a median follow-up period of 15 years. The overall survival rate at 10 years was 85%, while the cancer-specific survival rate was 90%. The biochemical recurrence-free survival rate at 10 years was 75%. Postoperative complications were observed in 20% of the patients, with erectile dysfunction and urinary incontinence being the most common functional outcomes. In conclusion, radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma demonstrates favorable long-term outcomes in terms of survival and recurrence rates. However, functional outcomes, particularly in sexual and urinary domains, remain a concern and should be considered when discussing treatment options with patients.

Bacterial meningitis: an update. Bacterial meningitis is a severe infection of the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. This review provides an update on the current understanding of bacterial meningitis, including its pathogenesis, clinical presentation, and management. Various bacterial pathogens, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type b, are the leading causes of this condition. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of therapy with appropriate antibiotics are crucial in reducing morbidity and mortality. The use of adjunctive therapies, such as corticosteroids and anticoagulants, remains controversial and requires further investigation. Vaccination against common pathogens has shown significant benefits in preventing bacterial meningitis, especially in high-risk populations, such as infants and immunocompromised individuals. Ongoing surveillance and implementation of public health measures are essential for controlling the spread of bacterial meningitis and improving patient outcomes.

X-linked spinal muscular atrophy (Kennedy's syndrome). X-linked spinal muscular atrophy, also known as Kennedy's syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males. This disorder is characterized by progressive weakness and wasting of the muscles, particularly in the limbs and trunk. The condition is caused by an abnormal expansion of a specific gene called the androgen receptor gene on the X chromosome. 
Symptoms typically begin in adulthood, usually between the ages of 20 and 40, and gradually worsen over time. Individuals may experience muscle cramps, difficulty walking, tremors, and muscle loss. In addition to muscle weakness, many patients also develop features of androgen insensitivity, such as gynecomastia and infertility. 
Diagnosis is made through genetic testing to detect the abnormal gene expansion. Currently, there is no cure for X-linked spinal muscular atrophy, and treatment primarily focuses on managing symptoms and improving quality of life.

Molecular analysis of acute promyelocytic leukemia breakpoint cluster region on chromosome 17. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is characterized by a specific chromosomal translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor-alpha (RAR) gene and the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene, resulting in the formation of the PML-RAR fusion protein. The breakpoint cluster region (BCR) on chromosome 17 is involved in this translocation. In this study, we performed molecular analysis of the BCR in 36 APL patients. We identified various breakpoints within the BCR, with the most common being at intron 3 and exon 6. Interestingly, we found a correlation between the specific breakpoint location and clinical characteristics, such as age at diagnosis and white blood cell count. These findings provide further insight into the molecular pathogenesis of APL and may have implications for risk stratification and treatment strategies.

Incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma and other rare skin cancers in a defined population.  Between 1970 and 1984 in Rochester, Minnesota, rare skin cancers developed in 15 local residents: cutaneous T cell lymphoma (six subjects), dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (four), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (two), Merkel cell carcinoma (one), liposarcoma (one), and extramammary Paget's disease (one). This study aimed to assess the incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) and other rare skin cancers in a specific population. Between 1970 and 1984, 15 individuals residing in Rochester, Minnesota, were diagnosed with rare skin cancers. Among them, six had CTCL, four had dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, two had adenocarcinoma of sweat glands, one had Merkel cell carcinoma, one had liposarcoma, and one had extramammary Paget's disease. These findings highlight the importance of monitoring and early detection of rare skin cancers in order to provide timely and appropriate treatment. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop effective preventive strategies for these uncommon malignancies.

The Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome examined by computed tomography, magnetic resonance, and 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose and positron emission tomography. Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome (MSS) is a rare neurogenetic disorder characterized by cerebellar ataxia, cataracts, intellectual disability, and muscle weakness. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the utility of various imaging techniques in the assessment of MSS.

Computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET) using 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) were performed on a cohort of MSS patients. CT scans revealed cerebellar atrophy in all patients, with varying degrees of severity. MRI showed hypointense cerebellar signal on T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighted images in all cases. Additionally, MRI indicated brainstem and basal ganglia abnormalities in some patients.

PET imaging with FDG revealed reduced glucose metabolism in the cerebellum, brainstem, and basal ganglia, consistent with the clinical manifestations of MSS. Furthermore, PET findings correlated with the degree of cerebellar atrophy observed on CT scans.

In conclusion, CT, MRI, and PET with FDG can provide valuable information for the evaluation and diagnosis of MSS. The multimodal imaging approach offers a comprehensive assessment of structural and functional abnormalities associated with this rare neurogenetic syndrome.

Neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids are elevated in migraine. Migraine is a common neurological disorder characterized by recurrent headaches and associated symptoms. The pathophysiology of migraine is complex and not fully understood. Recent studies have suggested a role for neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids in the pathogenesis of migraine. This study aimed to investigate the levels of neuroexcitatory amino acids in patients with migraine compared with healthy controls. 

A total of 100 patients with migraine and 100 age- and sex-matched healthy controls were included in the study. Plasma samples were collected from each participant, and the levels of neuroexcitatory amino acids, including glutamate, aspartate, and glycine, were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography.

The results showed significantly elevated levels of glutamate and aspartate in the plasma of migraine patients compared with healthy controls (p<0.05). However, no significant difference was observed in the levels of glycine between the two groups.

These findings suggest that neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids, particularly glutamate and aspartate, may play a role in the pathophysiology of migraine. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these findings.

Medical treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.  Many agents seem to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. However, the management and prevention of peptic ulcer disease require a multidimensional approach. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) are commonly used for acid suppression and symptom relief. In addition, antibiotics are prescribed to eradicate Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection, a major cause of peptic ulcers. Lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and tobacco, are also recommended. The selection of treatment agents depends on various factors, including the presence of H. pylori, patient compliance, and the severity of symptoms. Combining PPIs, H2RAs, and antibiotics has shown higher eradication rates compared to monotherapy. Furthermore, there is growing evidence for the use of probiotics in preventing the recurrence of peptic ulcers. Overall, a tailored approach based on individual patient characteristics and risk factors is crucial for effective management and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.

Cause of death in an emergency department A retrospective review was done of 601 consecutive emergency department deaths.  Nontrauma causes accounted for 77% of the deaths and this group had an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. A retrospective review was conducted to identify the leading causes of death in a sample of 601 patients who presented to the emergency department (ED) and subsequently died. The majority of deaths (77%) were due to nontrauma causes, with an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. The most common nontrauma causes of death were cardiac events, including myocardial infarction and arrhythmias, accounting for 40% of the cases. Respiratory failure was the second most common cause, responsible for 18% of the deaths. Other notable causes included cerebrovascular events (12%), sepsis (10%), and gastrointestinal bleeding (6%). These findings underscore the importance of prompt recognition and appropriate management of cardiac and respiratory emergencies in the ED setting to potentially improve outcomes and reduce mortality.

Carboplatin in childhood brain tumors. Carboplatin has emerged as a promising treatment option for childhood brain tumors due to its efficacy and tolerability. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of carboplatin as a part of multimodal therapy in pediatric patients with brain tumors. 

A total of 50 patients diagnosed with various types of brain tumors were included in the study. All patients received carboplatin in combination with other chemotherapeutic agents and/or radiation therapy. The response to treatment was assessed using radiological imaging and clinical evaluation.

The results showed that carboplatin demonstrated a favorable response in the majority of patients, with a significant reduction in tumor size observed in 70% of cases. Moreover, the treatment was well-tolerated, with only mild to moderate side effects reported. 

Subgroup analysis based on tumor type revealed that carboplatin was particularly effective in medulloblastoma and ependymoma, with response rates of 80% and 75%, respectively. In contrast, gliomas showed a lower response rate of 50%.

In conclusion, carboplatin is a promising therapeutic option for childhood brain tumors, exhibiting both efficacy and tolerability. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize treatment protocols.

The operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease.  Three hundred eight patients who underwent operation for hyperparathyroidism were studied. Among these patients, 17 also had coexisting thyroid disease. The aim of this study was to evaluate the outcomes of operative management in patients with concurrent thyroid and parathyroid diseases. The mean age of the patients was 54 years, with a female predominance (82%). Preoperatively, 12 patients had symptoms related to hyperparathyroidism, while 5 patients were asymptomatic. All patients underwent a comprehensive preoperative evaluation, including laboratory tests and imaging studies. Intraoperatively, a focused parathyroidectomy was performed in 12 patients, while a bilateral exploration was required in 5 patients. Postoperatively, all patients had improvement or resolution of symptoms related to hyperparathyroidism. There were no major complications observed in any patient. This study highlights the successful operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid diseases, and supports the need for a comprehensive evaluation and individualized surgical approach in these cases.

Surgical aspects of sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis. Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis (SEP) is a rare condition characterized by the progressive encapsulation of the small bowel within a fibrous membrane. This fibrous membrane can lead to bowel obstruction and associated symptoms. Surgical intervention is often necessary to alleviate symptoms and prevent complications. This article reviews the surgical aspects of SEP, including the various techniques employed in the management of this condition. The surgical approach depends on the severity of bowel obstruction and the extent of adhesions. Techniques such as adhesiolysis, partial enterectomy, and intestinal bypass may be utilized. The use of adjuvant therapy, such as corticosteroids or immunosuppressants, may also be considered in some cases. Surgical treatment of SEP carries a risk of complications, including intraoperative bowel injury and infection. Close postoperative monitoring is essential to detect and manage any complications promptly. Overall, surgical intervention plays a crucial role in the management of SEP, and a multidisciplinary approach involving surgeons, radiologists, and gastroenterologists is essential to optimize patient outcomes.

Immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class glutathione S-transferases in human tissues. Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) are a family of enzymes involved in the detoxification of xenobiotics and endogenous compounds. The expression and localization of different GST isoforms in human tissues have significant implications for understanding drug metabolism and susceptibility to various diseases. In this study, we utilized immunohistochemistry to determine the cellular distribution of alpha, mu, and pi class GSTs in various human tissues. Our results demonstrate differential expression patterns of GST isoforms in different tissues, with the alpha class predominantly observed in liver and kidney, the mu class in lung and gastrointestinal tract, and the pi class in the liver, kidney, and lung. Additionally, we observed tissue-specific variations in subcellular localization, with cytoplasmic and nuclear staining observed for alpha and mu classes, while pi class staining was predominantly cytoplasmic. These findings provide valuable insights into the tissue-specific regulation and functional significance of GST isoforms in human physiology and disease, highlighting their potential as diagnostic and therapeutic targets.

Comparison of shunt fraction estimation using transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine and technetium-99m-pertechnetate in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. The aim of this study was to compare the accuracy and reliability of transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine (IMP) and technetium-99m-pertechnetate (Tc) in estimating shunt fraction in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. Sixteen dogs were divided into two groups: eight dogs in the IMP group and eight dogs in the Tc group. Shunt fraction was calculated using both radiotracers and compared to the gold standard measurement obtained via direct portography. Results showed that both IMP and Tc provided accurate estimations of shunt fraction, with no significant difference between the two groups. However, the IMP group demonstrated lower variability and higher inter-observer reliability compared to the Tc group. These findings suggest that transcolonic IMP may be a reliable alternative to Tc in the assessment of shunt fraction in dogs with chronic biliary cirrhosis. Further research is needed to validate these results in a larger patient population.

Decreased local toxicity with subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin): a preliminary report. This preliminary report presents the findings of a study aimed at evaluating the local toxicity of subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin) administration. Historically, intravenous administration of heroin has been associated with various local complications. Therefore, the investigation of alternative routes, such as subcutaneous, is of clinical interest. A total of 30 individuals with opioid dependence were included in the study, and they received subcutaneous injections of diamorphine. The results indicate a low incidence of local adverse effects, such as infection and tissue damage, supporting the potential for subcutaneous diamorphine administration as a safer route without compromising the effectiveness of the drug for opioid-dependent individuals. Further research is warranted to validate these findings.

Progression of stage T1 bladder tumors after intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin [published erratum appears in J Urol 1991 Apr;145(4):840] Of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis and T1) treated by transurethral resection and an initial 6-week course of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) 195 were evaluated after 3 months for local response. This study aims to evaluate the progression of stage T1 bladder tumors following treatment with intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG). A total of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis, and T1) underwent transurethral resection and received an initial 6-week course of intravesical BCG. After 3 months, 195 patients were evaluated for local response. The results revealed that some T1 bladder tumors progressed despite BCG treatment. This finding highlights the need for further research on alternative treatment modalities and the potential impact of tumor characteristics on the effectiveness of BCG therapy. Understanding the progression patterns of T1 bladder tumors is crucial for optimizing treatment strategies and improving patient outcomes. The findings of this study contribute to the existing literature on bladder cancer management.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. Pain management is a crucial aspect in the care of gynecologic cancer patients. Indwelling epidural catheters have been increasingly utilized for effective pain control in this population. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of indwelling epidural catheters for pain management in gynecologic cancer patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent gynecologic cancer surgery and received indwelling epidural catheters for postoperative pain control. Pain scores, analgesic consumption, and adverse events were assessed. Our results demonstrated that indwelling epidural catheters provided effective pain relief with significantly decreased pain scores and reduced analgesic requirements. Furthermore, the incidence of adverse events, such as respiratory depression and catheter-related complications, was low. Therefore, indwelling epidural catheters are a safe and effective modality for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients undergoing surgery, improving patient comfort and overall outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and optimize the management of pain in this patient population.

Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy. Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used for the removal of the gallbladder. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of this technique in a cohort of patients. The study analyzed data from 150 patients who underwent the procedure between 2015 and 2017. The results showed that outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy was successful in all cases, with no major complications reported. The patients experienced minimal postoperative pain and had faster recovery times compared to traditional open cholecystectomy. Additionally, the cosmetic outcome was excellent, with minimal scarring observed. This study suggests that outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy is a safe and effective alternative to traditional gallbladder removal surgery.

Marijuana smoking as a possible cause of tongue carcinoma in young patients. The association between marijuana smoking and tongue carcinoma in young patients was investigated. A retrospective study was conducted on patients with tongue carcinoma aged 40 years or younger. Medical records were reviewed to identify patients with a history of marijuana smoking. Comparisons were made between marijuana smokers and non-smokers in terms of clinical characteristics and pathological features of tongue carcinoma. A total of X patients were included in the study, with X% being marijuana smokers. The analysis showed that marijuana smokers were more likely to develop tongue carcinoma at a younger age compared to non-smokers. Additionally, marijuana smokers had a higher incidence of advanced stage disease and a greater presence of poorly differentiated tumors. These findings suggest that marijuana smoking may be a possible risk factor for the development of tongue carcinoma in young patients.

Use of activated charcoal to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate.  The course of a neonate administered activated charcoal orally for elevated phenobarbital concentration is described. Activated charcoal has been used as a treatment to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in adults, but its use in neonates is limited. This case report describes the successful use of activated charcoal in a neonate with elevated phenobarbital levels. The patient was a term neonate who was inadvertently overdosed with phenobarbital. Activated charcoal was administered orally and the serum phenobarbital concentration was monitored over time. The concentration decreased significantly within 12 hours of charcoal administration. No adverse effects were observed during the course of treatment. This case highlights the potential benefit of activated charcoal in reducing elevated phenobarbital levels in neonates. Further studies are needed to establish the optimal dose and timing of activated charcoal administration in this population.

Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease: a review of the retroperitoneal approach. The retroperitoneal approach for infrarenal abdominal aortic disease has gained attention as an alternative to the traditional transperitoneal approach. This review aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the retroperitoneal approach and discuss its advantages and disadvantages in comparison to the transperitoneal approach. Several studies have demonstrated that the retroperitoneal approach offers several advantages, including decreased operative time, less blood loss, reduced postoperative morbidity, shorter hospital stay, and lower costs. However, it may pose technical challenges and require advanced surgical skills. Despite these limitations, the retroperitoneal approach appears to be a viable option for selected patients and warrants further investigation to better understand its long-term outcomes and impact on patient quality of life.

Prognosticating study for cervical myelopathy using evoked spinal cord potentials. Cervical myelopathy is a condition characterized by compression or injury to the spinal cord in the neck region, resulting in motor, sensory, and coordination deficits. Currently, prognosis prediction for cervical myelopathy relies mainly on clinical evaluation and radiographic findings, which may not accurately reflect the extent of spinal cord dysfunction. This study aimed to investigate the prognostic value of evoked spinal cord potentials (ESCPs) in predicting the functional outcome of patients with cervical myelopathy. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with cervical myelopathy underwent ESCP assessment before surgical intervention. The ESCP parameters, including latency, amplitude, and waveform morphology, were analyzed and correlated with postoperative functional outcome scores. The results demonstrated a significant correlation between ESCP parameters and functional outcome scores, indicating that ESCPs could serve as a valuable prognostic tool for predicting the recovery outcome in patients with cervical myelopathy. Further studies are warranted to validate and refine the predictive value of ESCPs in larger patient populations.

Mammographic follow-up of low-suspicion lesions: compliance rate and diagnostic yield. The aim of this study was to evaluate the compliance rate and diagnostic yield of mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions. A total of 500 patients with low-suspicion lesions identified on mammography were included in the study. The compliance rate for follow-up mammography was 78%. Among the patients who completed the follow-up, 20% had an upgrade in their lesion classification and were recommended for further investigation. The diagnostic yield of follow-up mammography was 4%, with 2% of patients being diagnosed with malignancy. The study findings suggest that mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions is associated with a moderate compliance rate and a low diagnostic yield. Further research is needed to optimize the management of these lesions and improve patient outcomes.

An analysis of abnormalities of the retinoblastoma gene in human ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. The retinoblastoma gene (Rb) is a key regulator of cell cycle progression and its abnormalities have been implicated in the development of various cancers. This study aimed to analyze the abnormalities of the Rb gene in human ovarian and endometrial carcinoma, two common gynecologic malignancies. 

Tumor samples from 50 ovarian and 50 endometrial carcinoma patients were collected and subjected to genetic analysis. The results showed that abnormalities of the Rb gene were present in a significant proportion of both ovarian and endometrial carcinoma cases. Specifically, mutations in the Rb gene were detected in 30% of ovarian carcinoma samples and 25% of endometrial carcinoma samples. Additionally, loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at the Rb locus was observed in 20% of ovarian carcinoma samples and 18% of endometrial carcinoma samples. 

These findings provide further evidence for the involvement of the Rb gene in the pathogenesis of ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. Targeting the Rb pathway may hold promise as a potential therapeutic strategy for these gynecologic malignancies. Further investigation is warranted to elucidate the precise mechanisms underlying Rb gene abnormalities and their potential clinical implications.

Adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus after total gastrectomy A 64-yr-old Japanese male who underwent a partial gastrectomy for a duodenal ulcer at the age of 21, a total resection of the remnant stomach for a stomal ulcer at age 25, and in whom Barrett's esophagus was diagnosed at age 47, was found to have a tumor at the distal esophagus and was operated on by thoracic esophagectomy. A 64-year-old Japanese male with a history of gastrectomy and Barrett's esophagus presented with a distal esophageal tumor. He underwent thoracic esophagectomy for tumor removal. This case highlights the potential development of adenocarcinoma in patients with Barrett's esophagus following gastrectomy.

Chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia: a manifestation of visceral vasculitis? Gastrointestinal involvement occurs frequently in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, and most often involves the liver and spleen. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between chronic diarrhea and essential mixed cryoglobulinemia (EMC), specifically exploring the possibility of visceral vasculitis as the underlying mechanism. Gastrointestinal manifestations are common in EMC, with the liver and spleen frequently affected. However, the association between EMC and chronic diarrhea remains poorly understood. Through a comprehensive literature review, we identified several case reports and series that described patients with EMC presenting with chronic diarrhea. These cases suggested a potential link between visceral vasculitis and the development of chronic diarrhea in EMC. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the pathophysiology of this association and explore targeted treatment strategies for improving gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with EMC. Understanding the mechanisms underlying chronic diarrhea in EMC may lead to improved management and overall quality of life for affected individuals.

Fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants. Fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants is a concerning issue in orthopedic surgery. The long-term stability and functionality of these implants are crucial for successful patient outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and factors contributing to fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants. A retrospective analysis of 50 patients who experienced implant failure was conducted. The mean time to failure was found to be 4.6 years, and the most common site of failure was the femoral stem. Factors such as patient age, body mass index, and implant design were found to significantly influence the incidence of fatigue failure. These findings emphasize the importance of careful patient selection and implant design in order to mitigate the risk of fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants.

Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism causing subacute cor pulmonale: a difficult antemortem diagnosis [published erratum appears in Mayo Clin Proc 1991 Apr;66(4):439] Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is difficult to diagnose. This case report describes a patient with subacute cor pulmonale ultimately attributed to microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism. A 63-year-old man with a history of bladder cancer presented with progressively worsening dyspnea, lower extremity edema, and elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Despite extensive evaluation, the cause of his cor pulmonale remained elusive. Autopsy revealed multiple microscopic tumor emboli throughout the pulmonary vasculature, with infiltrating deposits also found in the liver and spleen. These findings were consistent with tumor embolism from his previously treated bladder cancer. The rarity and diagnostic challenges of microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism are discussed, including the limited sensitivity of imaging modalities and the need for invasive procedures such as transbronchial lung biopsy or autopsy for definitive diagnosis. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for tumor embolism in patients with unexplained cor pulmonale, particularly those with a history of malignancy.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. A study was conducted to analyze the heart weights of white men between the ages of 20 and 39 years through autopsy cases. A total of 218 cases were included in the analysis. The mean heart weight was found to be 323 grams, with a standard deviation of 43 grams. The authors also compared the heart weights based on body weight and height and found a positive correlation between heart weight and both variables. However, when adjusted for body surface area, the correlation was no longer significant. These findings provide valuable information on the normal distribution of heart weights in this specific population, which can be useful for clinical practice and further research in cardiology.

Air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres: new sign of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs. Intraperitoneal air is a common finding in various intra-abdominal pathologies, such as bowel perforation or surgical procedures. The presence of intraperitoneal air is usually radiologically assessed using different imaging modalities. We present a case report of a 45-year-old male who underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis and subsequently developed postoperative abdominal pain and bloating. Plain radiographs of the abdomen showed a new sign, namely air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres, which correlated with intraperitoneal air. This radiographic sign previously has not been described in the literature. The recognition of this new sign may aid in the diagnosis of intraperitoneal air and prompt appropriate management in patients with suspected intra-abdominal pathology.

99mTc HM-PAO SPECT in pediatric migraine. The aim of this study was to evaluate the cerebral perfusion patterns in children with migraine using technetium-99m hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (99mTc HM-PAO) single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). A total of 27 pediatric patients with migraine and 20 healthy controls underwent 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT imaging. SPECT images were acquired 30 minutes after intravenous injection of 99mTc HM-PAO and were analyzed using a region of interest approach. The results showed that children with migraine had significantly decreased perfusion in the bilateral frontal, temporal, and parietal regions compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between the severity of migraine and the extent of hypoperfusion in these regions. These findings suggest that cerebral hypoperfusion may play a role in the pathophysiology of pediatric migraine and provide insights for further investigation and potential therapeutic interventions.

A T-cell neoplasia showing clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis with novel chromosomal abnormalities and N-ras mutation.  Malignant histiocytosis (MH) is a distinct disease entity defined clinically and morphologically. We present a case of T-cell neoplasia exhibiting clinicopathologic features consistent with malignant histiocytosis (MH) and novel chromosomal abnormalities along with an N-ras mutation. A 47-year-old female presented with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and anemia. A bone marrow biopsy revealed infiltration of the bone marrow by large, atypical lymphoid cells showing histiocytic differentiation. Immunophenotyping studies demonstrated CD3 positivity and a lack of pan-B-cell markers. Molecular studies identified an N-ras mutation in the neoplastic cells. Cytogenetic analysis revealed complex chromosomal abnormalities, including a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 1 and 15. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of T-cell neoplasia with MH-like features associated with an N-ras mutation and novel chromosomal abnormalities. This case expands the spectrum of MH-like neoplasms and highlights the importance of comprehensive molecular and cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and classification of histiocytic neoplasms. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms driving the development of these rare and aggressive neoplasms.

The effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe polycystic ovarian syndrome. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a common reproductive disorder characterized by ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism. In this study, we investigated the effect of metoclopramide, a dopamine antagonist, on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe PCOS. Thirty-five patients were randomized into two groups: metoclopramide group (n=18) and control group (n=17). The metoclopramide group received 10 mg of oral metoclopramide daily for 10 days prior to gonadotropin administration, while the control group received a placebo. Ovarian stimulation was performed using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist protocol. The metoclopramide group showed significantly higher number of mature follicles, oocytes retrieved, and fertilization rates compared to the control group. Additionally, there was a significant increase in endometrial thickness in the metoclopramide group. Our findings suggest that metoclopramide enhances ovarian responsiveness and improves reproductive outcomes in patients with severe PCOS undergoing controlled ovarian stimulation. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize the treatment protocol.

Treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. Systemic fungal infections are a common cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with AIDS. Current treatment options are limited and often associated with significant adverse effects and high costs. A new antifungal agent, caspofungin, has shown promise in the management of these infections. This abstract aims to summarize the clinical efficacy and safety profile of caspofungin in treating systemic fungal infections in patients with AIDS. Several clinical trials have demonstrated the effectiveness of caspofungin in achieving successful treatment outcomes, including improved survival rates and reduced fungal burdens. Additionally, caspofungin has shown favorable tolerability with minimal drug interactions and a low incidence of adverse effects. These findings suggest that caspofungin may be a valuable therapeutic option for clinicians in the management of systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal dosing regimens and long-term outcomes of caspofungin therapy.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. Chronic pain is a complex condition that can have profound psychological implications. However, the nature of the relationship between emotional disturbance and chronic pain remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate whether emotional disturbance acts as a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain. Participants with chronic pain were assessed for various psychological factors, including anxiety, depression, and stress levels. Additionally, pain intensity and duration were measured. The results showed a significant positive relationship between emotional disturbance and pain severity, indicating that psychological factors may contribute to the perpetuation of pain. Furthermore, a temporal analysis suggested that emotional disturbance may act as both a precipitator and a consequence of chronic pain, suggesting a bidirectional relationship. These findings highlight the importance of addressing emotional well-being in the management of chronic pain to improve patient outcomes.

Decision criteria for pure-tone detection used by two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. The ability to detect pure-tone stimuli is essential for speech perception and communication in everyday life. This study aimed to investigate the decision criteria used by two age groups (young and older) of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired individuals during pure-tone detection tasks. The results revealed that both age groups of normal-hearing listeners displayed similar decision criteria, with higher thresholds for older individuals. In contrast, hearing-impaired participants exhibited different decision criteria, characterized by higher thresholds and a more conservative response bias. These findings suggest that age and hearing status play a crucial role in determining the decision criteria used in pure-tone detection tasks, highlighting the importance of individualized management strategies for individuals with hearing impairment.

Analysis of alterations in the retinoblastoma gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. This study aimed to investigate the correlation between alterations in the retinoblastoma (RB) gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. A total of 80 patients diagnosed with bone and soft-tissue sarcomas were included in the study. Tumor grade was determined based on histopathological analysis, and RB gene alterations were analyzed using molecular techniques. The results showed that alterations in the RB gene were significantly associated with higher tumor grade in both bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. Specifically, a higher frequency of RB gene alterations was observed in high-grade tumors compared to low-grade tumors. This finding suggests that RB gene alterations may play a role in the progression and aggressiveness of bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. Further investigation is warranted to elucidate the mechanism underlying this association and to explore the potential use of RB gene alterations as a prognostic marker for sarcoma patients.

Pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats: muscarinic regulation of indole metabolism.  1. The pineal gland plays a crucial role in regulating circadian rhythms and melatonin synthesis. Previous studies have suggested a potential link between pineal dysfunction and hypertension. In this study, we investigated pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and its regulation by muscarinic receptors. Using immunohistochemical analysis, we found an increased expression of indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO), the rate-limiting enzyme in indole metabolism, in the pineal glands of SHR compared to normotensive control rats. Additionally, we observed elevated levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), a major metabolite of indoleamine, in the cerebrospinal fluid of SHR. Pharmacological blockade of muscarinic receptors attenuated the hyperactivity of IDO in SHR, suggesting a muscarinic regulation of pineal function. These findings provide novel insights into the potential involvement of pineal dysfunction and indole metabolism in the pathogenesis of hypertension. Further investigations are needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this relationship and the therapeutic implications for hypertension management.

Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. Anton's syndrome, also known as Anton-Babinski syndrome, is a rare condition characterized by visual anosognosia, or denial of visual loss, in which the patient is unaware of their blindness despite objective evidence of visual dysfunction. This case report presents a patient with Anton's syndrome following posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. The patient, a 45-year-old male, sustained a severe head injury in a motor vehicle accident. Initial examination showed bilateral optic disc edema and decreased visual acuity. However, the patient adamantly denied any visual impairments and exhibited confabulation to compensate for his blindness. Imaging revealed optic nerve damage and contusions in the frontal lobes. This case emphasizes the importance of considering Anton's syndrome in patients with traumatic brain injuries and associated visual dysfunction, as it has implications for rehabilitation strategies and quality of life.

Oral squamous cell carcinoma arising in a patient with long-standing lichen planus. A case report and literature review. Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) is known to occur in patients with lichen planus (LP), a chronic mucocutaneous inflammatory disease. However, the exact relationship between LP and the development of OSCC remains unclear. We present a case of a 64-year-old female with a 10-year history of LP who developed OSCC in the oral cavity. The patient had no known risk factors for OSCC, such as tobacco or alcohol use. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of OSCC. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. This case highlights the importance of regular monitoring and surveillance of patients with LP for the early detection of OSCC, as they may be at increased risk for malignancy.

Pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. The aim of this study was to investigate the levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. Serum samples from 150 patients with chronic cardiovascular disease (CVD) and 150 patients with obstructive lung disease (OLD) were collected and analyzed for the presence of serotype-specific pneumococcal IgG antibodies using a multiplexed bead-based immunoassay. The results were compared to a control group consisting of 150 healthy individuals. Overall, patients with CVD had lower levels of IgG antibodies against pneumococcal serotypes compared to healthy controls (P < 0.001). In contrast, patients with OLD had significantly higher levels of IgG antibodies against pneumococcal serotypes compared to healthy controls (P < 0.001). These findings suggest a potential dysregulation of the immune response to pneumococcal infections in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease, which may have implications for vaccination strategies in these patient populations.

Awareness during caesarean section.  Between 1982 and 1989 over 3000 patients were questioned about recall and dreaming after general anaesthesia for Caesarean section. In this study, a retrospective analysis was conducted on over 3000 patients who underwent general anesthesia for Caesarean section between 1982 and 1989 to investigate the occurrence of awareness and dreaming during the procedure. Data was collected through structured questionnaires and interviews with the patients postoperatively.

Results showed that a significant proportion of patients reported experiencing awareness during their Caesarean section, with some even recalling specific details of the surgery. Additionally, a substantial number of patients reported having dreams during the procedure.

These findings highlight the potential occurrence of awareness and dreaming under general anesthesia during Caesarean section, emphasizing the importance of careful monitoring and optimal anesthetic management to minimize such events. Further research is needed to explore the underlying factors contributing to these phenomena and to develop strategies to prevent or manage them effectively.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites, a rare complication of chronic pancreatitis, is characterized by the accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity. The definitive treatment for pancreatic ascites often involves surgical intervention, such as pancreatic duct drainage or distal pancreatectomy. However, these procedures are associated with significant morbidity and mortality. 

We report a case of a 55-year-old male with chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic ascites who underwent treatment with continuous somatostatin infusion. The patient was admitted with signs and symptoms of abdominal distension, pain, and respiratory distress. Diagnostic investigations confirmed the presence of pancreatic ascites, and conservative management failed to improve his symptoms. 

Continuous somatostatin infusion was initiated to reduce the production and secretion of pancreatic enzymes, which are responsible for the formation of pancreatic fluid. The patient showed significant improvement in symptoms, with a decrease in abdominal distension and pain, as well as improved respiratory function. This case highlights continuous somatostatin infusion as a potential non-surgical treatment option for pancreatic ascites, providing relief and avoiding the associated risks of surgical interventions. Further studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this approach.

Colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age.  From 1973 to 1985, 105 patients under 40 years of age were treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute. Colorectal adenocarcinoma is typically considered a disease of older individuals, but cases among younger patients have been observed. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the characteristics and outcomes of colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients under 40 years of age. Data was collected from 105 patients treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute between 1973 and 1985. The majority of patients were female (56.2%) and presented with advanced disease (stage III or IV, 66.7%). The most common location of the tumor was the rectum (51.4%). Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with 82.9% of patients undergoing curative-intent surgery. The overall 5-year survival rate was 53.8%. These findings highlight the need for increased awareness and surveillance of colorectal adenocarcinoma in younger patients, as well as further research to understand the possible etiological factors contributing to its occurrence at such a young age.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. Periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) is a common finding in infants on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). However, the significance and prognosis of PVH in this age group is still unclear. In this retrospective study, we evaluated 21 infants younger than 12 months of age who were diagnosed with PVH on MRI. We assessed the clinical characteristics, neurodevelopmental outcomes, and associated risk factors in these infants. Our results showed that PVH was associated with a variety of etiologies, including prematurity, perinatal hypoxic-ischemic injury, and congenital infections. We also observed a range of neurodevelopmental outcomes, with some infants showing normal development while others had cognitive and motor delays. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to better understand the long-term implications of PVH in infancy.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. Further investigations including ultrasound, CT scan and MRI revealed a mass in the biliary tract. A biopsy was performed and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive reactivity for S100 protein and Melan-A, further supporting the diagnosis. The patient underwent surgical resection of the mass followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. However, despite aggressive treatment, the patient experienced tumor recurrence and metastasis to the liver. Palliative treatment was initiated to alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life. Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract is an extremely rare and aggressive malignancy with poor prognosis. Early diagnosis, prompt intervention, and close monitoring are crucial for improving patient outcomes.

Extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for retinal reattachment in advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy cases. We present a surgical technique involving extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for the treatment of retinal reattachment in advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) cases. This case series included 15 patients with severe recurrent retinal detachment due to PVR. All cases underwent pars plana vitrectomy with extensive peripheral retinectomy and posterior 360 degrees retinotomy. Anatomical success was achieved in 12 out of 15 cases (80%) at the final follow-up visit, with a mean follow-up duration of 14 months. Visual acuity improved in 10 cases (66.7%) postoperatively. However, postoperative complications, including cataract progression and intraocular pressure elevation, were observed in some cases. This surgical technique shows promise in achieving retinal reattachment in advanced PVR cases, although careful consideration of potential complications is necessary.

Post-traumatic bile fistulae.  Bile leakage after liver injury has been reported to be a complication associated with significant mortality. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the incidence and associated mortality of post-traumatic bile fistulae after liver injury. A total of 62 patients with bile leakage following liver injury were included in the study. The majority of cases were due to blunt non-penetrating trauma (74%), with the remaining attributed to penetrating trauma. The overall mortality rate in this patient population was 27%. A significantly higher mortality rate (54%) was observed in patients with bile fistulae compared to those without (7%). The mean time to diagnosis of bile fistulae was 7 days post-injury. The most common diagnostic method used was abdominal ultrasound (85%). Surgical intervention was required in 42% of patients, with bile duct repair being performed in the majority of cases. Complications associated with surgical intervention included wound infections, postoperative bleeding, and biliary stenosis. In conclusion, post-traumatic bile fistulae are a serious complication of liver injury and are associated with a high mortality rate. Early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention are essential in improving patient outcomes.

Absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of myasthenia gravis patients. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. The thymus gland is believed to play a role in the pathogenesis of MG, as it is commonly associated with thymic abnormalities such as thymomas. Acetylcholine (ACh) is a neurotransmitter involved in neuromuscular transmission and is known to be dysregulated in MG. This study aimed to investigate the presence of ACh-induced currents in epithelial cells derived from thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients.

Epithelial cells were obtained from 17 MG patients undergoing thymectomy for the treatment of thymomas, as well as from 10 non-MG patients without thymomas undergoing thymectomy for other indications. Patch clamp recordings were performed to measure ACh-induced currents in these cells.

Interestingly, ACh-induced currents were absent in epithelial cells from both thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients. However, normal ACh-induced currents were observed in epithelial cells from non-MG patients. This finding suggests a potential defect in ACh signaling in thymic epithelial cells of MG patients, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of this autoimmune disorder.
