We report a case of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium, which was successfully resected using cardiopulmonary bypass. A 58-year-old male with chronic hepatitis B presented with symptoms of abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging studies revealed a large hepatic mass with extension into the inferior vena cava and right atrium. After thorough preoperative evaluation, the patient underwent a combined liver resection and cardiopulmonary bypass-assisted tumor thrombectomy. The procedure was technically challenging due to the extent of tumor thrombus and involvement of the right atrium. However, complete resection of the tumor and thrombus was achieved without any complications. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and has been followed up for 18 months without evidence of tumor recurrence. This case highlights the feasibility and effectiveness of employing cardiopulmonary bypass in the surgical management of HCC with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium.

Clinical results of femoropopliteal bypass using externally supported (EXS) Dacron grafts: with a comparison of above- and below-knee anastomosis.  As of the end of September 1989, 52 EXS Dacron grafts had been implanted for femoropopliteal bypass operations. The clinical outcomes of femoropopliteal bypass using externally supported (EXS) Dacron grafts were evaluated, specifically comparing above-knee (AK) and below-knee (BK) anastomosis techniques. A total of 52 patients underwent this procedure by the end of September 1989. The patency rates at 1, 3, and 5 years were 83.3%, 72.5%, and 70%, respectively, for AK anastomosis, and 77.3%, 62.2%, and 54.2%, respectively, for BK anastomosis. The difference in patency rates between the two techniques was not statistically significant. However, the limb salvage rate was significantly higher with AK anastomosis compared to BK anastomosis (87% vs 61%, p=0.02). EXS Dacron grafts show promising results for femoropopliteal bypass, with AK anastomosis potentially providing better limb salvage outcomes.

DNA analysis of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas.  The authors used retrospective quantitative DNA analysis to study interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas in seven patients. The study aimed to investigate the genetic characteristics and potential clonal relationships among multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas (RCCs). Retrospective quantitative DNA analysis was performed on tumor samples from seven patients with multiple synchronous RCCs. The authors utilized flow cytometry to measure DNA content and determine the DNA index and S-phase fraction. 

The results showed varying DNA indices and S-phase fractions among the multiple RCCs in each patient, indicating genetic heterogeneity. Clonal relationships between synchronous RCCs were observed in five out of the seven patients, suggesting a common clonal origin or clonal evolution. The remaining two patients exhibited independent clonal origins of their synchronous RCCs. 

These findings highlight the complexity and diversity of multiple synchronous RCCs. Understanding the genetic characteristics and clonal relationships of these tumors can provide valuable insights into their development and potentially guide personalized treatment strategies. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these genetic findings in multiple synchronous RCCs.

Removal of radiation-induced cataracts in patients treated for retinoblastoma.  Experience with removal of radiation-induced cataract in patients treated for retinoblastoma is limited. We present our experience with the removal of radiation-induced cataracts in patients treated for retinoblastoma. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 23 patients who underwent cataract surgery following radiotherapy for retinoblastoma. The mean age at the time of cataract surgery was 8 years and the mean time interval between completion of radiotherapy and cataract surgery was 5.5 years. Visual acuity and intraocular pressure were measured preoperatively and at follow-up visits. The majority of patients experienced improvement in visual acuity following surgery, with 65% achieving a visual acuity of 20/40 or better. Intraocular pressure remained within normal range in all patients. Complications related to surgery were minimal. Our findings suggest that removal of radiation-induced cataracts in retinoblastoma patients can lead to significant visual improvement with acceptable safety outcomes.

Granular cell tumor of the esophagus: endoscopic ultrasonographic demonstration and endoscopic removal. Granular cell tumors (GCTs) of the esophagus are rare and benign neoplasms. We present a case of a 45-year-old female who underwent endoscopy for evaluation of dysphagia and was found to have a submucosal mass in the mid-esophageal region. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) was performed, which revealed a hypoechoic mass arising from the fourth layer of the esophageal wall, consistent with a GCT. The patient underwent endoscopic removal of the tumor using a snare polypectomy technique. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of GCT. EUS played a crucial role in the preoperative evaluation and guided the endoscopic removal of the tumor, highlighting its utility in the management of esophageal GCTs. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of endoscopic removal in these cases.

Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices.  Report of a case and review of the literature. We report a case of islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices. A 53-year-old male presented with hematemesis and melena. Endoscopy revealed isolated gastric varices in the fundus of the stomach. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed a mass in the pancreas. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the pancreatic mass confirmed the diagnosis of islet cell carcinoma. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor along with a distal pancreatectomy. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of islet cell carcinoma. Postoperative follow-up showed resolution of the bleeding episodes and the patient remained asymptomatic for six months. This case highlights the importance of considering islet cell carcinoma as a rare cause of bleeding from isolated gastric varices and emphasizes the role of imaging and biopsy in the diagnosis and management of such cases.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. This study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of infants with periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The infants were assessed for underlying etiology, neurological findings, and developmental outcomes. Among the 21 infants, 17 had associated neurologic abnormalities, including hypertonia, hypotonia, and abnormal head circumference growth. Eight infants had abnormal neuroimaging findings in addition to PVH. The most common underlying etiology identified was prematurity, followed by hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Developmental outcomes were assessed at a median age of 12 months, and the majority of infants showed abnormalities in motor, cognitive, or language domains. This study highlights the importance of early detection and thorough evaluation in infants with PVH on MRI to guide appropriate management and intervention strategies for optimal developmental outcomes.

Cytologic diagnosis of aspergillosis in cardiac transplantation. Cardiac transplantation recipients are at increased risk for opportunistic infections, including fungal infections such as aspergillosis. However, the diagnosis of aspergillosis in these patients can be challenging, especially when relying solely on cytologic evaluation. We present a case of a cardiac transplant recipient who developed aspergillosis and underwent fine-needle aspiration (FNA) for a suspicious lung nodule. Cytologic evaluation of the FNA specimen showed abundant neutrophils and septate hyphae consistent with Aspergillus species. This diagnosis was confirmed by fungal culture and subsequent histopathologic examination. Our case highlights the importance of considering aspergillosis in the differential diagnosis of lung nodules in cardiac transplant recipients and the limitations of cytologic evaluation alone for diagnosing fungal infections in this population.

Genotypic analyses of Richter's syndrome. Richter's syndrome is a transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) into an aggressive lymphoma. Multiple genetic aberrations have been identified in Richter's syndrome, but their frequency and clinical significance remain unclear. In this study, we performed genotypic analyses on a cohort of patients with Richter's syndrome to identify the most prevalent genetic alterations associated with this aggressive transformation. By using array-based comparative genomic hybridization and next-generation sequencing techniques, we identified recurrent deletions and amplifications in key oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. In addition, we identified novel mutations in genes involved in DNA repair, cell cycle regulation, and apoptosis. Our results suggest that Richter's syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease with complex genomic alterations. The identification of these genetic aberrations could potentially improve prognostication and guide therapeutic strategies in patients with Richter's syndrome. Further investigations are required to validate and expand upon our findings.

On the inheritance of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a common and potentially life-threatening condition. Inheritance patterns of AAA have been of interest to researchers, as understanding the genetic basis of the disease could help identify individuals at risk and guide screening and prevention strategies. This study aimed to examine the inheritance patterns of AAA in a large cohort of patients. Through genetic testing and family history assessments, we identified a strong familial component in the development of AAA. Our results suggest that AAA has a complex inheritance pattern, including both autosomal dominant and multifactorial inheritance. This finding highlights the importance of genetic counseling and screening for individuals with a family history of AAA. Further research is needed to identify specific genes and genetic variants associated with AAA development, which could lead to improved risk assessment and targeted interventions for affected individuals and their families.

Genotypic analyses of Richter's syndrome. Richter's syndrome is a rare and aggressive transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) into high-grade lymphoma, typically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), and is associated with poor prognosis. Genetic abnormalities in Richter's syndrome have not been extensively studied. In this study, we performed genotypic analyses on a cohort of 27 patients with Richter's syndrome to identify recurrent genetic alterations and potential therapeutic targets. Whole-exome sequencing and targeted sequencing were performed, revealing frequent mutations in genes such as TP53, NOTCH1, and SF3B1. Additionally, copy number alterations in genes including MYC and CDKN2A were detected. Our findings highlight the complexity of Richter's syndrome and provide insights into potential therapeutic strategies. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and develop personalized treatment approaches for patients with Richter's syndrome.

Differentiation in embryonal neuroepithelial tumors of the central nervous system. Embryonal neuroepithelial tumors (NETs) of the central nervous system (CNS) are a group of highly malignant neoplasms that predominantly affect children and young adults. This study aimed to investigate the differentiation patterns observed in NETs and their clinical implications. A total of 54 patients with NETs were included in the analysis, and histopathological examinations were performed on their tumor samples. Three main differentiation patterns were identified: neuroblastoma-like, medulloblastoma-like, and ependymoblastoma-like. Additionally, mixed patterns were observed in some cases. Differences in clinical features, including age at diagnosis, tumor location, and overall survival, were found among the differentiation patterns. Patients with neuroblastoma-like tumors tended to be younger at diagnosis and had a poorer prognosis compared to those with medulloblastoma-like tumors. These findings highlight the importance of considering the differentiation patterns in the diagnosis and treatment of NETs, as they could guide clinicians in selecting appropriate therapeutic strategies and predicting patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms driving these differentiation patterns in NETs.

Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH in normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. This study aimed to investigate the pH levels in the gastrointestinal tract of normal subjects, as well as individuals with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. pH levels were measured in the stomach, duodenum, jejunum, and colon using a pH-sensitive electrode. Results showed that the pH in the stomach and duodenum were significantly lower in subjects with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma compared to normal subjects. However, there were no significant differences in pH levels between normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma in the jejunum and colon. These findings suggest that alterations in luminal pH may play a role in the development of colorectal adenoma or carcinoma, particularly in the upper gastrointestinal tract. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

Stressful events and life satisfaction among elderly men and women.  The purpose of this study was to examine the interrelationships among stressful events, domain-specific assessments of life satisfaction, and global evaluations of life satisfaction. This study aimed to investigate the associations between stressful events, domain-specific assessments of life satisfaction, and global evaluations of life satisfaction in elderly men and women. A sample of 300 participants aged 65 and older completed self-report measures assessing stressful events, domain-specific life satisfaction, and global life satisfaction. Results showed that there was a significant negative correlation between number of stressful events and global life satisfaction. Furthermore, domain-specific life satisfaction in the areas of health, relationships, and leisure activities mediated the relationship between stressful events and global life satisfaction. These findings highlight the importance of considering both specific life domains and overall life satisfaction in assessing the impact of stressful events on elderly individuals' well-being. Targeted interventions aimed at improving satisfaction in these specific domains may have a positive impact on overall life satisfaction in this population.

The natural history of left ventricular spontaneous contrast.  Spontaneous contrast in the left ventricle is an unusual entity. Left ventricular spontaneous contrast (LVSC) is a rare phenomenon characterized by the presence of swirling patterns or smoke-like echoes within the left ventricular cavity on echocardiography. This study aims to investigate the natural history of LVSC and its clinical implications. 

A retrospective analysis of patients with LVSC detected on echocardiography was performed. Clinical characteristics, echocardiographic parameters, and clinical outcomes were analyzed. 

A total of 45 patients with LVSC were included in the study. The majority of patients were male (64%) and had underlying cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension (73%) and dyslipidemia (53%). The most common underlying cardiac pathology was ischemic heart disease (49%). 

During a mean follow-up period of 24 months, 33% of patients experienced adverse cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction, stroke, and cardiovascular death. The presence of LVSC was associated with a higher incidence of adverse events (p<0.001). 

In conclusion, LVSC is a marker of increased cardiovascular risk and is associated with adverse clinical outcomes. Its detection on echocardiography should prompt further evaluation and aggressive management of underlying cardiovascular risk factors.

A pitfall in azygos vein cannulation in cirrhotic patients: mistaken cannulation of the mammary vein. Cannulation of the azygos vein plays a vital role in the management of cirrhotic patients with portal hypertension. However, in some cases, there can be a potential pitfall of mistakenly cannulating the mammary vein instead. This misplacement can lead to complications, such as bleeding, embolism, and impaired hemodynamics. This abstract presents a case report of a cirrhotic patient who underwent a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt procedure, during which the mammary vein was accidentally cannulated instead of the azygos vein. Prompt recognition and intervention were necessary to prevent further complications. Awareness of this potential pitfall is crucial for interventional radiologists and clinicians to ensure accurate cannulation and optimize patient outcomes in cirrhotic patients with portal hypertension.

Argon versus krypton panretinal photocoagulation side effects on the anterior segment. The purpose of this study was to compare the side effects of argon and krypton panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) on the anterior segment of the eye. A total of 50 patients with proliferative diabetic retinopathy were randomly assigned to receive either argon or krypton PRP. The anterior segment side effects, including corneal epithelial defects, corneal edema, anterior chamber inflammation, and intraocular pressure changes, were evaluated before and after the PRP treatment. The results showed that both argon and krypton PRP caused similar anterior segment side effects, with corneal epithelial defects being the most common side effect in both groups. However, the incidence and severity of corneal edema and anterior chamber inflammation were slightly higher in the argon group compared to the krypton group. Overall, both argon and krypton PRP were found to be effective in treating proliferative diabetic retinopathy, with similar but slightly different side effect profiles on the anterior segment.

Neuro-imaging and positron emission tomography of congenital homonymous hemianopsia. Congenital homonymous hemianopsia is a rare condition characterized by decreased vision in both eyes on the same side of the visual field. We present a case of congenital homonymous hemianopsia in a 14-year-old male, assessed with neuro-imaging and positron emission tomography (PET). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed structural abnormalities in the optic radiations and visual cortex, confirming the diagnosis. PET scans showed decreased glucose metabolism in the affected visual cortex, further supporting the hypothesis of neuronal dysfunction in the visual pathway. This case highlights the potential utility of neuro-imaging and PET in evaluating and understanding the underlying pathophysiology of congenital homonymous hemianopsia. Further research is needed to explore potential therapeutic approaches for this condition.

Vector short-latency somatosensory-evoked potentials after median nerve stimulation. Short-latency somatosensory-evoked potentials (SLSEP) are an important tool for assessing peripheral nerve function. This study aimed to investigate the use of SLSEP in assessing the median nerve after stimulation. A total of 30 healthy subjects were included in the study and SLSEP was recorded following median nerve stimulation at the wrist. The results showed distinct waveform patterns, including N20, P25, N30, and P45, with corresponding latencies ranging from 20 to 45 milliseconds. These observations indicate that SLSEP measurements can accurately reflect the conduction of the median nerve and provide valuable information regarding the integrity of the somatosensory pathways. This technique may have clinical implications in the diagnosis and monitoring of peripheral nerve disorders and can potentially aid in the development of targeted interventions for nerve regeneration and rehabilitation.

Contracturing granulomatous myositis: a separate entity. Contracturing granulomatous myositis (CGM) is a rare inflammatory myopathy characterized by chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and contracture formation in skeletal muscle. This study aims to demonstrate that CGM is a distinct entity within the spectrum of myositides. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 25 patients diagnosed with CGM, who were compared with 50 patients diagnosed with other forms of myositis. Clinical features, laboratory findings, muscle biopsy specimens, and treatment outcomes were analyzed. CGM patients had a mean age of onset of 47 years and predominantly presented with proximal muscle weakness and contractures. Muscle biopsy specimens revealed lymphocyte-rich granulomas and significant fibrosis in affected muscles. Compared to other myositis patients, CGM patients had significantly higher levels of inflammatory markers and a poorer response to standard immunosuppressive therapy. These findings suggest that CGM represents a distinct subgroup of myositis, with unique clinical and pathological features. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatment strategies for CGM.

Acinic cell carcinoma.  Clinicopathologic review. Acinic cell carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor originating from the salivary glands. This study presents a clinicopathologic review of acinic cell carcinoma, aiming to provide a comprehensive understanding of its characteristics and management. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed with acinic cell carcinoma between 2000 and 2019. The clinicopathologic features, treatment modalities, and outcomes were assessed. 

A total of 45 patients were included in the study, with a mean age at diagnosis of 51 years. The most common site of involvement was the parotid gland (80%), followed by the submandibular gland (11%). Histologically, the majority of cases exhibited characteristic acinic cell differentiation, with occasional areas of atypical features. 

Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with adjuvant radiotherapy administered in cases with high-risk features. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 72%. However, patients with advanced stage disease or distant metastasis had a significantly lower survival rate. 

In conclusion, acinic cell carcinoma is a rare malignancy of the salivary glands with distinct clinicopathologic features. Surgical resection remains the mainstay of treatment, with adjuvant therapy considered based on risk factors. Further research is needed to improve our understanding and management of this rare tumor.

The Ams (altered mRNA stability) protein and ribonuclease E are encoded by the same structural gene of Escherichia coli. The relationship between the Ams protein and ribonuclease E in Escherichia coli has been studied to determine their functional roles in mRNA stability. Through genetic analysis and biochemical assays, it was revealed that the Ams protein and ribonuclease E are encoded by the same structural gene in E. coli. This finding suggests that the Ams protein and ribonuclease E may have overlapping or interconnected functions in regulating mRNA stability. Further investigation is required to elucidate the specific mechanisms by which these proteins interact and affect mRNA degradation. Understanding the intricacies of mRNA stability regulation is crucial for deciphering gene expression patterns and gene regulation in bacterial cells. This knowledge may have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting mRNA stability in bacterial infections and other pathological conditions.

Cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a renal disorder characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. Although it primarily affects the kidneys, it has been associated with various systemic complications, including cardiovascular events. Cerebral infarction, a known consequence of vascular events, has been reported in patients with nephrotic syndrome, but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the incidence and risk factors for cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. A total of 287 patients with nephrotic syndrome were enrolled, and their medical records were reviewed. The incidence of cerebral infarction was found to be 8.4% in this cohort. Furthermore, age, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypoalbuminemia were identified as independent risk factors for the development of cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. These findings highlight the importance of careful monitoring and appropriate management of cardiovascular risk factors in patients with nephrotic syndrome to prevent cerebral infarction and subsequent morbidity and mortality.

Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis and segmental dilatation. Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation are congenital anomalies of the small intestine that can cause significant morbidity and mortality if not promptly diagnosed and treated. This study aimed to evaluate the radiographic techniques and efficacy in diagnosing these conditions. Various imaging modalities were used, including prenatal ultrasound, neonatal abdominal radiography, contrast-enhanced fluoroscopy, and computed tomography (CT). Prenatal ultrasound can provide valuable information about the presence and location of the obstruction. Neonatal abdominal radiography is an initial screening tool to identify signs of bowel obstruction, such as air-fluid levels or distended loops of bowel. Contrast-enhanced fluoroscopy, particularly with upper gastrointestinal series, can further assess the morphology and function of the small bowel. CT is reserved for cases with diagnostic uncertainty or suspicion of associated anomalies. Overall, a multi-modal approach combining these radiographic techniques can aid in diagnosing and determining the appropriate management of neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation.

The perineal artificial sphincter for acquired incontinence--a cut and dried solution? Sixteen males with stress incontinence due to sphincter damage were investigated with videourodynamic studies after implantation of a perineal artificial urinary sphincter. The use of a perineal artificial urinary sphincter in treating acquired incontinence due to sphincter damage was evaluated in a study of sixteen male patients. Videourodynamic studies were conducted after the implantation of the device to assess its efficacy in managing stress incontinence. Results showed that the perineal artificial sphincter provided a reliable solution for urinary incontinence, with significant improvements in urinary control indicated by reduced leakage episodes and improved bladder capacity. Adverse events were minimal, with only one patient experiencing a device-related complication. The perineal artificial urinary sphincter appears to be a promising treatment option for acquired incontinence in males with sphincter damage, providing a cut and dried solution for this debilitating condition. Further long-term studies are needed to evaluate its durability and continued efficacy.

Growth, thermogenesis, and hyperphagia. Growth, thermogenesis, and hyperphagia are intricately connected physiological processes that regulate energy balance and body weight. In this review, we explore the interplay between these processes and their impact on overall metabolic homeostasis. Growth, primarily regulated by growth hormone and insulin-like growth factor 1, is essential for development and tissue maintenance. On the other hand, thermogenesis, driven by brown adipose tissue activation and uncoupling protein 1 activity, plays a critical role in energy dissipation and regulation of body temperature. Hyperphagia, characterized by increased food intake, may occur in response to growth or thermogenic demands, as well as other factors such as hormonal imbalances or pathological conditions. Understanding the complex mechanisms that govern these processes is crucial for the development of therapeutic interventions targeting obesity and related metabolic disorders. Therapies aimed at promoting healthy growth, enhancing thermogenic capacity, and modulating appetite regulation may hold promise in the fight against obesity.

Erythropoietin response to anemia as a function of age.  The erythropoietin (EPO) response to anemia was assessed for 244 subjects aged 1-64 years (mean 45. The aim of this study was to investigate the erythropoietin (EPO) response to anemia in a population ranging from 1 to 64 years of age. A total of 244 subjects were included, with a mean age of 45 years. Hemoglobin levels and EPO concentrations were measured in all participants. The results showed a significant decrease in hemoglobin levels with increasing age. However, the EPO response to anemia differed among age groups. Younger individuals (1-20 years) exhibited a higher EPO response compared to older individuals (21-64 years). These findings suggest that the EPO response to anemia may be age-dependent, with younger individuals showing a more robust response. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and implications of this age-related difference in EPO response.

Neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy in large submucous fibroids. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy in the treatment of large submucous fibroids. Fifteen patients with symptomatic submucous fibroids measuring greater than 5 cm in diameter were included in the study. The neodymium: YAG laser was used to vaporize and remove the fibroids under direct hysteroscopic visualization. The procedure was successful in all patients, with complete removal of the fibroids achieved. Postoperative follow-up revealed significant improvement in symptoms, including reduction in menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. No major complications or adverse events were reported. Neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy appears to be a safe and effective method for the management of large submucous fibroids, offering a minimally invasive alternative to traditional surgical approaches.

Multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. We present two cases of multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses, a rare and challenging condition. Case 1 involved a 54-year-old female with a history of chronic fungal sinusitis, who presented with progressive visual loss and headache. Imaging revealed multiple intracranial mucoceles compressing the optic nerves. Surgical resection of the mucoceles and antifungal therapy resulted in significant improvement of her symptoms. Case 2 involved a 68-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis, who presented with headache and seizures. Imaging revealed multiple intracranial mucoceles extending into the frontal lobes. Surgical drainage of the mucoceles and antifungal therapy led to resolution of his symptoms. Phaeohyphomycosis is a rare fungal infection typically caused by dematiaceous fungi and is often associated with immunocompromised states. The development of intracranial mucoceles in the setting of phaeohyphomycosis is extremely rare and requires a multidisciplinary approach for optimal management. This report highlights the importance of considering fungal etiologies in the differential diagnosis of intracranial mucoceles.

Phospholipids from rat, human, and canine gastric mucosa.  Composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine. This study aimed to investigate the composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine (PC) in the gastric mucosa of rats, humans, and canines. Gastric mucosal tissues were collected from these species and subjected to lipid extraction and analysis. The results revealed that PC was the predominant phospholipid in all three species, accounting for more than 80% of total phospholipids. Analysis of the molecular species of PC showed significant differences among the species, with certain species of PCs being more abundant in rats compared to humans and canines. Furthermore, metabolic labeling experiments using radiolabeled choline demonstrated that the turnover rate of PCs was similar among the three species. Overall, these findings provide valuable insight into the composition and metabolism of PCs in the gastric mucosa of different species, which could have implications for understanding gastric physiology and developing therapeutic interventions for gastric disorders.

Sclerotherapy of varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. Sclerotherapy is a commonly used treatment for varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sclerotherapy in a group of 45 patients with lower extremity varicosities and telangiectasias. The patients were treated with a sclerosing agent injected into the affected veins, and the outcomes were assessed using clinical and ultrasound evaluation at a follow-up of 6 months.

The results demonstrated a high success rate of 90%, with significant improvement in both clinical symptoms and cosmetic appearance. Complications were minimal and included hyperpigmentation and transient discomfort at the injection site. The procedure was well-tolerated by all patients, and there were no instances of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

In conclusion, sclerotherapy is an effective and safe treatment option for varicose and telangiectatic leg veins, providing excellent cosmetic and functional outcomes. Further studies with longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings and assess long-term durability of the treatment.

Quality of life in elderly, chronically ill outpatients.  Quality of life (QL) in elderly outpatients is poorly characterized. The aim of this study was to assess the quality of life (QL) in a population of elderly, chronically ill outpatients. A total of 150 patients aged 65 years and older were included in the study. QL was evaluated using the EuroQol-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D) questionnaire, which includes five dimensions (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression) and a visual analog scale (VAS) for overall health status. The mean EQ-5D index score was 0.63, indicating a moderate impairment in QL. The most affected dimensions were pain/discomfort and mobility. The mean VAS score was 57.84, reflecting a moderate level of overall health status. Older age, female gender, and the presence of multiple comorbidities were associated with lower QL scores. These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to improve the QL of elderly, chronically ill outpatients, particularly in areas such as pain management and mobility assistance.

Comparison of structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments. The structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments were investigated in this study. Five different ligaments were examined: the supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, posterior longitudinal ligament, and anterior longitudinal ligament. 

Histological analysis revealed that all ligaments consisted primarily of collagen fibers, although the organization and composition varied among the ligaments. Mechanical testing showed that the ligamentum flavum had the highest tensile strength, followed by the posterior longitudinal ligament, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and anterior longitudinal ligament. 

These findings suggest that the ligamentum flavum and posterior longitudinal ligament are primarily responsible for providing stability and preventing excessive flexion and extension of the lumbar spine. The supraspinous and interspinous ligaments may play a role in limiting excessive movement in the sagittal plane, while the anterior longitudinal ligament may contribute to maintaining the alignment of the vertebral bodies. 

Understanding the structure and mechanical properties of these ligaments is crucial for the development of surgical techniques and rehabilitation strategies for patients with lumbar spine disorders. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific functions of each ligament and their contributions to spinal stability.

Management of penile gunshot wounds. Penile gunshot wounds are rare and challenging injuries that require immediate and specialized management. We present a case series of three patients with penile gunshot wounds and discuss the management strategies employed. Prompt recognition and early intervention are crucial to minimize morbidity and functional impairment. In all cases, primary surgical exploration was performed to assess the extent of injury and facilitate proper debridement. Penile reconstruction techniques were employed to restore form and function, including primary closure, local flaps, and penile prostheses. Adequate antibiotic prophylaxis and meticulous wound care were essential in preventing infection and promoting healing. Long-term follow-up revealed satisfactory cosmetic and functional outcomes in all patients. These cases highlight the complexity of penile gunshot wounds and emphasize the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving urologists, plastic surgeons, and trauma specialists. This review aims to provide insights into the management of these challenging injuries and aid in decision-making for future cases.

Ocular complications of rheumatic diseases of childhood. Rheumatic diseases of childhood are associated with various ocular complications that can result in significant morbidity if not promptly identified and treated. This review examines the ocular manifestations of childhood rheumatic diseases, including juvenile idiopathic arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and systemic vasculitides. Ocular involvement can range from mild symptoms such as conjunctivitis and dry eyes to severe complications such as uveitis, scleritis, and optic neuritis. These ocular manifestations often occur concurrently with systemic symptoms of the underlying rheumatic disease, but they can also present in isolation. Prompt recognition and multidisciplinary management involving rheumatologists and ophthalmologists are crucial in preventing long-term visual impairment and improving patient outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management strategies for ocular complications in childhood rheumatic diseases.

The Maylard incision in gynecologic surgery The transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision was used in 175 gynecologic patients who required pelvic-abdominal surgery. The Maylard incision is a surgical technique commonly used in gynecologic surgery for pelvic-abdominal procedures. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and efficacy of this incision in 175 gynecologic patients. The incision was performed in patients requiring various gynecologic procedures, including hysterectomy, oophorectomy, and pelvic lymphadenectomy. The results showed that the Maylard incision provided excellent exposure and access to the pelvic and abdominal organs. The incision was associated with minimal blood loss and low rates of complications such as wound infection and dehiscence. Additionally, the incision allowed for a faster recovery and shorter hospital stay. Overall, the Maylard incision was found to be a safe and effective surgical approach in gynecologic surgery, providing optimal exposure and improved patient outcomes.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Gastroparesis, a common complication of diabetes, is characterized by delayed gastric emptying and symptoms of postprandial fullness, nausea, and vomiting. Various treatment options have been explored, including prokinetic agents such as motilin. This study aimed to assess the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis.

A total of 20 patients with confirmed diabetic gastroparesis were enrolled in the study. Each patient underwent a gastric emptying study using a radioactive meal and was then randomly assigned to receive either motilin or placebo for a period of 6 weeks. Gastric emptying was assessed again after the treatment period.

The results showed a significant improvement in gastric emptying time in the motilin group compared to the placebo group. The mean gastric half-emptying time decreased from 147 minutes to 98 minutes in the motilin group, while it remained relatively unchanged in the placebo group. Additionally, the motilin group reported a significant reduction in symptom severity and frequency compared to the placebo group.

In conclusion, motilin appears to be an effective prokinetic agent in improving gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings and explore the long-term effects of motilin in this patient population.

Isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. Griseofulvin, an antifungal medication, has been commonly used for the treatment of dermatophytosis. However, recent studies have reported rare but severe adverse effects associated with long-term griseofulvin therapy. This case report describes a 51-year-old male who presented with isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency after prolonged use of griseofulvin for onychomycosis. The patient had normal renal and hematologic parameters prior to griseofulvin initiation. Upon investigation, bone marrow biopsy revealed erythroid hypoplasia without evidence of other myeloid or lymphoid abnormalities. Renal biopsy demonstrated interstitial nephritis and tubular atrophy. Following discontinuation of griseofulvin, hematologic parameters and renal function gradually improved. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency associated with griseofulvin therapy. Clinicians should be aware of these potential complications and consider close monitoring of renal and hematologic parameters in patients receiving long-term griseofulvin therapy. Further studies are warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and risk factors for these adverse effects.

Doppler diagnostics, indications, and control of surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology. Carotid pathology is a common condition that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Doppler diagnostics has emerged as an important tool for the evaluation of carotid pathology, providing valuable information regarding the hemodynamics of blood flow in the carotid arteries. This abstract aims to review the indications and utility of Doppler diagnostics in the control and management of surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology. Studies have shown that Doppler ultrasound can accurately assess the degree of stenosis in the carotid arteries, guide decisions regarding surgical intervention, and monitor the success of surgical procedures. Furthermore, Doppler ultrasound can also detect postoperative complications such as restenosis and thrombosis, allowing for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. In conclusion, Doppler diagnostics plays a crucial role in the comprehensive management of patients with carotid pathology.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a rare disorder characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia in patients who have ingested high doses of L-tryptophan. This study aimed to investigate the neuromuscular pathology of EMS. Autopsy data from 24 patients with confirmed EMS were analyzed. Histopathological analysis revealed a range of findings including muscle fiber necrosis, fibrosis, and inflammatory infiltrates in affected muscles. Eosinophilic infiltrates were also observed in peripheral nerves and dorsal root ganglia. Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated increased expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I antigens in affected muscle fibers. Electron microscopy revealed mitochondrial abnormalities and evidence of oxidative stress. These findings suggest that EMS is a systemic disorder affecting both muscle and peripheral nerves. The identification of specific neuromuscular pathology in EMS may aid in the diagnosis and treatment of this condition. Further research is needed to fully understand the pathogenesis of EMS and develop targeted therapies.

Atonic pupil: an unusual complication of cataract surgery. We present a case of atonic pupil as an unusual complication following cataract surgery. A 65-year-old female underwent uncomplicated phacoemulsification cataract surgery in her left eye. Postoperatively, she developed a dilated and fixed pupil, which was unresponsive to light and near stimulation. Intraocular pressure was within normal limits and there were no signs of inflammation or infection. Pupil function tests confirmed the diagnosis of atonic pupil. The patient was managed conservatively with topical miotic agents to improve functional vision. A tonic pupil is a rare but recognized complication of ocular surgery, including cataract surgery. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to ensure optimal visual outcomes for affected individuals. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and risk factors associated with this complication.

Lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen: MR appearance. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the magnetic resonance (MR) appearance of lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen. A retrospective analysis of MR imaging scans of 200 patients with low back pain was conducted. The study included patients who had undergone MR imaging between January 2015 and December 2017. The neural foramen was evaluated in terms of nerve size, shape, location, and signal intensity. The results showed that the lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen were typically of oval shape and exhibited hyperintense signal on T2-weighted images. The nerves were observed to pass through the foraminal zone in all cases, with variations in the location and course. This study provides valuable information on the normal MR appearance of lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen, which can aid in the diagnosis and treatment of spinal nerve pathologies.

Synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in the rabbit uterine horn model. Adhesion formation is a common complication following surgical procedures, often leading to significant morbidity and increased healthcare costs. This study aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7), a bioresorbable barrier, and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in a rabbit uterine horn model. Four groups of six rabbits each were included in the study: control (no treatment), INTERCEED(TC7) alone, heparin alone, and a combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin. Adhesions were evaluated macroscopically and histologically 21 days postoperatively. The combination group exhibited significantly lower adhesion scores compared to the control and individual treatment groups (p < 0.05). Histological analysis demonstrated a reduction in inflammation and fibrosis in the combination group compared to the other groups. These findings suggest that the combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin demonstrates synergistic effects in reducing adhesion formation in a rabbit uterine horn model. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical application of this combination therapy in preventing postoperative adhesions.

Intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" report of two cases after pelvic irradiation. We report two cases of intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" that developed after pelvic irradiation. Both cases presented with nonspecific symptoms including abdominal pain, weight loss, and fatigue. Imaging studies revealed multiple intra-abdominal masses with vascular characteristics. Histopathological examination of the resected masses confirmed the diagnosis of angiosarcoma, characterized by proliferating endothelial cells forming irregular vascular channels. Both patients had a history of pelvic irradiation, with the first case receiving radiation for cervical cancer and the second case for prostate cancer. Following the diagnosis, both patients underwent surgical resection of the masses, but despite aggressive treatment, they experienced disease progression and succumbed to the illness. Intra-abdominal angiosarcomatosis is an extremely rare and aggressive condition, and its association with prior pelvic irradiation warrants further investigation. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for this rare complication in patients presenting with intra-abdominal masses and a history of pelvic irradiation.

The risk for systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients with central retinal vein occlusion.  In this cross-sectional study, the authors evaluated 197 patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985 to determine the risk of systemic disease and mortality. The aim of this study was to assess the risk of systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). A total of 197 patients with CRVO were included in this cross-sectional study conducted at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985. The patients' medical records were reviewed to determine the presence of systemic diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and cardiovascular diseases. Additionally, mortality data were collected from the National Death Index. The results showed that patients with CRVO had a significantly higher prevalence of systemic diseases compared to the general population. Furthermore, the mortality rate was found to be higher in patients with CRVO compared to age-matched controls. These findings highlight the importance of early identification and treatment of systemic vascular diseases in patients with CRVO to improve outcomes and reduce mortality risk.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant is a rare complication following liver transplantation, with limited literature available on its radiologic presentation. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the case histories and radiologic findings of eight liver transplant recipients who developed mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, CT, and US imaging were performed for each patient. The study found that mucocele of the cystic duct remnant presented as a localized cystic dilatation in the porta hepatis, with characteristic imaging features including an expansile lesion containing low attenuation fluid on CT and a cystic structure with internal debris or septations on US. Cholangiography clearly demonstrated the cystic nature of the lesion along the cystic duct remnant. Recognition of mucocele of the cystic duct remnant and its radiologic features is crucial for early diagnosis and appropriate management in liver transplant recipients.

'Cystic papilloma' in humans? Demonstration of human papillomavirus in plantar epidermoid cysts. Cystic papilloma, a term traditionally used to describe benign tumors in animals caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, has rarely been reported in humans. In this study, we present three cases of plantar epidermoid cysts, which have histological features resembling cystic papillomas, and demonstrate the presence of HPV DNA in these lesions. The patients, two males and one female, presented with painful plantar nodules that were eventually excised. Histopathological examination revealed epidermoid cysts with characteristic cystic architecture and papillary projections. Immunohistochemical staining showed positivity for p16, a surrogate marker for HPV infection. Further analysis using polymerase chain reaction and DNA sequencing confirmed the presence of HPV DNA in these lesions. These findings suggest that plantar epidermoid cysts may represent a cystic papilloma in humans, caused by HPV infection. This study highlights the importance of considering HPV as a potential etiological agent in the development of epidermoid cysts and emphasizes the need for further research to elucidate the pathogenesis and clinical significance of cystic papillomas in humans.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a rare malignant tumor of the salivary glands, with a tendency for local recurrence and distant metastasis. In this study, flow cytometric DNA content analysis was performed on 34 cases of ACC of the submandibular gland to evaluate its correlation with histologic features and prognosis. The DNA aneuploidy rate was 53%. There was a significant association between DNA aneuploidy and high-grade histologic features, such as cribriform and solid growth patterns. Patients with DNA aneuploidy had significantly worse overall survival rates compared to those with diploidy. The presence of DNA aneuploidy may serve as a prognostic marker for ACC of the submandibular gland and could help guide treatment decisions and follow-up strategy in these patients. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore potential targeted therapies.

Decalcification of a choroidal osteoma. Choroidal osteoma is a rare benign tumor of the eye that can cause visual impairment due to excessive calcification. This case report discusses a 42-year-old female patient who presented with reduced vision in her left eye. Ophthalmological examination revealed a choroidal osteoma with significant calcification. The patient underwent a decalcification procedure, which involved the use of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) solution to dissolve the calcium deposits in the tumor. Following decalcification, the patient experienced improvement in visual acuity and reduction in tumor size. This case highlights the efficacy of decalcification as a treatment option for choroidal osteoma, providing a non-invasive alternative to surgical excision. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and potential complications of this procedure.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Review article. Chronic pelvic pain is a common and debilitating condition that affects many individuals worldwide, particularly women. Despite its high prevalence, the underlying causes and pathophysiology of pelvic pain are not fully understood. This review aims to provide insights into the etiology of pelvic pain by exploring its anatomical and physiological aspects. The pelvic region contains numerous structures, including organs, nerves, and muscles, which can all contribute to the development of pain. Abnormalities in the pelvic floor muscles, hormonal imbalances, inflammation, and nerve dysfunction are identified as potential mechanisms underlying pelvic pain. Understanding the complex interplay between these factors is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of pelvic pain. Further research is needed to unravel the intricate connections between anatomy, physiology, and pelvic pain in order to develop effective treatment strategies.

Expression and characterization of TCA3: a murine inflammatory protein.  TCA3 is a cDNA originally isolated from activated T cells. TCA3 is a murine inflammatory protein that was initially identified in activated T cells. In this study, the expression and characterization of TCA3 were investigated. The cDNA of TCA3 was isolated and further analyzed. The expression of TCA3 was found to be upregulated in various inflammatory conditions, suggesting its potential role in mediating the inflammatory response.

To characterize TCA3, various biochemical and molecular biology techniques were employed. Western blot analysis revealed a specific band corresponding to the predicted size of TCA3. Additionally, immunofluorescence staining demonstrated the localization of TCA3 in the cytoplasm of activated T cells.

Furthermore, functional studies were conducted to investigate the role of TCA3 in the inflammatory process. Knockdown of TCA3 resulted in a significant reduction in the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, indicating its involvement in the regulation of inflammatory signaling pathways.

Overall, this study provides insights into the expression and characterization of TCA3, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target for inflammatory disorders. Further investigation is required to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which TCA3 modulates the inflammatory response and determine its therapeutic potential.

Risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease in the elderly. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of mortality and morbidity in elderly populations. Estimating the effect of risk factors on the development of CVD in this age group requires considering both risk ratios and risk differences. While risk ratios assess the relative effect of a risk factor, risk differences quantify the absolute impact. This study aimed to compare the use of risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of common risk factors for CVD in the elderly.

A comprehensive review of literature was conducted, identifying relevant studies that explored the association between various risk factors and CVD outcomes in elderly populations. Results indicated that risk ratios were more commonly reported but had limitations in assessing the overall impact of risk factors, particularly when baseline risk was low. Conversely, risk differences provided a more comprehensive assessment, depicting the absolute change in disease occurrence associated with specific risk factors.

In conclusion, considering both risk ratios and risk differences provides a more complete understanding of the effect of risk factors on CVD in the elderly. Future studies should aim to report both measures to accurately quantify the impact of risk factors on disease occurrence in this population.

Cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy resulting in renal allograft loss and its successful reuse: a report of two cases. Cyclosporine is commonly used as an immunosuppressive agent in renal transplantation. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a rare but severe side effect of cyclosporine therapy. We present two cases of cyclosporine-induced TMA resulting in renal allograft loss. Both patients initially presented with acute kidney injury and characteristic features of TMA, including thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Despite appropriate management, renal function continued to deteriorate, necessitating renal allograft nephrectomy. Interestingly, both patients subsequently underwent successful retransplantation using the same renal allograft, with normal graft function restored. This report highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly managing cyclosporine-induced TMA to prevent irreversible damage to renal allografts.

Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts. Ovarian cysts are a common gynecological condition that often requires surgical intervention. Laparoscopic management has become the preferred approach due to its minimally invasive nature and associated benefits. In this study, we evaluated the outcomes of laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts in a cohort of patients. A total of 100 patients underwent laparoscopic surgery for ovarian cysts, of which 80% were diagnosed with functional cysts and 20% with pathological cysts. The mean operative time was 60 minutes, with minimal blood loss. Postoperative complications were rare, with only 5% of patients experiencing minor complications such as surgical site infection or urinary retention. Our findings suggest that laparoscopic management is a safe and effective method for the treatment of ovarian cysts, providing excellent surgical outcomes and minimal morbidity.

Facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve: an experimental study in the rabbit. This experimental study aimed to investigate the feasibility of facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve in rabbits. Ten rabbits were included in the study, and facial paralysis was induced by selective nerve injury. After a six-week recovery period, a surgical procedure was performed to connect the trigeminal motor nerve to the paralyzed facial muscles. The animals were followed for six months postoperatively. Results showed successful facial muscle reanimation in all rabbits, with restoration of facial symmetry and functional movement. There were no postoperative complications or adverse effects observed. This study suggests that facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve is a viable option for the management of facial paralysis. Further research is warranted to explore its application in human subjects.

Radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater.  One hundred four consecutive patients who underwent radical resection for ampullary cancer between 1965 and 1989 were retrospectively reviewed. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the outcomes of radical resection in patients with carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. A total of 104 consecutive patients who underwent radical resection for ampullary cancer between 1965 and 1989 were retrospectively reviewed. The majority of patients (82.7%) underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy, while a small subset (17.3%) underwent local excision. The overall 5-year survival rate was 62.5%, with a median survival time of 48 months. The presence of lymph node involvement was found to be a negative prognostic factor, significantly decreasing 5-year survival rates. Furthermore, tumor stage of T3 or greater was also associated with poorer survival outcomes. Local recurrence was observed in 21.2% of patients, while distant metastasis occurred in 7.7% of cases. Radical resection remains a viable treatment option for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater, with favorable long-term survival rates in patients without lymph node involvement or advanced tumor stage.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. The study aimed to investigate the acute and long-term prognosis of patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI). A total of 43 patients with LMI were included in the study, which was conducted using data collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. The patients were followed up over a period of time to assess their prognosis. The study found that the majority of patients experienced initial symptoms such as vertigo, nausea, and ataxia. Over time, the symptoms improved in many patients, with the majority recovering their ability to walk independently. However, some patients continued to experience long-term neurological deficits, including persistent gait disturbance and dysarthria. The study concludes that LMI can have variable outcomes, with a significant proportion of patients experiencing long-term disability.

Carcinoma of female urethra.  Manitoba experience: 1958-1987. Carcinoma of the female urethra is a rare malignancy, constituting less than 1% of all genitourinary tumors. The aim of this study was to analyze the clinical characteristics, treatment approaches, and outcomes of patients with carcinoma of the female urethra in Manitoba, Canada, from 1958 to 1987. A retrospective review was conducted, identifying a total of 24 patients diagnosed with carcinoma of the female urethra during the specified period. The mean age at diagnosis was 64 years, with the majority of patients presenting with advanced disease (stage III or IV). The most common histological subtype was squamous cell carcinoma. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, often combined with radiation therapy. The 5-year overall survival rate was 42%, with higher survival rates observed in patients with localized disease. In conclusion, carcinoma of the female urethra is a rare malignancy associated with poor prognosis, emphasizing the need for early detection and multidisciplinary treatment approaches.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  4. Rehabilitation plays a crucial role in the management of brain disorders, including stroke, traumatic brain injury, and neurodegenerative diseases. The objective of rehabilitation is to optimize functional recovery and minimize disability through targeted interventions and multidisciplinary approaches. Physical therapy focuses on improving motor function, strength, and coordination, while occupational therapy addresses activities of daily living and cognitive abilities. Speech and language therapy aims to enhance communication skills and swallowing function. Cognitive rehabilitation targets cognitive impairments, including attention, memory, and executive functions. Rehabilitation programs also incorporate psychological support, education, and counseling to address emotional and psychological aspects of recovery. Various techniques, such as constraint-induced movement therapy, virtual reality, and robotic-assisted therapy, have been developed to facilitate motor recovery. The efficacy of rehabilitation interventions has been supported by evidence from clinical trials and systematic reviews. However, individualized treatment plans are necessary to cater to the unique needs of each patient. Further research is warranted to investigate the optimal timing, intensity, and duration of rehabilitation interventions for different brain disorders.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. Rectal carcinoid tumors are a rare form of neuroendocrine tumors that arise from the enterochromaffin cells of the rectum. The DNA ploidy pattern of these tumors has not been extensively studied. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the DNA ploidy pattern in a series of rectal carcinoid tumors using flow cytometry. We found that the majority of rectal carcinoid tumors exhibited a diploid DNA content (67%), while a smaller proportion showed aneuploidy (22%) or tetraploidy (11%). Our results suggest that rectal carcinoid tumors have a heterogeneous DNA ploidy pattern, similar to other neuroendocrine tumors. Further studies are needed to evaluate the clinical significance of DNA ploidy in rectal carcinoid tumors and its potential role as a prognostic marker.

Sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features of cervical condylomas. Cervical condylomas, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, are common genital warts with potential risk for malignant transformation. We aimed to determine the sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features in the diagnosis of cervical condylomas. A total of 100 women with histologically confirmed cervical condylomas were included in the study. The presence or absence of specific morphological features, including papillary growth, acanthosis, squamous eddies, koilocytosis, and hyperkeratosis, was assessed. Sensitivity and specificity were calculated for each feature. Papillary growth had the highest sensitivity (88%) and specificity (90%), followed by acanthosis (86% sensitivity, 88% specificity) and squamous eddies (76% sensitivity, 82% specificity). Koilocytosis and hyperkeratosis had lower sensitivity and specificity. Our findings suggest that specific morphological features can aid in the accurate diagnosis of cervical condylomas, with papillary growth being the most reliable feature.

Nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a VA emergency department.  Nursing home residents are frequently transferred to hospital emergency departments. This study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and outcomes of nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a Veterans Affairs (VA) emergency department (ED). A retrospective chart review was conducted on nursing home residents who were transferred to the VA ED via ambulance over a six-month period. The study included 286 transfers, with a mean age of 82 years. The most common reasons for transfer were altered mental status (39%) and falls (26%). Upon arrival at the VA ED, 45% of patients required hospital admission, and the most frequent primary diagnoses were infection (28%) and cardiovascular disease (22%). The average ED length of stay was 4.5 hours. Overall, 30-day mortality was 19%. Factors associated with increased mortality included older age, presence of comorbidities, and need for hospital admission. These findings highlight the high acuity and complex medical needs of nursing home residents transferred to the VA ED, emphasizing the importance of effective communication and coordination between nursing homes and EDs to optimize patient outcomes.

Association of disease-free survival and percent of ideal dose in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the association between disease-free survival and the percent of ideal dose received in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. A total of 120 patients were included in the analysis, all of whom received adjuvant chemotherapy after surgical resection of breast cancer. The percent of ideal dose received was calculated based on the actual dose received relative to the recommended dose. 

After a median follow-up of 5 years, the disease-free survival rate was significantly higher in patients who received a higher percent of ideal dose compared to those who had a lower percent of ideal dose (p < 0.05). Specifically, patients who received at least 90% of the ideal dose had a higher disease-free survival rate compared to those who received less than 90% of the ideal dose. 

These findings suggest that achieving a higher percent of ideal dose in adjuvant breast chemotherapy may contribute to improved disease-free survival outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and guide treatment decisions in the adjuvant setting.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collateral recruitment plays a crucial role in maintaining myocardial perfusion in the setting of coronary artery disease. Animal and human studies have established the existence and functional importance of coronary collaterals. These collateral vessels provide alternative routes for blood flow when the main coronary arteries become occluded or stenosed, preventing myocardial ischemia and improving cardiac function.

Additionally, the rate of vessel closure is a critical factor influencing collateral recruitment. Animal models have shown that gradual vessel closure leads to enhanced collateral development compared to sudden occlusion. This suggests that the time course of occlusion plays a role in collateral vessel growth.

Understanding the functional significance of coronary collateral recruitment and its relationship to the rate of vessel closure can guide the development of therapeutic strategies aimed at promoting collateral vessel growth in patients with coronary artery disease. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms underlying collateral recruitment and its potential clinical implications.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. We report a rare case of a metastatic small cell tumor of bone exhibiting 'true' rosettes and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). A 53-year-old male presented with progressive back pain and was found to have a lytic lesion in the L3 vertebra on imaging studies. A biopsy revealed a small cell tumor characterized by closely packed cells forming 'true' rosettes. Immunohistochemical analysis showed strong positivity for GFAP, a marker typically associated with glial cells. This unique finding prompted a thorough investigation, ruling out a primary brain tumor, and ultimately confirming the metastatic nature of the tumor. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy, which resulted in partial response and alleviation of symptoms. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with GFAP positivity is exceedingly rare, and awareness of this entity is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein. Portal vein aneurysms are rare vascular abnormalities that can be associated with a tortuous portal vein. This case report describes a 58-year-old male presenting with abdominal pain and hepatosplenomegaly. Imaging studies revealed an extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm measuring 2 cm in diameter. Additionally, a tortuous portal vein was identified. The patient underwent surgical resection of the aneurysm due to the risk of rupture and subsequent portal hypertension. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with resolution of symptoms and normalization of liver function tests. Regular follow-up with Doppler ultrasound demonstrated a patent portal vein without evidence of recurrence or thrombosis. This report highlights the importance of considering a tortuous portal vein as a predisposing factor for the development of a portal vein aneurysm and emphasizes the need for surgical intervention to prevent potentially life-threatening complications in such cases.

Pancreaticobiliary ductal union. Pancreaticobiliary ductal union refers to the anatomical arrangement where the pancreatic duct and the common bile duct join together to form a common channel before entering the duodenum. This anatomical variation can be of clinical significance as it may predispose individuals to various pathologies such as choledocholithiasis, pancreatitis, and malignancies. In this retrospective study, we evaluated 200 patients who underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for various indications. We found that 23% of patients had pancreaticobiliary ductal union, with the majority being females (62%). Additionally, patients with this anatomical variation had a higher incidence of choledocholithiasis (38%) compared to those without anatomical variation (18%). Our findings highlight the importance of recognizing pancreaticobiliary ductal union as a potential factor contributing to biliary and pancreatic diseases, especially in females. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and determine appropriate management strategies for patients with this anatomical variant.

Benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene. Benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene, also known as CFTR, have been the subject of much research and debate in the medical community. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical significance of these variations in a large cohort of patients with cystic fibrosis. The researchers analyzed data from over 500 patients and found that benign missense variations were present in approximately 30% of the cohort. These variations were found to have no significant impact on disease severity or progression. Additionally, the researchers assessed the functional consequences of these variations using in vitro assays and found that they did not affect CFTR protein function. These findings suggest that benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene should not be considered pathogenic and should not be used to guide clinical management decisions for patients with cystic fibrosis.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease is a rare glycogen storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of polyglucosan bodies within various tissues, including the liver, muscle, and central nervous system. This abstract describes 15 cases of adult polyglucosan disease, highlighting the clinical and pathological features of the disease. Patients typically present with progressive neurological symptoms such as gait disturbances, lower extremity weakness, and bladder dysfunction. Muscle biopsy reveals the presence of polyglucosan bodies within myocytes. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis, with mutations identified in the glycogen branching enzyme gene (GBE1). Despite limited treatment options, supportive measures and physical therapy can help improve patients' quality of life. Further research is needed to gain a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapies for this rare disorder.

Susceptibility to invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b disease and the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. Invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide. Several factors have been identified as potential risk factors for susceptibility to this disease, including the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. This allotype is associated with decreased antibody response to polysaccharide antigens, such as the Hib capsular polysaccharide. Several studies have shown that children with the G2m(n) allotype are at an increased risk of developing invasive Hib disease. Understanding the role of this allotype in susceptibility to Hib is crucial for the development of effective prevention and treatment strategies, especially in populations where this disease remains a major public health concern.

Effects of prostaglandin E1 on collagen diseases with high levels of circulating immune complexes. This study aimed to investigate the effects of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) on collagen diseases characterized by high levels of circulating immune complexes (CIC). It was hypothesized that PGE1, known for its immune modulatory properties, would have a beneficial effect on these diseases. Thirty patients with collagen diseases and high CIC levels were enrolled in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. They received either PGE1 or a placebo for a period of 12 weeks.
